services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.extraIni.description:
Additional arguments for <command>borg init</command>.
Can also be set at runtime using <literal>$extraInitArgs</literal>.

services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.extraPru.description:
Additional arguments for <command>borg prune</command>.
Can also be set at runtime using <literal>$extraPruneArgs</literal>.

services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.group.description:
The group borg is run as. User or group needs read permission
for the specified <option>paths</option>.

services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.paths.type: list of strings or string convertible to it

services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.postCrea.description:
Shell commands to run after <command>borg create</command>. The name
of the created archive is stored in <literal>$archiveName</literal>.

services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.postHook.description:
Shell commands to run just before exit. They are executed
even if a previous command exits with a non-zero exit code.
The latter is available as <literal>$exitStatus</literal>.

services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.postInit.description: Shell commands to run after <command>borg init</command>.

services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.postPrun.description: Shell commands to run after <command>borg prune</command>.

services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.preHook.description:
Shell commands to run before the backup.
This can for example be used to mount file systems.
services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.preHook.example:
# To add excluded paths at runtime
extraCreateArgs="$extraCreateArgs --exclude /some/path"

services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.privateT.description:
Set the <literal>PrivateTmp</literal> option for
the systemd-service. Set to false if you need sockets
or other files from global /tmp.

services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.prune.ke.description:
Prune a repository by deleting all archives not matching any of the
specified retention options. See <command>borg help prune</command>
for the available options.
services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.prune.ke.type: attribute set of signed integer or string matching the pattern [[:digit:]]+[Hdwmy]s

services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.prune.pr.description:
Only consider archive names starting with this prefix for pruning.
By default, only archives created by this job are considered.
Use <literal>""</literal> to consider all archives.

services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.readWrit.description:
By default, borg cannot write anywhere on the system but
<literal>$HOME/.config/borg</literal> and <literal>$HOME/.cache/borg</literal>.
If, for example, your preHook script needs to dump files
somewhere, put those directories here.

services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.repo.description: Remote or local repository to back up to.

services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.startAt.description:
When or how often the backup should run.
Must be in the format described in
<citerefentry><refentrytitle>systemd.time</refentrytitle>
<manvolnum>7</manvolnum></citerefentry>.
If you do not want the backup to start
automatically, use <literal>[ ]</literal>.

services.borgbackup.jobs.<name>.user.description:
The user <command>borg</command> is run as.
User or group need read permission
for the specified <option>paths</option>.

services.borgbackup.repos.description:
Serve BorgBackup repositories to given public SSH keys,
restricting their access to the repository only.
Also, clients do not need to specify the absolute path when accessing the repository,
i.e. <literal>user@machine:.</literal> is enough. (Note colon and dot.)

services.borgbackup.repos.<name>.allowSu.description:
Allow clients to create repositories in subdirectories of the
specified <option>path</option>. These can be accessed using
<literal>user@machine:path/to/subrepo</literal>. Note that a
<option>quota</option> applies to repositories independently.
Therefore, if this is enabled, clients can create multiple
repositories and upload an arbitrary amount of data.

services.borgbackup.repos.<name>.authori.description:
Public SSH keys that are given full write access to this repository.
You should use a different SSH key for each repository you write to, because
the specified keys are restricted to running <command>borg serve</command>
and can only access this single repository.

Public SSH keys that can only be used to append new data (archives) to the repository.
Note that archives can still be marked as deleted and are subsequently removed from disk
upon accessing the repo with full write access, e.g. when pruning.

services.borgbackup.repos.<name>.group.description:
The group <command>borg serve</command> is run as.
User or group needs write permission
for the specified <option>path</option>.

services.borgbackup.repos.<name>.path.description:
Where to store the backups. Note that the directory
is created automatically, with correct permissions.

services.borgbackup.repos.<name>.quota.description:
Storage quota for the repository. This quota is ensured for all
sub-repositories if <option>allowSubRepos</option> is enabled
but not for the overall storage space used.
services.borgbackup.repos.<name>.quota.type: null or string matching the pattern [[:digit:].]+[KMGTP]?

services.borgbackup.repos.<name>.user.description:
The user <command>borg serve</command> is run as.
User or group needs write permission
for the specified <option>path</option>.

services.bosun.extraConfig.description:
Extra configuration options for Bosun. You should describe your
desired templates, alerts, macros, etc through this configuration
option.

A detailed description of the supported syntax can be found at-spi2-atk
http://bosun.org/configuration.html

services.bosun.group.description: Group account under which bosun runs.

services.bosun.influxHost.description: Host and port of the influxdb database.

services.bosun.ledisDir.description: Path to bosun's ledis data dir

services.bosun.listenAddress.description: The host address and port that bosun's web interface will listen on.

services.bosun.opentsdbHost.description:
Host and port of the OpenTSDB database that stores bosun data.
To disable opentsdb you can pass null as parameter.

services.bosun.user.description: User account under which bosun runs.

services.brltty.enable.description: Whether to enable the BRLTTY daemon.

services.btrfs.autoScrub.enable.description: Whether to enable regular btrfs scrub.

services.btrfs.autoScrub.fileSystems.description:
List of paths to btrfs filesystems to regularily call <command>btrfs scrub</command> on.
Defaults to all mount points with btrfs filesystems.
If you mount a filesystem multiple times or additionally mount subvolumes,
you need to manually specify this list to avoid scrubbing multiple times.

services.btrfs.autoScrub.interval.description:
Systemd calendar expression for when to scrub btrfs filesystems.
The recommended period is a month but could be less
(<citerefentry><refentrytitle>btrfs-scrub</refentrytitle>
<manvolnum>8</manvolnum></citerefentry>).
See
<citerefentry><refentrytitle>systemd.time</refentrytitle>
<manvolnum>7</manvolnum></citerefentry>
for more information on the syntax.

services.buildbot-master.bpPort.description: Port where the master will listen to Buildbot Worker.

services.buildbot-master.enable.description: Whether to enable the Buildbot continuous integration server.

services.buildbot-master.extraConfig.description: Extra configuration to append to master.cfg

services.buildbot-master.extraGroups.description: List of extra groups that the buildbot user should be a part of.

services.buildbot-master.listenAddress.description: Specifies the bind address on which the buildbot HTTP interface listens.

services.buildbot-master.masterCfg.description: Optionally pass master.cfg path. Other options in this configuration will be ignored.

services.buildbot-master.packages.description: Packages to add to PATH for the buildbot process.

services.buildbot-master.port.description: Specifies port number on which the buildbot HTTP interface listens.

services.buildbot-master.pythonPackages.description: Packages to add the to the PYTHONPATH of the buildbot process.

services.buildbot-master.user.description: User the buildbot server should execute under.

services.buildbot-worker.adminMessage.description: Name of the administrator of this worker

services.buildbot-worker.enable.description: Whether to enable the Buildbot Worker.

services.buildbot-worker.extraGroups.description: List of extra groups that the Buildbot Worker user should be a part of.

services.buildbot-worker.group.description: Primary group of buildbot Worker user.

services.buildbot-worker.masterUrl.description: Specifies the Buildbot Worker connection string.

services.buildbot-worker.package.description: Package to use for buildbot worker.

services.buildbot-worker.packages.description: Packages to add to PATH for the buildbot process.

services.buildbot-worker.user.description: User the buildbot Worker should execute under.

services.buildbot-worker.workerPassFile.description: File used to store the Buildbot Worker password

services.buildkite-agent.extraConfig.description: Extra lines to be added verbatim to the configuration file.

services.buildkite-agent.hooks.checkout.description:
The `checkout` hook script will replace the default checkout routine of the
bootstrap.sh script. You can use this hook to do your own SCM checkout
behaviour

services.buildkite-agent.hooks.command.description:
The `command` hook script will replace the default implementation of running
the build command.

services.buildkite-agent.hooks.environme.description:
The `environment` hook will run before all other commands, and can be used
to set up secrets, data, etc. Anything exported in hooks will be available
to the build script.

Note: the contents of this file will be copied to the world-readable
Nix store.

services.buildkite-agent.hooks.post-arti.description: The `post-artifact` hook will run just after artifacts are uploaded

services.buildkite-agent.hooks.post-chec.description:
The `post-checkout` hook will run after the bootstrap script has checked out
your projects source code.

services.buildkite-agent.hooks.post-comm.description:
The `post-command` hook will run after the bootstrap script has run your
build commands

services.buildkite-agent.hooks.pre-artif.description: The `pre-artifact` hook will run just before artifacts are uploaded

services.buildkite-agent.hooks.pre-check.description:
The `pre-checkout` hook will run just before your projects source code is
checked out from your SCM provider

services.buildkite-agent.hooks.pre-comma.description: The `pre-command` hook will run just before your build command runs

services.buildkite-agent.hooks.pre-exit.description: The `pre-exit` hook will run just before your build job finishes

services.buildkite-agent.hooksPath.description:
Path to the directory storing the hooks.
Consider using <option>services.buildkite-agent.hooks.<name></option>
instead.

services.buildkite-agent.meta-data.description: Meta data for the agent. This is a comma-separated list of key=value pairs.

services.buildkite-agent.openssh.private.description:
Private agent key.

A run-time path to the key file, which is supposed to be provisioned
outside of Nix store.

services.buildkite-agent.openssh.publicK.description:
Public agent key.

A run-time path to the key file, which is supposed to be provisioned
outside of Nix store.

services.buildkite-agent.runtimePackages.description: Add programs to the buildkite-agent environment

services.buildkite-agent.tokenPath.description:
The token from your Buildkite "Agents" page.

A run-time path to the token file, which is supposed to be provisioned
outside of Nix store.

services.cachefilesd.enable.description: Whether to enable cachefilesd network filesystems caching daemon.

services.cachefilesd.extraConfig.description: Additional configuration file entries. See cachefilesd.conf(5) for more information.

services.caddy.agree.description: Agree to Let's Encrypt Subscriber Agreement

services.caddy.ca.description: Certificate authority ACME server. The default (Let's Encrypt production server) should be fine for most people.

services.caddy.dataDir.description:
The data directory, for storing certificates. Before 17.09, this
would create a .caddy directory. With 17.09 the contents of the
.caddy directory are in the specified data directory instead.

services.caddy.enable.description: Whether to enable Caddy web server.

services.cadvisor.extraOptions.description:
Additional cadvisor options.

See <link xlink:href='https://github.com/google/cadvisor/blob/master/docs/runtime_options.md'/> for available options.

services.cadvisor.storageDriverPassword.description:
Cadvisor storage driver password.

Warning: this password is stored in the world-readable Nix store. It's
recommended to use the <option>storageDriverPasswordFile</option> option
since that gives you control over the security of the password.
<option>storageDriverPasswordFile</option> also takes precedence over <option>storageDriverPassword</option>.

services.cadvisor.storageDriverPasswordF.description:
File that contains the cadvisor storage driver password.

<option>storageDriverPasswordFile</option> takes precedence over <option>storageDriverPassword</option>

Warning: when <option>storageDriverPassword</option> is non-empty this defaults to a file in the
world-readable Nix store that contains the value of <option>storageDriverPassword</option>.

It's recommended to override this with a path not in the Nix store.
Tip: use <link xlink:href='https://nixos.org/nixops/manual/#idm140737318306400'>nixops key management</link>

services.cadvisor.storageDriverSecure.description: Cadvisor storage driver, enable secure communication.

services.calibre-server.libraryDir.description: The directory where the Calibre library to serve is.

services.canto-daemon.enable.description: Whether to enable the canto RSS daemon.

services.cassandra.allowClients.description:
Enables or disables the native transport server (CQL binary protocol).
This server uses the same address as the <literal>rpcAddress</literal>,
but the port it uses is not <literal>rpc_port</literal> but
<literal>native_transport_port</literal>. See the official Cassandra
docs for more information on these variables and set them using
<literal>extraConfig</literal>.

services.cassandra.clusterName.description:
The name of the cluster.
This setting prevents nodes in one logical cluster from joining
another. All nodes in a cluster must have the same value.

services.cassandra.enable.description:
Whether to enable Apache Cassandra  Scalable and highly available database.
.

services.cassandra.extraConfig.description: Extra options to be merged into cassandra.yaml as nix attribute set.

services.cassandra.fullRepairInterval.description:
Set the interval how often full repairs are run, i.e.
<literal>nodetool repair --full</literal> is executed. See
https://cassandra.apache.org/doc/latest/operating/repair.html
for more information.

Set to <literal>null</literal> to disable full repairs.

services.cassandra.fullRepairOptions.description: Options passed through to the full repair command.

services.cassandra.group.description: Run Apache Cassandra under this group.

services.cassandra.heapNewSize.description:
Must be left blank or set together with heapNewSize.
If left blank a sensible value for the available amount of RAM and CPU
cores is calculated.

Override to set the amount of memory to allocate to the JVM at
start-up. For production use you may wish to adjust this for your
environment. HEAP_NEWSIZE refers to the size of the young
generation.

The main trade-off for the young generation is that the larger it
is, the longer GC pause times will be. The shorter it is, the more
expensive GC will be (usually).

The example HEAP_NEWSIZE assumes a modern 8-core+ machine for decent pause
times. If in doubt, and if you do not particularly want to tweak, go with
100 MB per physical CPU core.

services.cassandra.incrementalRepairInte.description:
Set the interval how often incremental repairs are run, i.e.
<literal>nodetool repair</literal> is executed. See
https://cassandra.apache.org/doc/latest/operating/repair.html
for more information.

Set to <literal>null</literal> to disable incremental repairs.

services.cassandra.incrementalRepairOpti.description: Options passed through to the incremental repair command.

services.cassandra.jmxPort.description:
Specifies the default port over which Cassandra will be available for
JMX connections.
For security reasons, you should not expose this port to the internet.
Firewall it if needed.

services.cassandra.jmxRoles.description:
Roles that are allowed to access the JMX (e.g. nodetool)
BEWARE: The passwords will be stored world readable in the nix-store.
        It's recommended to use your own protected file using
        <literal>jmxRolesFile</literal>

Doesn't work in versions older than 3.11 because they don't like that
it's world readable.

services.cassandra.jmxRolesFile.description:
Specify your own jmx roles file.

Make sure the permissions forbid "others" from reading the file if
you're using Cassandra below version 3.11.

services.cassandra.listenAddress.description:
Address or interface to bind to and tell other Cassandra nodes
to connect to. You _must_ change this if you want multiple
nodes to be able to communicate!

Set listenAddress OR listenInterface, not both.

Leaving it blank leaves it up to
InetAddress.getLocalHost(). This will always do the Right
Thing _if_ the node is properly configured (hostname, name
resolution, etc), and the Right Thing is to use the address
associated with the hostname (it might not be).

Setting listen_address to 0.0.0.0 is always wrong.

services.cassandra.listenInterface.description:
Set listenAddress OR listenInterface, not both. Interfaces
must correspond to a single address, IP aliasing is not
supported.

services.cassandra.logbackConfig.default:
<configuration scan="false">
  <appender name="STDOUT" class="ch.qos.logback.core.ConsoleAppender">
    <encoder>
      <pattern>%-5level %date{HH:mm:ss,SSS} %msg%n</pattern>
    </encoder>
  </appender>

  <root level="INFO">
    <appender-ref ref="STDOUT" />
  </root>

  <logger name="com.thinkaurelius.thrift" level="ERROR"/>
</configuration>

services.cassandra.mallocArenaMax.description: Set this to control the amount of arenas per-thread in glibc.

services.cassandra.maxHeapSize.description:
Must be left blank or set together with heapNewSize.
If left blank a sensible value for the available amount of RAM and CPU
cores is calculated.

Override to set the amount of memory to allocate to the JVM at
start-up. For production use you may wish to adjust this for your
environment. MAX_HEAP_SIZE is the total amount of memory dedicated
to the Java heap. HEAP_NEWSIZE refers to the size of the young
generation.

The main trade-off for the young generation is that the larger it
is, the longer GC pause times will be. The shorter it is, the more
expensive GC will be (usually).

services.cassandra.package.description: The Apache Cassandra package to use.

services.cassandra.remoteJmx.description:
Cassandra ships with JMX accessible *only* from localhost.
To enable remote JMX connections set to true.

Be sure to also enable authentication and/or TLS.
See: https://wiki.apache.org/cassandra/JmxSecurity

services.cassandra.rpcAddress.description:
The address or interface to bind the native transport server to.

Set rpcAddress OR rpcInterface, not both.

Leaving rpcAddress blank has the same effect as on
listenAddress (i.e. it will be based on the configured hostname
of the node).

Note that unlike listenAddress, you can specify 0.0.0.0, but you
must also set extraConfig.broadcast_rpc_address to a value other
than 0.0.0.0.

For security reasons, you should not expose this port to the
internet. Firewall it if needed.

services.cassandra.rpcInterface.description:
Set rpcAddress OR rpcInterface, not both. Interfaces must
correspond to a single address, IP aliasing is not supported.

services.cassandra.seedAddresses.description:
The addresses of hosts designated as contact points in the cluster. A
joining node contacts one of the nodes in the seeds list to learn the
topology of the ring.
Set to 127.0.0.1 for a single node cluster.

services.cassandra.user.description: Run Apache Cassandra under this user.

services.ceph.client.enable.description: Whether to enable Ceph client configuration.

services.ceph.client.extraConfig.description:
Extra configuration to add to the client section. Configuration for rados gateways
would be added here, with their own sections, see example.

services.ceph.enable.description: Whether to enable Ceph global configuration.

services.ceph.extraConfig.description: Extra configuration to add to the global section. Use for setting values that are common for all daemons in the cluster.

services.ceph.global.authClientRequired.description: Enables requiring the cluster to authenticate itself to the client.

services.ceph.global.authClusterRequired.description: Enables requiring daemons to authenticate with eachother in the cluster.

services.ceph.global.authServiceRequired.description: Enables requiring clients to authenticate with the cluster to access services in the cluster (e.g. radosgw, mds or osd).

services.ceph.global.clusterNetwork.description: A comma-separated list of subnets that will be used as cluster networks in the cluster.

services.ceph.global.fsid.description:
Filesystem ID, a generated uuid, its must be generated and set before
attempting to start a cluster

services.ceph.global.maxOpenFiles.description: Max open files for each OSD daemon.

services.ceph.global.mgrModulePath.description: Path at which to find ceph-mgr modules.

services.ceph.global.monHost.description: List of hostname shortnames/IP addresses of the initial monitors.

services.ceph.global.monInitialMembers.description: List of hosts that will be used as monitors at startup.

services.ceph.global.publicNetwork.description: A comma-separated list of subnets that will be used as public networks in the cluster.

services.ceph.global.rgwMimeTypesFile.description: Path to mime types used by radosgw.

services.ceph.mds.daemons.description:
A list of metadata service daemons that should have a service created. The names correspond
to the id part in ceph i.e. [ "name1" ] would result in mds.name1

services.ceph.mds.enable.description: Whether to enable Ceph MDS daemon.

services.ceph.mds.extraConfig.description: Extra configuration to add to the MDS section.

services.ceph.mgr.daemons.description:
A list of names for manager daemons that should have a service created. The names correspond
to the id part in ceph i.e. [ "name1" ] would result in mgr.name1

services.ceph.mgr.enable.description: Whether to enable Ceph MGR daemon.

services.ceph.mgr.extraConfig.description: Extra configuration to add to the global section for manager daemons.

services.ceph.mon.daemons.description:
A list of monitor daemons that should have a service created. The names correspond
to the id part in ceph i.e. [ "name1" ] would result in mon.name1

services.ceph.mon.enable.description: Whether to enable Ceph MON daemon.

services.ceph.mon.extraConfig.description: Extra configuration to add to the monitor section.

services.ceph.osd.daemons.description:
A list of OSD daemons that should have a service created. The names correspond
to the id part in ceph i.e. [ "name1" ] would result in osd.name1

services.ceph.osd.enable.description: Whether to enable Ceph OSD daemon.

services.ceph.osd.extraConfig.description: Extra configuration to add to the OSD section.

services.ceph.rgw.daemons.description:
A list of rados gateway daemons that should have a service created. The names correspond
to the id part in ceph i.e. [ "name1" ] would result in client.name1, radosgw daemons
aren't daemons to cluster in the sense that OSD, MGR or MON daemons are. They are simply
daemons, from ceph, that uses the cluster as a backend.

services.ceph.rgw.enable.description: Whether to enable Ceph RadosGW daemon.

services.certmgr.defaultRemote.description: The default CA host:port to use.

services.certmgr.metricsAddress.description: The address for the Prometheus HTTP endpoint.

services.certmgr.metricsPort.description: The port for the Prometheus HTTP endpoint.
services.certmgr.metricsPort.type: 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

services.certmgr.package.description: Which certmgr package to use in the service.

services.certmgr.renewInterval.description: How often to check certificate expirations and how often to update the cert_next_expires metric.

services.certmgr.specs.description:
Certificate specs as described by:
<link xlink:href="https://github.com/cloudflare/certmgr#certificate-specs" />
These will be added to the Nix store, so they will be world readable.
services.certmgr.specs.type: attribute set of submodule or paths

services.certmgr.svcManager.description:
This specifies the service manager to use for restarting or reloading services.
See: <link xlink:href="https://github.com/cloudflare/certmgr#certmgryaml" />.
For how to use the "command" service manager in particular,
see: <link xlink:href="https://github.com/cloudflare/certmgr#command-svcmgr-and-how-to-use-it" />.

services.certmgr.validMin.description: The interval before a certificate expires to start attempting to renew it.

services.cfdyndns.apikey.description: The API Key to use to authenticate to CloudFlare.

services.cfdyndns.email.description: The email address to use to authenticate to CloudFlare.

services.cfdyndns.enable.description: Whether to enable Cloudflare Dynamic DNS Client.

services.cfdyndns.records.description: The records to update in CloudFlare.

services.cfssl.ca.description: CA used to sign the new certificate -- accepts '[file:]fname' or 'env:varname'.

services.cfssl.configFile.description: Path to configuration file. Do not put this in nix-store as it might contain secrets.

services.cfssl.dbConfig.description: Certificate db configuration file. Path must be writeable.

services.cfssl.enable.description: Whether to enable the CFSSL CA api-server.

services.cfssl.metadata.description:
Metadata file for root certificate presence.
The content of the file is a json dictionary (k,v): each key k is
a SHA-1 digest of a root certificate while value v is a list of key
store filenames.

services.cfssl.mutualTlsCa.description: Mutual TLS - require clients be signed by this CA.

services.cfssl.mutualTlsClientCert.description: Mutual TLS - client certificate to call remote instance requiring client certs.

services.cfssl.mutualTlsClientKey.description: Mutual TLS - client key to call remote instance requiring client certs. Do not put this in nix-store.

services.cfssl.mutualTlsCn.description: Mutual TLS - regex for whitelist of allowed client CNs.

services.cfssl.port.type: 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

services.cfssl.responderKey.description: Private key for OCSP responder certificate. Do not put this in nix-store.

services.cfssl.tlsCert.description: Other endpoint's CA to set up TLS protocol.

services.cfssl.tlsKey.description: Other endpoint's CA private key. Do not put this in nix-store.

services.cfssl.tlsRemoteCa.description: CAs to trust for remote TLS requests.

services.cgminer.enable.description:
Whether to enable cgminer, an ASIC/FPGA/GPU miner for bitcoin and
litecoin.

services.cgminer.hardware.description: List of config options for every GPU

services.cgminer.pools.description: List of pools where to mine

services.cgminer.user.description: User account under which cgminer runs

services.charybdis.enable.description: Whether to enable Charybdis IRC daemon.

services.charybdis.motd.description:
Charybdis MOTD text.

Charybdis will read its MOTD from /etc/charybdis/ircd.motd .
If set, the value of this option will be written to this path.

services.charybdis.statedir.description: Location of the state directory of charybdis.

services.chronos.enable.description: Whether to enable graphite web frontend.

services.chrony.enable.description:
Whether to synchronise your machine's time using chrony.
Make sure you disable NTP if you enable this service.

services.chrony.extraConfig.description:
Extra configuration directives that should be added to
<literal>chrony.conf</literal>

services.chrony.extraFlags.description: Extra flags passed to the chronyd command.

services.chrony.initstepslew.description:
Allow chronyd to make a rapid measurement of the system clock error at
boot time, and to correct the system clock by stepping before normal
operation begins.

services.chrony.servers.description: The set of NTP servers from which to synchronise.

services.cjdns.ETHInterface.beacon.description:
Auto-connect to other cjdns nodes on the same network.
Options:
  0: Disabled.
  1: Accept beacons, this will cause cjdns to accept incoming
     beacon messages and try connecting to the sender.
  2: Accept and send beacons, this will cause cjdns to broadcast
     messages on the local network which contain a randomly
     generated per-session password, other nodes which have this
     set to 1 or 2 will hear the beacon messages and connect
     automatically.

services.cjdns.ETHInterface.bind.description:
Bind to this device for native ethernet operation.
<literal>all</literal> is a pseudo-name which will try to connect to all devices.

services.cjdns.ETHInterface.connectTo.description:
Credentials for connecting look similar to UDP credientials
except they begin with the mac address.

services.cjdns.ETHInterface.connectTo.<n.description: Optional hostname to add to /etc/hosts; prevents reverse lookup failures.
Authorized password to the opposite end of the tunnel.
Public key at the opposite end of the tunnel.

services.cjdns.UDPInterface.bind.description: Address and port to bind UDP tunnels to.

services.cjdns.UDPInterface.connectTo.<n.description: Optional hostname to add to /etc/hosts; prevents reverse lookup failures.
Authorized password to the opposite end of the tunnel.
Public key at the opposite end of the tunnel.

services.cjdns.addExtraHosts.description:
Whether to add cjdns peers with an associated hostname to
<filename>/etc/hosts</filename>.  Beware that enabling this
incurs heavy eval-time costs.

services.cjdns.admin.bind.description: Bind the administration port to this address and port.

services.cjdns.authorizedPasswords.description:
Any remote cjdns nodes that offer these passwords on
connection will be allowed to route through this node.

services.cjdns.confFile.description: Ignore all other cjdns options and load configuration from this file.

services.cjdns.enable.description:
Whether to enable the cjdns network encryption
and routing engine. A file at /etc/cjdns.keys will
be created if it does not exist to contain a random
secret key that your IPv6 address will be derived from.

services.cjdns.extraConfig.description:
Extra configuration, given as attrs, that will be merged recursively
with the rest of the JSON generated by this module, at the root node.

services.clamav.daemon.enable.description: Whether to enable ClamAV clamd daemon.

services.clamav.daemon.extraConfig.description:
Extra configuration for clamd. Contents will be added verbatim to the
configuration file.

services.clamav.updater.enable.description: Whether to enable ClamAV freshclam updater.

services.clamav.updater.extraConfig.description:
Extra configuration for freshclam. Contents will be added verbatim to the
configuration file.

services.clamav.updater.frequency.description: Number of database checks per day.

services.clamav.updater.interval.description:
How often freshclam is invoked. See systemd.time(7) for more
information about the format.

services.clamsmtp.instances.*.action.description:
Action to take when a virus is detected.

Note that viruses often spoof sender addresses, so bouncing is
in most cases not a good idea.

services.clamsmtp.instances.*.header.description:
A header to add to scanned messages. See clamsmtpd.conf(5) for
more details. Empty means no header.

services.clamsmtp.instances.*.keepAlives.description:
Number of seconds to wait between each NOOP sent to the sending
server. 0 to disable.

This is meant for slow servers where the sending MTA times out
waiting for clamd to scan the file.

services.clamsmtp.instances.*.listen.description:
Address to wait for incoming SMTP connections on. See
clamsmtpd.conf(5) for more details.

services.clamsmtp.instances.*.maxConnect.description: Maximum number of connections to accept at once.

services.clamsmtp.instances.*.outAddress.description:
Address of the SMTP server to send email to once it has been
scanned.

services.clamsmtp.instances.*.quarantine.description:
Whether to quarantine files that contain viruses by leaving them
in the temporary directory.

services.clamsmtp.instances.*.tempDirect.description:
Temporary directory that needs to be accessible to both clamd
and clamsmtpd.

services.clamsmtp.instances.*.virusActio.description:
Command to run when a virus is found. Please see VIRUS ACTION in
clamsmtpd(8) for a discussion of this option and its safe use.

services.clamsmtp.instances.*.xClient.description:
Send the XCLIENT command to the receiving server, for forwarding
client addresses and connection information if the receiving
server supports this feature.

services.clickhouse.enable.description: Whether to enable ClickHouse database server.

services.clight.enable.description: Whether to enable clight or not.

services.clight.settings.description:
Additional configuration to extend clight.conf. See
<link xlink:href="https://github.com/FedeDP/Clight/blob/master/Extra/clight.conf"/> for a
sample configuration file.
services.clight.settings.type: attribute set of null or signed integer or string or boolean or floating point number or list of signed integer or string or boolean or floating point numberss

services.clight.temperature.day.description:
Colour temperature to use during the day, between
<literal>1000</literal> and <literal>25000</literal> K.

services.clight.temperature.night.description:
Colour temperature to use at night, between
<literal>1000</literal> and <literal>25000</literal> K.

services.clipmenu.enable.description: Whether to enable clipmenu, the clipboard management daemon.

services.cloud-init.btrfs.enable.description: Allow the cloud-init service to operate `btrfs` filesystem.

services.cloud-init.config.default:
system_info:
  distro: nixos
users:
   - root

disable_root: false
preserve_hostname: false

cloud_init_modules:
 - migrator
 - seed_random
 - bootcmd
 - write-files
 - growpart
 - resizefs
 - update_etc_hosts
 - ca-certs
 - rsyslog
 - users-groups

cloud_config_modules:
 - disk_setup
 - mounts
 - ssh-import-id
 - set-passwords
 - timezone
 - disable-ec2-metadata
 - runcmd
 - ssh

cloud_final_modules:
 - rightscale_userdata
 - scripts-vendor
 - scripts-per-once
 - scripts-per-boot
 - scripts-per-instance
 - scripts-user
 - ssh-authkey-fingerprints
 - keys-to-console
 - phone-home
 - final-message
 - power-state-change

services.cloud-init.enable.description:
Enable the cloud-init service. This services reads
configuration metadata in a cloud environment and configures
the machine according to this metadata.

This configuration is not completely compatible with the
NixOS way of doing configuration, as configuration done by
cloud-init might be overriden by a subsequent nixos-rebuild
call. However, some parts of cloud-init fall outside of
NixOS's responsibility, like filesystem resizing and ssh
public key provisioning, and cloud-init is useful for that
parts. Thus, be wary that using cloud-init in NixOS might
come as some cost.

services.cloud-init.ext4.enable.description: Allow the cloud-init service to operate `ext4` filesystem.

services.cntlm.enable.description: Whether to enable the cntlm, which start a local proxy.

services.cntlm.extraConfig.description: Additional config appended to the end of the generated <filename>cntlm.conf</filename>.

services.cntlm.noproxy.description: A list of domains where the proxy is skipped.

services.cntlm.password.description: Proxy account password. Note: use chmod 0600 on /etc/cntlm.password for security.

services.cntlm.port.description: Specifies on which ports the cntlm daemon listens.

services.cntlm.proxy.description:
A list of NTLM/NTLMv2 authenticating HTTP proxies.

Parent proxy, which requires authentication. The same as proxy on the command-line, can be used more than  once  to  specify  unlimited
number  of  proxies.  Should  one proxy fail, cntlm automatically moves on to the next one. The connect request fails only if the whole
list of proxies is scanned and (for each request) and found to be invalid. Command-line takes precedence over the configuration file.

services.cntlm.username.description: Proxy account name, without the possibility to include domain name ('at' sign is interpreted literally).

services.cockroachdb.cache.description:
The total size for caches.

This can be a percentage, expressed with a fraction sign or as a
decimal-point number, or any bytes-based unit. For example,
<literal>"25%"</literal>, <literal>"0.25"</literal> both represent
25% of the available system memory. The values
<literal>"1000000000"</literal> and <literal>"1GB"</literal> both
represent 1 gigabyte of memory.

services.cockroachdb.certsDir.description: The path to the certificate directory.

services.cockroachdb.group.description: User account under which CockroachDB runs

services.cockroachdb.http.address.description: Address to bind to for http-based Admin UI

services.cockroachdb.http.port.description: Port to bind to for http-based Admin UI
services.cockroachdb.http.port.type: 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

services.cockroachdb.join.description: The addresses for connecting the node to a cluster.

services.cockroachdb.listen.address.description: Address to bind to for intra-cluster communication

services.cockroachdb.listen.port.description: Port to bind to for intra-cluster communication
services.cockroachdb.listen.port.type: 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

services.cockroachdb.locality.description:
An ordered, comma-separated list of key-value pairs that describe the
topography of the machine. Topography might include country,
datacenter or rack designations. Data is automatically replicated to
maximize diversities of each tier. The order of tiers is used to
determine the priority of the diversity, so the more inclusive
localities like country should come before less inclusive localities
like datacenter.  The tiers and order must be the same on all nodes.
Including more tiers is better than including fewer. For example:

<literal>
    country=us,region=us-west,datacenter=us-west-1b,rack=12
    country=ca,region=ca-east,datacenter=ca-east-2,rack=4

    planet=earth,province=manitoba,colo=secondary,power=3
</literal>

services.cockroachdb.maxSqlMemory.description:
The maximum in-memory storage capacity available to store temporary
data for SQL queries.

This can be a percentage, expressed with a fraction sign or as a
decimal-point number, or any bytes-based unit. For example,
<literal>"25%"</literal>, <literal>"0.25"</literal> both represent
25% of the available system memory. The values
<literal>"1000000000"</literal> and <literal>"1GB"</literal> both
represent 1 gigabyte of memory.

services.cockroachdb.openPorts.description: Open firewall ports for cluster communication by default

services.cockroachdb.package.description:
The CockroachDB derivation to use for running the service.

This would primarily be useful to enable Enterprise Edition features
in your own custom CockroachDB build (Nixpkgs CockroachDB binaries
only contain open source features and open source code).

services.cockroachdb.user.description: User account under which CockroachDB runs

services.codimd.configuration.allowAnony.description:

when <option>allowAnonymous</option> is enabled.

services.codimd.configuration.allowFreeU.description: Whether to allow note creation by accessing a nonexistent note URL.

services.codimd.configuration.allowGrava.description: Whether to use gravatar as profile picture source.

services.codimd.configuration.azure.cont.description:
Azure Blob Storage container name.

services.codimd.configuration.csp.description:

For configuration details see <link xlink:href="https://helmetjs.github.io/docs/csp/"

Specify the configuration for sequelize.
CodiMD supports mysql, postgres, sqlite and mssql.
See <link xlink:href="https://sequelize.readthedocs.io/en/v3/">
https://sequelize.readthedocs.io/en/v3/</link> for more information.

CodiMD supports mysql, postgres, sqlite and mssql.
See <link xlink:href="https://sequelize.readthedocs.io/en/v3/">
https://sequelize.readthedocs.io/en/v3/</link> for more information.
Note: This option overrides <option>db</option>.

services.confluence.sso.applicationName.description: Exact name of this Confluence instance in Crowd

services.confluence.sso.applicationPassw.description: Application password of this Confluence instance in Crowd

services.confluence.sso.crowd.description: Crowd Base URL without trailing slash

services.consul.extraConfig.description:
Extra configuration options which are serialized to json and added
to the config.json file.

services.consul.extraConfigFiles.description:
Additional configuration files to pass to consul
NOTE: These will not trigger the service to be restarted when altered.

services.consul.forceIpv4.description: Whether we should force the interfaces to only pull ipv4 addresses.

services.consul.interface.advertise.description: The name of the interface to pull the advertise_addr from.

services.consul.interface.bind.description: The name of the interface to pull the bind_addr from.

services.consul.leaveOnStop.description:
If enabled, causes a leave action to be sent when closing consul.
This allows a clean termination of the node, but permanently removes
it from the cluster. You probably don't want this option unless you
are running a node which going offline in a permanent / semi-permanent
fashion.

services.consul.package.description: The package used for the Consul agent and CLI.

services.consul.webUi.description: Enables the web interface on the consul http port.

services.coredns.config.description: Verbatim Corefile to use. See <link xlink:href="https://coredns.io/manual/toc/#configuration"/> for details.

services.coredns.enable.description: Whether to enable Coredns dns server.

services.coturn.alt-listening-port.description:
Alternative listening port for UDP and TCP listeners;
default (or zero) value means "listening port plus one".
This is needed for RFC 5780 support
(STUN extension specs, NAT behavior discovery). The TURN Server
supports RFC 5780 only if it is started with more than one
listening IP address of the same family (IPv4 or IPv6).
RFC 5780 is supported only by UDP protocol, other protocols
are listening to that endpoint only for "symmetry".

services.coturn.alt-tls-listening-port.description: Alternative listening port for TLS and DTLS protocols.

services.coturn.cli-ip.description: Local system IP address to be used for CLI server endpoint.

services.coturn.cli-password.description:
CLI access password.
For the security reasons, it is recommended to use the encrypted
for of the password (see the -P command in the turnadmin utility).

services.coturn.dh-file.description: Use custom DH TLS key, stored in PEM format in the file.

services.coturn.enable.description: Whether to enable coturn TURN server.

services.coturn.listening-ips.description:
Listener IP addresses of relay server.
If no IP(s) specified in the config file or in the command line options,
then all IPv4 and IPv6 system IPs will be used for listening.

services.coturn.listening-port.description:
TURN listener port for UDP and TCP.
Note: actually, TLS and DTLS sessions can connect to the
"plain" TCP and UDP port(s), too - if allowed by configuration.

services.coturn.max-port.description: Upper bound of UDP relay endpoints

services.coturn.min-port.description: Lower bound of UDP relay endpoints

services.coturn.no-auth.description:
This option is opposite to lt-cred-mech.
(TURN Server with no-auth option allows anonymous access).
If neither option is defined, and no users are defined,
then no-auth is default. If at least one user is defined,
in this file or in command line or in usersdb file, then
lt-cred-mech is default.

services.coturn.pkey.description: Private key file in PEM format.

services.coturn.realm.description:
The default realm to be used for the users when no explicit
origin/realm relationship was found in the database, or if the TURN
server is not using any database (just the commands-line settings
and the userdb file). Must be used with long-term credentials
mechanism or with TURN REST API.

services.coturn.relay-ips.description:
Relay address (the local IP address that will be used to relay the
packets to the peer).
Multiple relay addresses may be used.
The same IP(s) can be used as both listening IP(s) and relay IP(s).

If no relay IP(s) specified, then the turnserver will apply the default
policy: it will decide itself which relay addresses to be used, and it
will always be using the client socket IP address as the relay IP address
of the TURN session (if the requested relay address family is the same
as the family of the client socket).

services.coturn.secure-stun.description:
Require authentication of the STUN Binding request.
By default, the clients are allowed anonymous access to the STUN Binding functionality.

services.coturn.static-auth-secret.description:
'Static' authentication secret value (a string) for TURN REST API only.
If not set, then the turn server
will try to use the 'dynamic' value in turn_secret table
in user database (if present). The database-stored  value can be changed on-the-fly
by a separate program, so this is why that other mode is 'dynamic'.

services.coturn.tls-listening-port.description:
TURN listener port for TLS.
Note: actually, "plain" TCP and UDP sessions can connect to the TLS and
DTLS port(s), too - if allowed by configuration. The TURN server
"automatically" recognizes the type of traffic. Actually, two listening
endpoints (the "plain" one and the "tls" one) are equivalent in terms of
functionality; but we keep both endpoints to satisfy the RFC 5766 specs.
For secure TCP connections, we currently support SSL version 3 and
TLS version 1.0, 1.1 and 1.2.
For secure UDP connections, we support DTLS version 1.

services.coturn.use-auth-secret.description:
TURN REST API flag.
Flag that sets a special authorization option that is based upon authentication secret.
This feature can be used with the long-term authentication mechanism, only.
This feature purpose is to support "TURN Server REST API", see
"TURN REST API" link in the project's page
https://github.com/coturn/coturn/

This option is used with timestamp:

usercombo -> "timestamp:userid"
turn user -> usercombo
turn password -> base64(hmac(secret key, usercombo))

This allows TURN credentials to be accounted for a specific user id.
If you don't have a suitable id, the timestamp alone can be used.
This option is just turning on secret-based authentication.
The actual value of the secret is defined either by option static-auth-secret,
or can be found in the turn_secret table in the database.

services.couchdb.bindAddress.description: Defines the IP address by which CouchDB will be accessible.

services.couchdb.configFile.description:
Configuration file for persisting runtime changes. File
needs to be readable and writable from couchdb user/group.

services.couchdb.databaseDir.description:
Specifies location of CouchDB database files (*.couch named). This
location should be writable and readable for the user the CouchDB
service runs as (couchdb by default).

services.couchdb.extraConfig.description: Extra configuration. Overrides any other cofiguration.

services.couchdb.group.description: Group account under which couchdb runs.

services.couchdb.logFile.description: Specifies the location of file for logging output.

services.couchdb.port.description: Defined the port number to listen.

services.couchdb.uriFile.description:
This file contains the full URI that can be used to access this
instance of CouchDB. It is used to help discover the port CouchDB is
running on (if it was set to 0 (e.g. automatically assigned any free
one). This file should be writable and readable for the user that
runs the CouchDB service (couchdb by default).

services.couchdb.user.description: User account under which couchdb runs.

services.couchdb.viewIndexDir.description:
Specifies location of CouchDB view index files. This location should
be writable and readable for the user that runs the CouchDB service
(couchdb by default).

services.cpuminer-cryptonight.enable.description: Whether to enable the cpuminer cryptonight miner.

services.cpuminer-cryptonight.threads.description: Number of miner threads, defaults to available processors

services.cron.cronFiles.description:
A list of extra crontab files that will be read and appended to the main
crontab file when the cron service starts.

services.cron.enable.description: Whether to enable the Vixie cron daemon.

services.cron.mailto.description: Email address to which job output will be mailed.

services.cron.systemCronJobs.description:
A list of Cron jobs to be appended to the system-wide
crontab.  See the manual page for crontab for the expected
format. If you want to get the results mailed you must setuid
sendmail. See <option>security.wrappers</option>

If neither /var/cron/cron.deny nor /var/cron/cron.allow exist only root
is allowed to have its own crontab file. The /var/cron/cron.deny file
is created automatically for you, so every user can use a crontab.

Many nixos modules set systemCronJobs, so if you decide to disable vixie cron
and enable another cron daemon, you may want it to get its system crontab
based on systemCronJobs.

services.crowd.catalinaOptions.description: Java options to pass to catalina/tomcat.

services.crowd.enable.description: Whether to enable Atlassian Crowd service.

services.crowd.home.description: Home directory of the Crowd instance.

services.crowd.jrePackage.description: Note that Atlassian only support the Oracle JRE (JRASERVER-46152).

services.crowd.proxy.enable.description: Whether to enable reverse proxy support.

services.crowd.proxy.secure.description: Whether the connections to the proxy should be considered secure.

Address to listen on.

services.darkhttpd.extraArgs.description: Additional configuration passed to the executable.

services.darkhttpd.hideServerId.description: Don't identify the server type in headers or directory listings.

services.darkhttpd.port.description:
Port to listen on.
Pass 0 to let the system choose any free port for you.
services.darkhttpd.port.type: 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

services.darkhttpd.rootDir.description: Path from which to serve files.

services.datadog-agent.apiKeyFile.description:
Path to a file containing the Datadog API key to associate the
agent with your account.

services.datadog-agent.checks.description:
Configuration for all Datadog checks. Keys of this attribute
set will be used as the name of the check to create the
appropriate configuration in `conf.d/$check.d/conf.yaml`.

The configuration is converted into JSON from the plain Nix
language configuration, meaning that you should write
configuration adhering to Datadog's documentation - but in Nix
language.

Refer to the implementation of this module (specifically the
definition of `defaultChecks`) for an example.

Note: The 'disk' and 'network' check are configured in
separate options because they exist by default. Attempting to
override their configuration here will have no effect.

services.datadog-agent.enable.description: Whether to enable the datadog-agent v6 monitoring service

services.datadog-agent.enableLiveProcess.description: Whether to enable the live process collection agent.

services.datadog-agent.enableTraceAgent.description: Whether to enable the trace agent.

services.datadog-agent.extraConfig.description:
Extra configuration options that will be merged into the
main config file <filename>datadog.yaml</filename>.

services.datadog-agent.extraIntegrations.description:
Extra integrations from the Datadog core-integrations
repository that should be built and included.

By default the included integrations are disk, mongo, network,
nginx and postgres.

To include additional integrations the name of the derivation
and a function to filter its dependencies from the Python
package set must be provided.

services.datadog-agent.hostname.description: The hostname to show in the Datadog dashboard (optional)

services.datadog-agent.package.description:
Which DataDog v6 agent package to use. Note that the provided
package is expected to have an overridable `pythonPackages`-attribute
which configures the Python environment with the Datadog
checks.

services.datadog-agent.tags.description: The tags to mark this Datadog agent

services.davfs2.davGroup.description:
The group of the running mount.davfs daemon. Ordinary users must be
member of this group in order to mount a davfs2 file system. Value must
be given as name, not as numerical id.

services.davfs2.davUser.description:
When invoked by root the mount.davfs daemon will run as this user.
Value must be given as name, not as numerical id.

services.davfs2.extraConfig.description: Extra lines appended to the configuration of davfs2.

services.davmail.config.description:
Davmail configuration. Refer to
<link xlink:href="http://davmail.sourceforge.net/serversetup.html"/>
and <link xlink:href="http://davmail.sourceforge.net/advanced.html"/>
for details on supported values.
services.davmail.config.type: davmail config type (str, int, bool or attribute set thereof)

services.davmail.enable.description: Whether to enable davmail, an MS Exchange gateway.

services.davmail.url.description: Outlook Web Access URL to access the exchange server, i.e. the base webmail URL.

services.dbus.packages.description:
Packages whose D-Bus configuration files should be included in
the configuration of the D-Bus system-wide or session-wide
message bus.  Specifically, files in the following directories
will be included into their respective DBus configuration paths:
<filename><replaceable>pkg</replaceable>/etc/dbus-1/system.d</filename>
<filename><replaceable>pkg</replaceable>/share/dbus-1/system.d</filename>
<filename><replaceable>pkg</replaceable>/share/dbus-1/system-services</filename>
<filename><replaceable>pkg</replaceable>/etc/dbus-1/session.d</filename>
<filename><replaceable>pkg</replaceable>/share/dbus-1/session.d</filename>
<filename><replaceable>pkg</replaceable>/share/dbus-1/services</filename>

services.dbus.socketActivated.description: Make the user instance socket activated.

services.dd-agent.api_key.description:
The Datadog API key to associate the agent with your account.

Warning: this key is stored in cleartext within the world-readable
Nix store! Consider using the new v6
<option>services.datadog-agent</option> module instead.

services.dd-agent.enable.description:
Whether to enable the dd-agent v5 monitoring service.
For datadog-agent v6, see <option>services.datadog-agent.enable</option>.

services.dd-agent.hostname.description: The hostname to show in the Datadog dashboard (optional)

services.dd-agent.tags.description: The tags to mark this Datadog agent

services.ddclient.configFile.description:
Path to configuration file.
When set to the default '/etc/ddclient.conf' it will be populated with the various other options in this module. When it is changed (for example: '/root/nixos/secrets/ddclient.conf') the file read directly to configure ddclient. This is a source of impurity.
The purpose of this is to avoid placing secrets into the store.

services.ddclient.enable.description: Whether to synchronise your machine's IP address with a dynamic DNS provider (e.g. dyndns.org).

services.ddclient.extraConfig.description: Extra configuration. Contents will be added verbatim to the configuration file.

services.ddclient.interval.description:
The interval at which to run the check and update.
See <command>man 7 systemd.time</command> for the format.

services.ddclient.password.description: Password. WARNING: The password becomes world readable in the Nix store.

services.ddclient.protocol.description: Protocol to use with dynamic DNS provider (see https://sourceforge.net/p/ddclient/wiki/protocols).

services.ddclient.quiet.description: Print no messages for unnecessary updates.

services.ddclient.script.description: script as required by some providers.

services.ddclient.ssl.description: Whether to use to use SSL/TLS to connect to dynamic DNS provider.

services.ddclient.use.description: Method to determine the IP address to send to the dynamic DNS provider.

services.ddclient.zone.description: zone as required by some providers.

services.deepin.core.enable.description:
Whether to enable 
      Basic dbus and systemd services, groups and users needed by the
      Deepin Desktop Environment.
    .

services.deepin.deepin-menu.enable.description:
Whether to enable 
      DBus service for unified menus in Deepin Desktop Environment.
    .

services.deepin.deepin-turbo.enable.description:
Whether to enable 
      Turbo service for the Deepin Desktop Environment. It is a daemon
      that helps to launch applications faster.
    .

services.deluge.authFile.description:
The file managing the authentication for deluge, the format of this
file is straightforward, each line contains a
username:password:level tuple in plaintext. It only has an effect
when <option>services.deluge.declarative</option> is set to
<literal>true</literal>.
See <link xlink:href="https://dev.deluge-torrent.org/wiki/UserGuide/Authentication"/> for
more informations.

services.deluge.config.description:
Deluge core configuration for the core.conf file. Only has an effect
when <option>services.deluge.declarative</option> is set to
<literal>true</literal>. String values must be quoted, integer and
boolean values must not. See
<link xlink:href="https://git.deluge-torrent.org/deluge/tree/deluge/core/preferencesmanager.py#n41"/>
for the availaible options.

services.deluge.dataDir.description: The directory where deluge will create files.

services.deluge.declarative.description:
Whether to use a declarative deluge configuration.
Only if set to <literal>true</literal>, the options
<option>services.deluge.config</option>,
<option>services.deluge.openFirewall</option> and
<option>services.deluge.authFile</option> will be
applied.

services.deluge.extraPackages.description:
Extra packages available at runtime to enable Deluge's plugins. For example,
extraction utilities are required for the built-in "Extractor" plugin.
This always contains unzip, gnutar, xz, p7zip and bzip2.

services.deluge.openFilesLimit.description: Number of files to allow deluged to open.

services.deluge.openFirewall.description:
Whether to open the firewall for the ports in
<option>services.deluge.config.listen_ports</option>. It only takes effet if
<option>services.deluge.declarative</option> is set to
<literal>true</literal>.

It does NOT apply to the daemon port nor the web UI port. To access those
ports secuerly check the documentation
<link xlink:href="https://dev.deluge-torrent.org/wiki/UserGuide/ThinClient#CreateSSHTunnel"/>
or use a VPN or configure certificates for deluge.

services.deluge.user.description: User account under which deluge runs.

services.deluge.web.enable.description: Whether to enable Deluge Web daemon.

services.deluge.web.openFirewall.description: Open ports in the firewall for deluge web daemon

services.deluge.web.port.type: 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

services.devmon.enable.description: Whether to enable devmon, an automatic device mounting daemon.

services.dhcpd4.configFile.description:
The path of the DHCP server configuration file.  If no file
is specified, a file is generated using the other options.

services.dhcpd4.enable.description: Whether to enable the DHCPv4 server.

services.dhcpd4.extraConfig.description:
Extra text to be appended to the DHCP server configuration
file. Currently, you almost certainly need to specify something
there, such as the options specifying the subnet mask, DNS servers,
etc.

services.dhcpd4.extraFlags.description: Additional command line flags to be passed to the dhcpd daemon.

services.dhcpd4.interfaces.description: The interfaces on which the DHCP server should listen.

services.dhcpd4.machines.description:
A list mapping Ethernet addresses to IPv4 addresses for the
DHCP server.

services.dhcpd4.machines.*.hostName.description: Hostname which is assigned statically to the machine.

services.dhcpd4.stateDir.description: State directory for the DHCP server.

services.dhcpd6.configFile.description:
The path of the DHCP server configuration file.  If no file
is specified, a file is generated using the other options.

services.dhcpd6.enable.description: Whether to enable the DHCPv6 server.

services.dhcpd6.extraConfig.description:
Extra text to be appended to the DHCP server configuration
file. Currently, you almost certainly need to specify something
there, such as the options specifying the subnet mask, DNS servers,
etc.

services.dhcpd6.extraFlags.description: Additional command line flags to be passed to the dhcpd daemon.

services.dhcpd6.interfaces.description: The interfaces on which the DHCP server should listen.

services.dhcpd6.machines.description:
A list mapping Ethernet addresses to IPv6 addresses for the
DHCP server.

services.dhcpd6.machines.*.hostName.description: Hostname which is assigned statically to the machine.

services.dhcpd6.stateDir.description: State directory for the DHCP server.

services.dictd.DBs.description: List of databases to make available.

services.dictd.enable.description: Whether to enable the DICT.org dictionary server.

services.diod.allsquash.description:
Remap all users to "nobody". The attaching user need not be present in the
password file.

services.diod.authRequired.description: Allow clients to connect without authentication, i.e. without a valid MUNGE credential.

services.diod.enable.description: Whether to enable the diod 9P file server.

services.diod.exportall.description:
Export all file systems listed in /proc/mounts. If new file systems are mounted
after diod has started, they will become immediately mountable. If there is a
duplicate entry for a file system in the exports list, any options listed in
the exports entry will apply.

services.diod.exportopts.description:
Establish a default set of export options. These are overridden, not appended
to, by opts attributes in an "exports" entry.

services.diod.exports.description:
List the file systems that clients will be allowed to mount. All paths should
be fully qualified. The exports table can include two types of element:
a string element (as above),
or an alternate table element form { path="/path", opts="ro" }.
In the alternate form, the (optional) opts attribute is a comma-separated list
of export options. The two table element forms can be mixed in the exports
table. Note that although diod will not traverse file system boundaries for a
given mount due to inode uniqueness constraints, subdirectories of a file
system can be separately exported.

services.diod.listen.description:
[ "IP:PORT" [,"IP:PORT",...] ]
List the interfaces and ports that diod should listen on.

services.diod.logdest.description:
Set the destination for logging.
The value has the form of "syslog:facility:level" or "filename".

services.diod.nwthreads.description:
Sets the (fixed) number of worker threads created to handle 9P
requests for a unique aname.

services.diod.squashuser.description: Change the squash user. The squash user must be present in the password file.

services.diod.statfsPassthru.description:
This option configures statfs to return the host file system's type
rather than V9FS_MAGIC.

services.diod.userdb.description:
This option disables password/group lookups. It allows any uid to attach and
assumes gid=uid, and supplementary groups contain only the primary gid.

services.disnix.enableMultiUser.description: Whether to support multi-user mode by enabling the Disnix D-Bus service

services.disnix.useWebServiceInterface.description: Whether to enable the DisnixWebService interface running on Apache Tomcat

services.dkimproxy-out.domains.description: List of domains DKIMproxy can sign for.

services.dkimproxy-out.enable.description:
Whether to enable dkimproxy_out.

Note that a key will be auto-generated, and can be found in
/var/lib/dkimproxy-out.

services.dkimproxy-out.keySize.description:
Size of the RSA key to use to sign outgoing emails. Note that the
maximum mandatorily verified as per RFC6376 is 2048.

services.dkimproxy-out.relay.description: Address:port DKIMproxy should forward mail to.

services.dkimproxy-out.selector.description:
The selector to use for DKIM key identification.

For example, if 'selector1' is used here, then for each domain
'example.org' given in `domain`, 'selector1._domainkey.example.org'
should contain the TXT record indicating the public key is the one
in /var/lib/dkimproxy-out/public.key: "v=DKIM1; t=s; p=[THE PUBLIC KEY]".

services.dleyna-renderer.enable.description:
Whether to enable dleyna-renderer service, a DBus service
for handling DLNA renderers.

services.dleyna-server.enable.description:
Whether to enable dleyna-server service, a DBus service
for handling DLNA servers.

services.dnscache.clientIps.description: Client IP addresses (or prefixes) from which to accept connections.

services.dnscache.domainServers.description:
Table of {hostname: server} pairs to use as authoritative servers for hosts (and subhosts).
If entry for @ is not specified predefined list of root servers is used.
services.dnscache.domainServers.type: attribute set of list of stringss

services.dnscache.enable.description: Whether to run the dnscache caching dns server.

services.dnscache.forwardOnly.description:
Whether to treat root servers (for @) as caching
servers, requesting addresses the same way a client does. This is
needed if you want to use e.g. Google DNS as your upstream DNS.

services.dnscache.ip.description: IP address on which to listen for connections.

services.dnschain.api.hostname.description: The hostname (or IP address) the DNSChain API server will bind to.

services.dnschain.api.port.description: The port the DNSChain API server (HTTP) will bind to.

services.dnschain.api.tlsPort.description: The port the DNSChain API server (HTTPS) will bind to.

services.dnschain.dns.address.description:
The IP address the DNSChain resolver will bind to.
Leave this unchanged if you do not wish to directly expose the resolver.

services.dnschain.dns.externalAddress.description:
The IP address used by clients to reach the resolver and the value of
the <literal>namecoin.dns</literal> record. Set this in case the bind address
is not the actual IP address (e.g. the machine is behind a NAT).

services.dnschain.dns.port.description: The port the DNSChain resolver will bind to.

services.dnschain.enable.description:
Whether to enable DNSChain, a blockchain based DNS + HTTP server.
To resolve .bit domains set <literal>services.namecoind.enable = true;</literal>
and an RPC username/password.
.

services.dnschain.extraConfig.description: Additional options that will be appended to the configuration file.

services.dnscrypt-proxy.customResolver.description:
Use an unlisted resolver (e.g., a private DNSCrypt provider). For
advanced users only. If specified, this option takes precedence.

services.dnscrypt-proxy.enable.description: Whether to enable the DNSCrypt client proxy

services.dnscrypt-proxy.extraArgs.description:
Additional command-line arguments passed verbatim to the daemon.
See <citerefentry><refentrytitle>dnscrypt-proxy</refentrytitle>
<manvolnum>8</manvolnum></citerefentry> for details.

services.dnscrypt-proxy.localAddress.description:
Listen for DNS queries to relay on this address. The only reason to
change this from its default value is to proxy queries on behalf
of other machines (typically on the local network).

services.dnscrypt-proxy.localPort.description:
Listen for DNS queries to relay on this port. The default value
assumes that the DNSCrypt proxy should relay DNS queries directly.
When running as a forwarder for another DNS client, set this option
to a different value; otherwise leave the default.

services.dnscrypt-proxy.resolverName.description:
The name of the DNSCrypt resolver to use, taken from
<filename>/var/lib/dnscrypt-proxy/dnscrypt-resolvers.csv</filename>.  The default is to
pick a random non-logging resolver that supports DNSSEC.

services.dnscrypt-wrapper.address.description: The DNSCrypt wrapper will bind to this IP address.

services.dnscrypt-wrapper.keys.checkInte.description: The time interval (in minutes) between key expiration checks.

services.dnscrypt-wrapper.keys.expiratio.description:
The duration (in days) of the time-limited secret key.
This will be automatically rotated before expiration.

services.dnscrypt-wrapper.port.description: The DNSCrypt wrapper will listen for DNS queries on this port.

services.dnscrypt-wrapper.providerName.description:
The name that will be given to this DNSCrypt resolver.
Note: the resolver name must start with <literal>2.dnscrypt-cert.</literal>.

services.dnscrypt-wrapper.upstream.addre.description: The IP address of the upstream DNS server DNSCrypt will "wrap".

services.dnscrypt-wrapper.upstream.port.description: The port of the upstream DNS server DNSCrypt will "wrap".

services.dnsdist.enable.description: Whether to enable dnsdist domain name server.

services.dnsdist.extraConfig.description: Extra lines to be added verbatim to dnsdist.conf.

services.dnsmasq.alwaysKeepRunning.description: If enabled, systemd will always respawn dnsmasq even if shut down manually. The default, disabled, will only restart it on error.

services.dnsmasq.extraConfig.description:
Extra configuration directives that should be added to
<literal>dnsmasq.conf</literal>.

services.dnsmasq.resolveDNSChainQueries.description: Resolve <literal>.bit</literal> top-level domains using DNSChain and namecoin.

services.dnsmasq.resolveLocalQueries.description:
Whether dnsmasq should resolve local queries (i.e. add 127.0.0.1 to
/etc/resolv.conf).

services.dnsmasq.servers.description: The DNS servers which dnsmasq should query.

services.dockerRegistry.enableDelete.description: Enable delete for manifests and blobs.

services.dockerRegistry.enableRedisCache.description: Whether to enable redis as blob cache.

services.dockerRegistry.garbageCollectDa.description:

which the garbage collect will occur.

services.dockerRegistry.listenAddress.description: Docker registry host or ip to bind to.

services.dockerRegistry.storagePath.description:
Docker registry storage path for the filesystem storage backend. Set to
null to configure another backend via extraConfig.

services.documize.db.description:
Database specific connection string for example:
<itemizedlist>
<listitem><para>MySQL/Percona/MariaDB:
  <literal>user:password@tcp(host:3306)/documize</literal>
</para></listitem>
<listitem><para>MySQLv8+:
  <literal>user:password@tcp(host:3306)/documize?allowNativePasswords=true</literal>
</para></listitem>
<listitem><para>PostgreSQL:
  <literal>host=localhost port=5432 dbname=documize user=admin password=secret sslmode=disable</literal>
</para></listitem>
<listitem><para>MSSQL:
  <literal>sqlserver://username:password@localhost:1433?database=Documize</literal> or
  <literal>sqlserver://sa@localhost/SQLExpress?database=Documize</literal>
</para></listitem>
</itemizedlist>

services.documize.forcesslport.description: Redirect given http port number to TLS.

services.documize.salt.description: The salt string used to encode JWT tokens, if not set a random value will be generated.

services.documize.stateDirectoryName.description:
The name of the directory below <filename>/var/lib/private</filename>
where documize runs in and stores, for example, backups.

services.dovecot2.configFile.description: Config file used for the whole dovecot configuration.

services.dovecot2.createMailUser.description:
Whether to automatically create the user
        given in <option>services.dovecot.user</option> and the group
        given in <option>services.dovecot.group</option>.

services.dovecot2.enable.description: Whether to enable Dovecot 2.x POP3/IMAP server.

services.dovecot2.enableImap.description: Start the IMAP listener (when Dovecot is enabled).

services.dovecot2.enableLmtp.description: Start the LMTP listener (when Dovecot is enabled).

services.dovecot2.enablePAM.description: Whether to create a own Dovecot PAM service and configure PAM user logins.

services.dovecot2.enablePop3.description: Start the POP3 listener (when Dovecot is enabled).

services.dovecot2.enableQuota.description: Whether to enable the dovecot quota service.

services.dovecot2.extraConfig.description: Additional entries to put verbatim into Dovecot's config file.

services.dovecot2.mailGroup.description: Default group to store mail for virtual users.

services.dovecot2.mailLocation.description: Location that dovecot will use for mail folders. Dovecot mail_location option.

services.dovecot2.mailUser.description: Default user to store mail for virtual users.

services.dovecot2.mailboxes.description: Configure mailboxes and auto create or subscribe them.

services.dovecot2.mailboxes.*.auto.description: Whether to automatically create or create and subscribe to the mailbox or not.

services.dovecot2.mailboxes.*.specialUse.description: Null if no special use flag is set. Other than that every use flag mentioned in the RFC is valid.

services.dovecot2.modules.description:
Symlinks the contents of lib/dovecot of every given package into

services.dovecot2.protocols.description: Additional listeners to start when Dovecot is enabled.

services.dovecot2.quotaGlobalPerUser.description: Quota limit for the user in bytes. Supports suffixes b, k, M, G, T and %.

The Port the dovecot quota service binds to.
If using postfix, add check_policy_service inet:localhost:12340 to your smtpd_recipient_restrictions in your postfix config.

services.dovecot2.sslServerKey.description: Path to the server's private key.

services.drbd.enable.description:
Whether to enable support for DRBD, the Distributed Replicated
Block Device.

services.dspam.domainSocket.description: Path to local domain socket which is used for communication with the daemon. Set to null to disable UNIX socket.

services.dspam.enable.description: Whether to enable the dspam spam filter.

services.dspam.maintenanceInterval.description: If set, maintenance script will be run at specified (in systemd.timer format) interval

Listening interface for the web UI
Set it to "any" to listen on all available interfaces

Duplicati runs as it's own user. It will only be able to backup world-readable files.
Run as root with special care.
