services.home-assistant.applyDefaultConf.description:
Setting this option enables a few configuration options for HA based on NixOS configuration (such as time zone) to avoid having to manually specify configuration we already have.
</para>
<para>
Currently one side effect of enabling this is that the <literal>http</literal> component will be enabled.
</para>
<para>
This only takes effect if <literal>config != null</literal> in order to ensure that a manually managed <filename>configuration.yaml</filename> is not overwritten.

services.home-assistant.autoExtraCompone.description:
If set to <literal>true</literal>, the components used in <literal>config</literal>
are set as the specified package's <literal>extraComponents</literal>.
This in turn adds all packaged dependencies to the derivation.
You might still see import errors in your log.
In this case, you will need to package the necessary dependencies yourself
or ask for someone else to package them.
If a dependency is packaged but not automatically added to this list,
you might need to specify it in <literal>extraPackages</literal>.

services.home-assistant.config.description:
Your <filename>configuration.yaml</filename> as a Nix attribute set.
Beware that setting this option will delete your previous <filename>configuration.yaml</filename>.

services.home-assistant.configDir.description: The config directory, where your <filename>configuration.yaml</filename> is located.

services.home-assistant.configWritable.description:
Whether to make <filename>configuration.yaml</filename> writable.
This only has an effect if <option>config</option> is set.
This will allow you to edit it from Home Assistant's web interface.
However, bear in mind that it will be overwritten at every start of the service.

services.home-assistant.lovelaceConfig.description:
Your <filename>ui-lovelace.yaml</filename> as a Nix attribute set.
Setting this option will automatically add
<literal>lovelace.mode = "yaml";</literal> to your <option>config</option>.
Beware that setting this option will delete your previous <filename>ui-lovelace.yaml</filename>

services.home-assistant.lovelaceConfigWr.description:
Whether to make <filename>ui-lovelace.yaml</filename> writable.
This only has an effect if <option>lovelaceConfig</option> is set.
This will allow you to edit it from Home Assistant's web interface.
However, bear in mind that it will be overwritten at every start of the service.

services.home-assistant.openFirewall.description: Whether to open the firewall for the specified port.

services.home-assistant.package.description:
Home Assistant package to use.
Override <literal>extraPackages</literal> or <literal>extraComponents</literal> in order to add additional dependencies.
If you specify <option>config</option> and do not set <option>autoExtraComponents</option>
to <literal>false</literal>, overriding <literal>extraComponents</literal> will have no effect.

services.home-assistant.port.description: The port on which to listen.

services.hoogle.enable.description: Whether to enable Haskell documentation server.

services.hoogle.haskellPackages.description: Which haskell package set to use.

services.hoogle.packages.description:
The Haskell packages to generate documentation for.

The option value is a function that takes the package set specified in
the <varname>haskellPackages</varname> option as its sole parameter and
returns a list of packages.

services.hoogle.port.description: Port number Hoogle will be listening to.

services.hostapd.channel.description:
Channel number (IEEE 802.11)
Please note that some drivers do not use this value from
<command>hostapd</command> and the channel will need to be configured
separately with <command>iwconfig</command>.

services.hostapd.driver.description:
Which driver <command>hostapd</command> will use.
Most applications will probably use the default.

services.hostapd.enable.description:
Enable putting a wireless interface into infrastructure mode,
allowing other wireless devices to associate with the wireless
interface and do wireless networking. A simple access point will
<option>enable hostapd.wpa</option>,
<option>hostapd.wpaPassphrase</option>, and
<option>hostapd.ssid</option>, as well as DHCP on the wireless
interface to provide IP addresses to the associated stations, and
NAT (from the wireless interface to an upstream interface).

services.hostapd.extraConfig.description: Extra configuration options to put in hostapd.conf.

services.hostapd.group.description: Members of this group can control <command>hostapd</command>.

services.hostapd.hwMode.description:
Operation mode.
(a = IEEE 802.11a, b = IEEE 802.11b, g = IEEE 802.11g).

services.hostapd.noScan.description:
Do not scan for overlapping BSSs in HT40+/- mode.
Caution: turning this on will violate regulatory requirements!

services.hostapd.ssid.description: SSID to be used in IEEE 802.11 management frames.

services.hostapd.wpa.description: Enable WPA (IEEE 802.11i/D3.0) to authenticate with the access point.

services.hostapd.wpaPassphrase.description:
WPA-PSK (pre-shared-key) passphrase. Clients will need this
passphrase to associate with this access point.
Warning: This passphrase will get put into a world-readable file in
the Nix store!

services.hound.config.description:
The full configuration of the Hound daemon. Note the dbpath
should be an absolute path to a writable location on disk.

services.hound.enable.description: Whether to enable the hound code search daemon.

services.hound.extraGroups.description: List of extra groups that the "hound" user should be a part of.

services.hound.group.description: Group the hound daemon should execute under.

services.hound.home.description:
The path to use as hound's $HOME. If the default user
"hound" is configured then this is the home of the "hound"
user.

services.hound.user.description: User the hound daemon should execute under.

services.htpdate.extraOptions.description: Additional command line arguments to pass to htpdate.

services.htpdate.servers.description: HTTP servers to use for time synchronization.

services.httpd.adminAddr.description: E-mail address of the server administrator.

services.httpd.configFile.description:
Override the configuration file used by Apache. By default,
NixOS generates one automatically.

services.httpd.documentRoot.description:
The path of Apache's document root directory.  If left undefined,
an empty directory in the Nix store will be used as root.

services.httpd.enable.description: Whether to enable the Apache HTTP Server.

services.httpd.enableMellon.description: Whether to enable the mod_auth_mellon module.

services.httpd.enablePHP.description: Whether to enable the PHP module.

services.httpd.enablePerl.description: Whether to enable the Perl module (mod_perl).

services.httpd.extraConfig.description:
These lines go to httpd.conf verbatim. They will go after
directories and directory aliases defined by default.

services.httpd.extraModules.description:
Additional Apache modules to be used.  These can be
specified as a string in the case of modules distributed
with Apache, or as an attribute set specifying the
<varname>name</varname> and <varname>path</varname> of the
module.

services.httpd.extraSubservices.description: Extra subservices to enable in the webserver.

services.httpd.globalRedirect.description:
If set, all requests for this host are redirected permanently to
the given URL.

services.httpd.group.description:
Group under which httpd runs.  The account is created
automatically if it doesn't exist.

services.httpd.listen.description: List of { /* ip: "*"; */ port = 80;} to listen on

services.httpd.listen.*.ip.description: Ip to listen on. 0.0.0.0 for ipv4 only, * for all.

services.httpd.logDir.description: Directory for Apache's log files.  It is created automatically.

services.httpd.logFormat.description: Log format for Apache's log files. Possible values are: combined, common, referer, agent.

services.httpd.logPerVirtualHost.description:
If enabled, each virtual host gets its own
<filename>access.log</filename> and
<filename>error.log</filename>, namely suffixed by the
<option>hostName</option> of the virtual host.

services.httpd.maxRequestsPerChild.description: Maximum number of httpd requests answered per httpd child (prefork), 0 means unlimited

services.httpd.multiProcessingModule.description:
Multi-processing module to be used by Apache.  Available
modules are <literal>prefork</literal> (the default;
handles each request in a separate child process),
<literal>worker</literal> (hybrid approach that starts a
number of child processes each running a number of
threads) and <literal>event</literal> (a recent variant of
<literal>worker</literal> that handles persistent
connections more efficiently).

services.httpd.package.description: Overridable attribute of the Apache HTTP Server package to use.

services.httpd.phpOptions.description: Options appended to the PHP configuration file <filename>php.ini</filename>.

services.httpd.phpPackage.description: Overridable attribute of the PHP package to use.

services.httpd.robotsEntries.description:
Specification of pages to be ignored by web crawlers. See <link
xlink:href='http://www.robotstxt.org/'/> for details.

services.httpd.servedDirs.description: This option provides a simple way to serve static directories.

services.httpd.servedFiles.description: This option provides a simple way to serve individual, static files.

services.httpd.serverAliases.description: Additional names of virtual hosts served by this virtual host configuration.

services.httpd.sslCiphers.description: Cipher Suite available for negotiation in SSL proxy handshake.

services.httpd.sslServerChain.description: Path to server SSL chain file.

services.httpd.sslServerKey.description: Path to server SSL certificate key.

services.httpd.stateDir.description:
Directory for Apache's transient runtime state (such as PID
files).  It is created automatically.  Note that the default,
<filename>/run/httpd</filename>, is deleted at boot time.

services.httpd.user.description:
User account under which httpd runs.  The account is created

services.httpd.virtualHosts.description:
Specification of the virtual hosts served by Apache.  Each
element should be an attribute set specifying the
configuration of the virtual host.  The available options
are the non-global options permissible for the main host.

services.httpd.virtualHosts.*.adminAddr.description: E-mail address of the server administrator.

services.httpd.virtualHosts.*.documentRo.description:
The path of Apache's document root directory.  If left undefined,

services.httpd.virtualHosts.*.extraConfi.description:
These lines go to httpd.conf verbatim. They will go after

services.httpd.virtualHosts.*.extraSubse.description: Extra subservices to enable in the webserver.

services.httpd.virtualHosts.*.globalRedi.description:
If set, all requests for this host are redirected permanently to

services.httpd.virtualHosts.*.listen.description: List of { /* ip: "*"; */ port = 80;} to listen on

services.httpd.virtualHosts.*.listen.*.i.description: Ip to listen on. 0.0.0.0 for ipv4 only, * for all.

services.httpd.virtualHosts.*.logFormat.description: Log format for Apache's log files. Possible values are: combined, common, referer, agent.

services.httpd.virtualHosts.*.robotsEntr.description:
Specification of pages to be ignored by web crawlers. See <link
xlink:href='http://www.robotstxt.org/'/> for details.

services.httpd.virtualHosts.*.servedDirs.description: This option provides a simple way to serve static directories.

services.httpd.virtualHosts.*.servedFile.description: This option provides a simple way to serve individual, static files.

services.httpd.virtualHosts.*.serverAlia.description: Additional names of virtual hosts served by this virtual host configuration.

services.httpd.virtualHosts.*.sslServerC.description: Path to server SSL chain file.

services.httpd.virtualHosts.*.sslServerK.description: Path to server SSL certificate key.

services.hydra.buildMachinesFiles.description: List of files containing build machines.

services.hydra.dbi.description: The DBI string for Hydra database connection.

services.hydra.debugServer.description: Whether to run the server in debug mode.

services.hydra.extraConfig.description: Extra lines for the Hydra configuration.

services.hydra.gcRootsDir.description: Directory that holds Hydra garbage collector roots.

services.hydra.hydraURL.description: The base URL for the Hydra webserver instance. Used for links in emails.

services.hydra.listenHost.description:
The hostname or address to listen on or <literal>*</literal> to listen
on all interfaces.

services.hydra.logo.description: Path to a file containing the logo of your Hydra instance.

services.hydra.minimumDiskFree.description: Threshold of minimum disk space (GiB) to determine if the queue runner should run or not.

services.hydra.minimumDiskFreeEvaluator.description: Threshold of minimum disk space (GiB) to determine if the evaluator should run or not.

services.hydra.notificationSender.description: Sender email address used for email notifications.

services.hydra.port.description: TCP port the web server should listen to.

services.hydra.smtpHost.description: Hostname of the SMTP server to use to send email.

services.hydra.tracker.description: Piece of HTML that is included on all pages.

services.hydra.useSubstitutes.description:
Whether to use binary caches for downloading store paths. Note that
binary substitutions trigger (a potentially large number of) additional
HTTP requests that slow down the queue monitor thread significantly.
Also, this Hydra instance will serve those downloaded store paths to
its users with its own signature attached as if it had built them
itself, so don't enable this feature unless your active binary caches
are absolute trustworthy.

services.hydron.dataDir.description: Location where hydron runs and stores data.

services.hydron.fetchTags.description: Fetch tags for imported images and webm from gelbooru.

services.hydron.importPaths.description: Paths that hydron will recursively import.

services.hydron.interval.description:
How often we run hydron import and possibly fetch tags. Runs by default every week.

The format is described in
<citerefentry><refentrytitle>systemd.time</refentrytitle>
<manvolnum>7</manvolnum></citerefentry>.

services.hydron.listenAddress.description: Listen on a specific IP address and port.

services.hydron.passwordFile.description: Password file for the hydron database.

services.hylafax.areaCode.description: Area code for server and all modems.

services.hylafax.autostart.description:
Autostart the HylaFAX queue manager at system start.
If this is <literal>false</literal>, the queue manager
will still be started if there are pending
jobs or if a user tries to connect to it.

services.hylafax.commonModemConfig.description:
Attribute set of default values for
modem config files <filename>etc/config.*</filename>.
Values can be either strings or integers
(which will be added to the config file verbatimly)
or lists thereof
(which will be translated to multiple
lines with the same configuration key).
Boolean values are translated to "Yes" or "No".
The default contains some reasonable
configuration to yield an operational system.

Think twice before changing
paths of fax-processing scripts.
services.hylafax.commonModemConfig.type: attribute set of list of string or signed integer convertible to it or boolean convertible to its or string or signed integer convertible to it or boolean convertible to it convertible to its

services.hylafax.countryCode.description: Country code for server and all modems.

services.hylafax.faxcron.enable.frequenc.description:
Purge old files from the spooling area with
<filename>faxcron</filename> with the given frequency
(see systemd.time(7)).

services.hylafax.faxcron.enable.spoolIni.description:
Whether to enable Purge old files from the spooling area with
<filename>faxcron</filename>
each time the spooling area is initialized.
.

services.hylafax.faxcron.infoDays.description:
Set the expiration time for data in the
remote machine information directory in days.

services.hylafax.faxcron.logDays.description:
Set the expiration time for
session trace log files in days.

services.hylafax.faxcron.rcvDays.description:
Set the expiration time for files in
the received facsimile queue in days.

services.hylafax.faxqConfig.description:
Attribute set of lines for the global
faxq config file <filename>etc/config</filename>.
Values can be either strings or integers
(which will be added to the config file verbatimly)
or lists thereof
(which will be translated to multiple
lines with the same configuration key).
Boolean values are translated to "Yes" or "No".
The default contains some reasonable
configuration to yield an operational system.
services.hylafax.faxqConfig.type: attribute set of list of string or signed integer convertible to it or boolean convertible to its or string or signed integer convertible to it or boolean convertible to it convertible to its

services.hylafax.faxqclean.archiving.description:
Enable or suppress job archiving:
<literal>never</literal> disables job archiving,
<literal>as-flagged</literal> archives jobs that
have been flagged for archiving by sendfax,
<literal>always</literal> forces archiving of all jobs.
See also sendfax(1) and faxqclean(8).

services.hylafax.faxqclean.docqMinutes.description:
Set the document
age threshold (in minutes) that controls how long
unreferenced files may reside in the docq directory.

services.hylafax.faxqclean.doneqMinutes.description:
Set the job
age threshold (in minutes) that controls how long
jobs may reside in the doneq directory.

services.hylafax.faxqclean.enable.freque.description:
Purge old files from the spooling area with
<filename>faxcron</filename> with the given frequency
(see systemd.time(7)).

services.hylafax.faxqclean.enable.spoolI.description:
Whether to enable Purge old files from the spooling area with
<filename>faxqclean</filename>
each time the spooling area is initialized.
.

services.hylafax.hfaxdConfig.description:
Attribute set of lines for the global
hfaxd config file <filename>etc/hfaxd.conf</filename>.
Values can be either strings or integers
(which will be added to the config file verbatimly)
or lists thereof
(which will be translated to multiple
lines with the same configuration key).
Boolean values are translated to "Yes" or "No".
The default contains some reasonable
configuration to yield an operational system.
services.hylafax.hfaxdConfig.type: attribute set of list of string or signed integer convertible to it or boolean convertible to its or string or signed integer convertible to it or boolean convertible to it convertible to its

services.hylafax.internationalPrefix.description: International prefix for server and all modems.

services.hylafax.longDistancePrefix.description: Long distance prefix for server and all modems.

services.hylafax.modems.description:
Description of installed modems.
At least on modem must be defined
to enable the HylaFAX server.
services.hylafax.modems.type: list or attribute set of submodules

services.hylafax.modems.<name?>.config.description:
Attribute set of values for the given modem.
Values can be either strings or integers
(which will be added to the config file verbatimly)
or lists thereof
(which will be translated to multiple
lines with the same configuration key).
Boolean values are translated to "Yes" or "No".
The default contains some reasonable
configuration to yield an operational system.

Options defined here override options in
<option>commonModemConfig</option> for this modem.
services.hylafax.modems.<name?>.config.type: attribute set of list of string or signed integer convertible to it or boolean convertible to its or string or signed integer convertible to it or boolean convertible to it convertible to its

services.hylafax.modems.<name?>.name.description:
Name of modem device,
will be searched for in <filename>/dev</filename>.

services.hylafax.modems.<name?>.type.description:
Name of modem configuration file,
will be searched for in <filename>config</filename>
in the spooling area directory.

services.hylafax.sendmailPath.description:
Path to <filename>sendmail</filename> program.
The default uses the local sendmail wrapper
(see <option>config.services.mail.sendmailSetuidWrapper</option>),
otherwise the <filename>false</filename>
binary to cause an error if used.

services.hylafax.spoolAreaPath.description:
The spooling area will be created/maintained
at the location given here.

services.hylafax.spoolExtraInit.description:
Additional shell code that is executed within the
spooling area directory right after its setup.
services.hylafax.spoolExtraInit.example: chmod 0755 .  # everyone may read my faxes

services.i2pd.addressbook.defaulturl.description: AddressBook subscription URL for initial setup

services.i2pd.bandwidth.description:
Set a router bandwidth limit integer in KBps.
If not set, <command>i2pd</command> defaults to 32KBps.

services.i2pd.dataDir.description: Alternative path to storage of i2pd data (RI, keys, peer profiles, ...)

services.i2pd.enable.description:
Enables I2Pd as a running service upon activation.
Please read http://i2pd.readthedocs.io/en/latest/ for further
configuration help.

services.i2pd.exploratory.inbound.length.description: Guaranteed minimum hops for exploratory tunnels.

services.i2pd.exploratory.outbound.lengt.description: Guaranteed minimum hops for exploratory tunnels.

services.i2pd.family.description: Specify a family the router belongs to.

services.i2pd.floodfill.description: If the router is declared to be unreachable and needs introduction nodes.

services.i2pd.inTunnels.description: Serve something on I2P network at port and delegate requests to address inPort.
services.i2pd.inTunnels.type: list or attribute set of submodules

services.i2pd.inTunnels.<name?>.accessLi.description: I2P nodes that are allowed to connect to this service.

services.i2pd.inTunnels.<name?>.crypto.t.description: Number of ElGamal/AES tags to send.

services.i2pd.inTunnels.<name?>.destinat.description: Remote endpoint, I2P hostname or b32.i2p address.

services.i2pd.inTunnels.<name?>.inPort.description: Service port. Default to the tunnel's listen port.

services.i2pd.inTunnels.<name?>.inbound..description: Guaranteed minimum hops for name tunnels.

services.i2pd.inTunnels.<name?>.outbound.description: Guaranteed minimum hops for name tunnels.

services.i2pd.limits.coreSize.description: Maximum size of corefile in Kb (0 - use system limit).

services.i2pd.limits.ntcpHard.description: Maximum number of active transit sessions.

services.i2pd.limits.ntcpSoft.description: Threshold to start probabalistic backoff with ntcp sessions (default: use system limit).

services.i2pd.limits.ntcpThreads.description: Maximum number of threads used by NTCP DH worker.

services.i2pd.limits.openFiles.description: Maximum number of open files (0 - use system default).

services.i2pd.limits.transittunnels.description: Maximum number of active transit sessions.

services.i2pd.logCLFTime.description: Whether to enable Full CLF-formatted date and time to log.

services.i2pd.logLevel.description:
The log level. <command>i2pd</command> defaults to "info"
but that generates copious amounts of log messages.

We default to "error" which is similar to the default log
level of <command>tor</command>.

services.i2pd.notransit.description: Tells the router to not accept transit tunnels during startup.

services.i2pd.ntcp2.port.description: Port to listen for incoming NTCP2 connections (0=auto).

services.i2pd.outTunnels.description: Connect to someone as a client and establish a local accept endpoint
services.i2pd.outTunnels.type: list or attribute set of submodules

services.i2pd.outTunnels.<name?>.crypto..description: Number of ElGamal/AES tags to send.

services.i2pd.outTunnels.<name?>.destina.description: Remote endpoint, I2P hostname or b32.i2p address.
Connect to particular port at destination.

services.i2pd.outTunnels.<name?>.inbound.description: Guaranteed minimum hops for name tunnels.

services.i2pd.outTunnels.<name?>.outboun.description: Guaranteed minimum hops for name tunnels.

services.i2pd.port.description: I2P listen port. If no one is given the router will pick between 9111 and 30777.

services.i2pd.precomputation.elgamal.description:
Whenever to use precomputated tables for ElGamal.
<command>i2pd</command> defaults to <literal>false</literal>
to save 64M of memory (and looses some performance).

We default to <literal>true</literal> as that is what most
users want anyway.

services.i2pd.proto.http.strictHeaders.description: Enable strict host checking on WebUI.

services.i2pd.proto.httpProxy.inbound.le.description: Guaranteed minimum hops for httpproxy tunnels.

services.i2pd.proto.httpProxy.outbound.l.description: Guaranteed minimum hops for httpproxy tunnels.

services.i2pd.proto.socksProxy.inbound.l.description: Guaranteed minimum hops for socksproxy tunnels.

services.i2pd.proto.socksProxy.outbound..description: Guaranteed minimum hops for socksproxy tunnels.

services.i2pd.reseed.file.description: Full path to SU3 file to reseed from.

services.i2pd.reseed.floodfill.description: Path to router info of floodfill to reseed from.

services.i2pd.reseed.proxy.description: URL for reseed proxy, supports http/socks.

services.i2pd.reseed.verify.description: Whether to enable SU3 signature verification.

services.i2pd.reseed.zipfile.description: Path to local .zip file to reseed from.

services.i2pd.share.description: Limit of transit traffic from max bandwidth in percents.

services.i2pd.trust.enable.description: Whether to enable Explicit trust options.

services.i2pd.trust.family.description: Router Familiy to trust for first hops.

services.i2pd.trust.routers.description: Only connect to the listed routers.

services.i2pd.upnp.enable.description: Whether to enable UPnP service discovery.

services.i2pd.upnp.name.description: Name i2pd appears in UPnP forwardings list.

services.icecast.admin.password.description: Password used for all administration functions.

services.icecast.admin.user.description: Username used for all administration functions.

services.icecast.hostname.description: DNS name or IP address that will be used for the stream directory lookups or possibily the playlist generation if a Host header is not provided.

services.icecast.listen.port.description: TCP port that will be used to accept client connections.

services.icingaweb2.authentications.description:
authentication.ini contents.
Will automatically be converted to a .ini file.

If the value is null, no authentication.ini is created and you can
modify it manually (e.g. via the web interface).

services.icingaweb2.enable.description: Whether to enable the icingaweb2 web interface.

services.icingaweb2.generalConfig.description:
config.ini contents.
Will automatically be converted to a .ini file.
If you don't set global.module_path, the module will take care of it.

If the value is null, no config.ini is created and you can
modify it manually (e.g. via the web interface).
Note that you need to update module_path manually.

services.icingaweb2.groupBackends.description:
groups.ini contents.
Will automatically be converted to a .ini file.

If the value is null, no groups.ini is created and you can
modify it manually (e.g. via the web interface).

services.icingaweb2.modulePackages.description:
Name-package attrset of Icingaweb 2 modules packages to enable.

If you enable modules manually (e.g. via the web ui), they will not be touched.

services.icingaweb2.modules.doc.enable.description: Whether to enable the icingaweb2 doc module.

services.icingaweb2.modules.migrate.enab.description: Whether to enable the icingaweb2 migrate module.

services.icingaweb2.modules.monitoring.e.description: Whether to enable the icingaweb2 monitoring module.

services.icingaweb2.modules.monitoring.g.description: Make config.ini of the monitoring module mutable (e.g. via the web interface).
List of string patterns for custom variables which should be excluded from users view.

services.icingaweb2.modules.monitoring.m.description: Make backends.ini of the monitoring module mutable (e.g. via the web interface).
Make commandtransports.ini of the monitoring module mutable (e.g. via the web interface).

services.icingaweb2.modules.monitoring.t.description: Host for the api or remote transport
Assign a icinga instance to this transport
Path to the socket for local or remote transports
Port to connect to for the api or remote transport
SSH identity resource for the remote transport
Username for the api or remote transport

services.icingaweb2.modules.setup.enable.description: Whether to enable the icingaweb2 setup module.

services.icingaweb2.modules.test.enable.description: Whether to enable the icingaweb2 test module.

services.icingaweb2.modules.translation..description: Whether to enable the icingaweb2 translation module.

services.icingaweb2.pool.description:
Name of existing PHP-FPM pool that is used to run Icingaweb2.
If not specified, a pool will automatically created with default values.

services.icingaweb2.resources.description:
resources.ini contents.
Will automatically be converted to a .ini file.

If the value is null, no resources.ini is created and you can
modify it manually (e.g. via the web interface).
Note that if you set passwords here, they will go into the nix store.

services.icingaweb2.roles.description:
roles.ini contents.
Will automatically be converted to a .ini file.

If the value is null, no roles.ini is created and you can
modify it manually (e.g. via the web interface).

services.icingaweb2.virtualHost.description: Name of the nginx virtualhost to use and setup. If null, no virtualhost is set up.

services.ihaskell.extraPackages.description:
Extra packages available to ghc when running ihaskell. The
value must be a function which receives the attrset defined
in <varname>haskellPackages</varname> as the sole argument.

services.illum.enable.description: Enable illum, a daemon for controlling screen brightness with brightness buttons.

services.incron.allow.description:
Users allowed to use incrontab.

If empty then no user will be allowed to have their own incrontab.
If <literal>null</literal> then will defer to <option>deny</option>.
If both <option>allow</option> and <option>deny</option> are null
then all users will be allowed to have their own incrontab.

services.incron.enable.description:
Whether to enable the incron daemon.

Note that commands run under incrontab only support common Nix profiles for the <envar>PATH</envar> provided variable.

services.incron.extraPackages.description: Extra packages available to the system incrontab.

services.infinoted.certificateChain.description:
Chain of CA-certificates to which our `certificateFile` is relative.
Optional for TLS.

services.infinoted.certificateFile.description: Server certificate to use for TLS

services.infinoted.extraConfig.description: Additional configuration to append to infinoted.conf

services.infinoted.group.description: What to call the primary group of the dedicated user under which infinoted is run

services.infinoted.keyFile.description: Private key to use for TLS

services.infinoted.passwordFile.description: File to read server-wide password from

services.infinoted.rootDirectory.description: Root of the directory structure to serve

services.infinoted.securityPolicy.description: How strictly to enforce clients connection with TLS.

services.infinoted.user.description: What to call the dedicated user under which infinoted is run

services.influxdb.dataDir.description: Data directory for influxd data files.

services.influxdb.enable.description: Whether to enable the influxdb server

services.influxdb.user.description: User account under which influxdb runs

services.interception-tools.enable.description: Whether to enable the interception tools service.

services.interception-tools.plugins.description:
A list of interception tools plugins that will be made available to use
inside the udevmon configuration.

services.interception-tools.udevmonConfi.default:
- JOB: "intercept -g $DEVNODE | caps2esc | uinput -d $DEVNODE"
  DEVICE:
    EVENTS:
      EV_KEY: [KEY_CAPSLOCK, KEY_ESC]
services.interception-tools.udevmonConfi.description:
String of udevmon YAML configuration, or path to a udevmon YAML
configuration file.
services.interception-tools.udevmonConfi.example:
- JOB: "intercept -g $DEVNODE | y2z | x2y | uinput -d $DEVNODE"
  DEVICE:
    EVENTS:
      EV_KEY: [KEY_X, KEY_Y]

services.iodine.clients.description:
Each attribute of this option defines a systemd service that
runs iodine. Many or none may be defined.
The name of each service is
<literal>iodine-<replaceable>name</replaceable></literal>
where <replaceable>name</replaceable> is the name of the
corresponding attribute name.

services.iodine.clients.<name>.relay.description: DNS server to use as a intermediate relay to the iodined server

services.iodine.clients.<name>.server.description: Domain or Subdomain of server running iodined

services.iodine.server.domain.description: Domain or subdomain of which nameservers point to us

services.iodine.server.ip.description: The assigned ip address or ip range

services.iperf3.authorizedUsersFile.description: Path to the configuration file containing authorized users credentials to run iperf tests.

services.iperf3.bind.description: Bind to the specific interface associated with the given address.

services.iperf3.enable.description: Whether to enable iperf3 network throughput testing server.

services.iperf3.extraFlags.description: Extra flags to pass to iperf3(1).

services.iperf3.forceFlush.description: Force flushing output at every interval.

services.iperf3.openFirewall.description: Open ports in the firewall for iperf3.

services.iperf3.port.description: Server port to listen on for iperf3 client requsts.
services.iperf3.port.type: 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

services.iperf3.rsaPrivateKey.description: Path to the RSA private key (not password-protected) used to decrypt authentication credentials from the client.

services.ipfs.apiAddress.description: Where IPFS exposes its API to

services.ipfs.autoMount.description: Whether IPFS should try to mount /ipfs and /ipns at startup.

services.ipfs.defaultMode.description: systemd service that is enabled by default

services.ipfs.emptyRepo.description: If set to true, the repo won't be initialized with help files

services.ipfs.enable.description: Whether to enable Interplanetary File System (WARNING: may cause severe network degredation).

services.ipfs.enableGC.description: Whether to enable automatic garbage collection

services.ipfs.extraConfig.description:
Attrset of daemon configuration to set using <command>ipfs config</command>, every time the daemon starts.
These are applied last, so may override configuration set by other options in this module.
Keep in mind that this configuration is stateful; i.e., unsetting anything in here does not reset the value to the default!

services.ipfs.extraFlags.description: Extra flags passed to the IPFS daemon

services.ipfs.gatewayAddress.description: Where the IPFS Gateway can be reached

services.ipfs.group.description: Group under which the IPFS daemon runs

services.ipfs.ipfsMountDir.description: Where to mount the IPFS namespace to

services.ipfs.ipnsMountDir.description: Where to mount the IPNS namespace to

services.ipfs.localDiscovery.description:
Whether to enable local discovery for the ipfs daemon.
          This will allow ipfs to scan ports on your local network. Some hosting services will ban you if you do this.

services.ipfs.serviceFdlimit.description: The fdlimit for the IPFS systemd unit or <literal>null</literal> to have the daemon attempt to manage it

services.ipfs.swarmAddress.description: Where IPFS listens for incoming p2p connections

services.ipfs.user.description: User under which the IPFS daemon runs

services.ircdHybrid.certificate.description: IRCD server SSL certificate. There are some limitations - read manual.

services.ircdHybrid.sid.description: IRCD server unique ID in a net of servers.

services.irkerd.enable.description: Whether to enable irker, an IRC notification daemon.

services.irkerd.listenAddress.description:
Specifies the bind address on which the irker daemon listens.
The default is localhost.

Irker authors strongly warn about the risks of running this on
a publicly accessible interface, so change this with caution.

services.irkerd.openPorts.description: Open ports in the firewall for irkerd

services.jack.alsa.enable.description: Route audio to/from generic ALSA-using applications using ALSA JACK PCM plugin.

services.jack.alsa.support32Bit.description: Whether to support sound for 32-bit ALSA applications on 64-bit system.

services.jack.jackd.enable.description:
Whether to enable JACK Audio Connection Kit. You need to add yourself to the "jackaudio" group
.

services.jack.jackd.extraOptions.description: Specifies startup command line arguments to pass to JACK server.

services.jack.jackd.session.description: Commands to run after JACK is started.

services.jack.loopback.dmixConfig.description:
For music production software that still doesn't support JACK natively you
would like to put buffer/period adjustments here
to decrease dmix device latency.

services.jack.loopback.enable.description:
Create ALSA loopback device, instead of using PCM plugin. Has broader
application support (things like Steam will work), but may need fine-tuning
for concrete hardware.

services.jack.loopback.index.description: Index of an ALSA loopback device.

services.jack.loopback.session.description: Additional commands to run to setup loopback device.

services.jackett.dataDir.description: The directory where Jackett stores its data files.

services.jackett.openFirewall.description: Open ports in the firewall for the Jackett web interface.

services.jackett.user.description: User account under which Jackett runs.

services.jboss.enable.description: Whether to enable JBoss. WARNING : this package is outdated and is known to have vulnerabilities.

services.jboss.libUrl.description: Location where the shared library JARs are stored

services.jboss.logDir.description: Location of the logfile directory of JBoss

services.jboss.serverDir.description: Location of the server instance files

services.jboss.tempDir.description: Location where JBoss stores its temp files

services.jboss.useJK.description: Whether to use to connector to the Apache HTTP server

services.jboss.user.description: User account under which jboss runs.

services.jellyfin.enable.description: Whether to enable Jellyfin Media Server.

services.jellyfin.user.description: User account under which Jellyfin runs.

services.jenkins.enable.description: Whether to enable the jenkins continuous integration server.

services.jenkins.environment.description:
Additional environment variables to be passed to the jenkins process.
As a base environment, jenkins receives NIX_PATH from
<option>environment.sessionVariables</option>, NIX_REMOTE is set to
"daemon" and JENKINS_HOME is set to the value of
<option>services.jenkins.home</option>.
This option has precedence and can be used to override those
mentioned variables.

services.jenkins.extraGroups.description: List of extra groups that the "jenkins" user should be a part of.

services.jenkins.extraJavaOptions.description: Additional command line arguments to pass to the Java run time (as opposed to Jenkins).

services.jenkins.extraOptions.description: Additional command line arguments to pass to Jenkins.

services.jenkins.group.description:
If the default user "jenkins" is configured then this is the primary
group of that user.

services.jenkins.home.description:
The path to use as JENKINS_HOME. If the default user "jenkins" is configured then
this is the home of the "jenkins" user.

services.jenkins.jobBuilder.accessToken.description:
User token in Jenkins used to reload config.
WARNING: This token will be world readable in the Nix store. To keep
it secret, use the <option>accessTokenFile</option> option instead.

services.jenkins.jobBuilder.accessTokenF.description:
File containing the API token for the <option>accessUser</option>
user.

services.jenkins.jobBuilder.accessUser.description: User id in Jenkins used to reload config.

services.jenkins.jobBuilder.enable.description:
Whether or not to enable the Jenkins Job Builder (JJB) service. It
allows defining jobs for Jenkins in a declarative manner.

Jobs managed through the Jenkins WebUI (or by other means) are left
unchanged.

Note that it really is declarative configuration; if you remove a
previously defined job, the corresponding job directory will be
deleted.

Please see the Jenkins Job Builder documentation for more info:
<link xlink:href="http://docs.openstack.org/infra/jenkins-job-builder/">
http://docs.openstack.org/infra/jenkins-job-builder/</link>

services.jenkins.jobBuilder.jsonJobs.description: Job descriptions for Jenkins Job Builder in JSON format.

services.jenkins.jobBuilder.nixJobs.description:
Job descriptions for Jenkins Job Builder in Nix format.

This is a trivial wrapper around jsonJobs, using builtins.toJSON
behind the scene.

services.jenkins.jobBuilder.yamlJobs.description: Job descriptions for Jenkins Job Builder in YAML format.
services.jenkins.jobBuilder.yamlJobs.example:
- job:
    name: jenkins-job-test-1
    builders:
      - shell: echo 'Hello world!'

services.jenkins.listenAddress.description:
Specifies the bind address on which the jenkins HTTP interface listens.
The default is the wildcard address.

services.jenkins.packages.description: Packages to add to PATH for the jenkins process.

services.jenkins.plugins.description:
A set of plugins to activate. Note that this will completely
remove and replace any previously installed plugins. If you
have manually-installed plugins that you want to keep while
using this module, set this option to
<literal>null</literal>. You can generate this set with a
tool such as <literal>jenkinsPlugins2nix</literal>.
services.jenkins.plugins.type: null or attribute set of packages

services.jenkins.port.description:
Specifies port number on which the jenkins HTTP interface listens.
The default is 8080.

services.jenkins.prefix.description:
Specifies a urlPrefix to use with jenkins.
If the example /jenkins is given, the jenkins server will be
accessible using localhost:8080/jenkins.

services.jenkins.user.description: User the jenkins server should execute under.

services.jenkinsSlave.enable.description:
If true the system will be configured to work as a jenkins slave.
If the system is also configured to work as a jenkins master then this has no effect.
In progress: Currently only assures the jenkins user is configured.

services.jenkinsSlave.group.description:
If the default slave agent user "jenkins" is configured then this is
the primary group of that user.

services.jenkinsSlave.home.description:
The path to use as JENKINS_HOME. If the default user "jenkins" is configured then
this is the home of the "jenkins" user.

services.jenkinsSlave.user.description: User the jenkins slave agent should execute under.

services.jira.catalinaOptions.description: Java options to pass to catalina/tomcat.

services.jira.enable.description: Whether to enable Atlassian JIRA service.

services.jira.home.description: Home directory of the JIRA instance.

services.jira.jrePackage.description: Note that Atlassian only support the Oracle JRE (JRASERVER-46152).

services.jira.proxy.enable.description: Whether to enable reverse proxy support.

services.jira.proxy.secure.description: Whether the connections to the proxy should be considered secure.

services.jira.sso.applicationName.description: Exact name of this JIRA instance in Crowd

services.jira.sso.applicationPassword.description: Application password of this JIRA instance in Crowd

services.jira.sso.crowd.description: Crowd Base URL without trailing slash

services.jira.sso.enable.description: Whether to enable SSO with Atlassian Crowd.

services.jira.sso.validationInterval.description:
Set to 0, if you want authentication checks to occur on each
request. Otherwise set to the number of minutes between request
to validate if the user is logged in or out of the Crowd SSO
server. Setting this value to 1 or higher will increase the
performance of Crowd's integration.

services.jormungandr.configFile.description:
The path of the jormungandr blockchain configuration file in YAML format.
If no file is specified, a file is generated using the other options.

services.jormungandr.genesisBlockFile.description: The path of the genesis block file if we are hosting it locally.

services.jormungandr.genesisBlockHash.description:
Set the genesis block hash (the hash of the block0) so we can retrieve
the genesis block (and the blockchain configuration) from the existing
storage or from the network.

services.jormungandr.secretFile.description:
The path of the jormungandr blockchain secret node configuration file in
YAML format. Do not store this in nix store!

services.journalbeat.extraConfig.description: Any other configuration options you want to add

services.journalbeat.stateDir.description:
Directory below <literal>/var/lib/</literal> to store journalbeat's
own logs and other data. This directory will be created automatically
using systemd's StateDirectory mechanism.

services.journalbeat.tags.description: Tags to place on the shipped log messages

services.journald.console.description: If non-empty, write log messages to the specified TTY device.

services.journald.enableHttpGateway.description: Whether to enable the HTTP gateway to the journal.

services.journald.extraConfig.description:
Extra config options for systemd-journald. See man journald.conf
for available options.

services.journald.forwardToSyslog.description: Whether to forward log messages to syslog.

services.journald.rateLimitBurst.description:
Configures the rate limiting burst limit (number of messages per
interval) that is applied to all messages generated on the system.
This rate limiting is applied per-service, so that two services
which log do not interfere with each other's limit.

services.journald.rateLimitInterval.description:
Configures the rate limiting interval that is applied to all
messages generated on the system. This rate limiting is applied
per-service, so that two services which log do not interfere with
each other's limit. The value may be specified in the following
units: s, min, h, ms, us. To turn off any kind of rate limiting,
set either value to 0.

services.journaldriver.applicationCreden.description:
Path to the service account private key (in JSON-format) used
to forward log entries to Stackdriver Logging on non-GCP
instances.

This option is required on non-GCP machines, but should not be
set on GCP instances.

services.journaldriver.enable.description:
Whether to enable journaldriver to forward journald logs to
Stackdriver Logging.

services.journaldriver.googleCloudProjec.description:
Configures the name of the Google Cloud project to which to
forward journald logs.

This option is required on non-GCP machines, but should not be
set on GCP instances.

services.journaldriver.logLevel.description: Log level at which journaldriver logs its own output.

services.journaldriver.logName.description:
Configures the name of the target log in Stackdriver Logging.
This option can be set to, for example, the hostname of a
machine to improve the user experience in the logging
overview.

services.journaldriver.logStream.description:
Configures the name of the Stackdriver Logging log stream into
which to write journald entries.

This option is required on non-GCP machines, but should not be
set on GCP instances.

services.journalwatch.accuracy.description:
The time window around the interval in which the journalwatch run will be scheduled.

The format is described in systemd.time(7).

services.journalwatch.enable.description: If enabled, periodically check the journal with journalwatch and report the results by mail.

services.journalwatch.extraConfig.description:
Extra lines to be added verbatim to the journalwatch/config configuration file.
You can add any commandline argument to the config, without the '--'.
See <literal>journalwatch --help</literal> for all arguments and their description.

default.filters:
(Stopped|Stopping|Starting|Started) .*
(Created slice|Removed slice) user-\d*\.slice\.
Received SIGRTMIN\+24 from PID .*
(Reached target|Stopped target) .*
Startup finished in \d*ms\.

services.journalwatch.filterBlocks.description:
filterBlocks can be defined to blacklist journal messages which are not errors.
Each block matches on a log entry field, and the filters in that block then are matched
against all messages with a matching log entry field.

All messages whose PRIORITY is at least 6 (INFO) are processed by journalwatch.
If you don't specify any filterBlocks, PRIORITY is reduced to 5 (NOTICE) by default.

All regular expressions are extended Python regular expressions, for details
see: http://doc.pyschools.com/html/regex.html

example.filters:
New session [a-z]?\d+ of user \w+\.
Removed session [a-z]?\d+\.

services.journalwatch.filterBlocks.*.fil.description:
The filters to apply on all messages which satisfy <option>match</option>.
Any of those messages that match any specified filter will be removed from journalwatch's output.
Each filter is an extended Python regular expression.
You can specify multiple filters and separate them by newlines.
Lines starting with '#' are comments. Inline-comments are not permitted.

services.journalwatch.filterBlocks.*.mat.description:
Syntax: <literal>field = value</literal>
Specifies the log entry <literal>field</literal> this block should apply to.
If the <literal>field</literal> of a message matches this <literal>value</literal>,
this patternBlock's <option>filters</option> are applied.
If <literal>value</literal> starts and ends with a slash, it is interpreted as
an extended python regular expression, if not, it's an exact match.
The journal fields are explained in systemd.journal-fields(7).

services.journalwatch.interval.description:
How often to run journalwatch.

The format is described in systemd.time(7).

services.journalwatch.mailBinary.description: Sendmail-compatible binary to be used to send the messages.

services.journalwatch.mailFrom.description: Mail address to send journalwatch reports from.

services.journalwatch.mailTo.description: Mail address to send journalwatch reports to.

services.journalwatch.priority.description:
Lowest priority of message to be considered.
A value between 7 ("debug"), and 0 ("emerg"). Defaults to 6 ("info").
If you don't care about anything with "info" priority, you can reduce
this to e.g. 5 ("notice") to considerably reduce the amount of
messages without needing many <option>filterBlocks</option>.

services.jupyter.enable.description: Whether to enable Jupyter development server.

services.jupyter.group.description:
Name of the group used to run the jupyter service.
Use this if you want to create a group of users that are able to view the notebook directory's content.

services.jupyter.kernels.description:
Declarative kernel config

      Kernels can be declared in any language that supports and has the required
      dependencies to communicate with a jupyter server.
      In python's case, it means that ipykernel package must always be included in
      the list of packages of the targeted environment.
services.jupyter.kernels.type: null or attribute set of submodules

services.jupyter.kernels.<name>.argv.description: Command and arguments to start the kernel.

services.jupyter.kernels.<name>.displayN.description: Name that will be shown to the user.

services.jupyter.kernels.<name>.language.description: Language of the environment. Typically the name of the binary.

services.jupyter.password.description:
Password to use with notebook.
Can be generated using:
  In [1]: from notebook.auth import passwd
  In [2]: passwd('test')
  Out[2]: 'sha1:1b961dc713fb:88483270a63e57d18d43cf337e629539de1436ba'
  NOTE: you need to keep the single quote inside the nix string.
Or you can use a python oneliner:
  "open('/path/secret_file', 'r', encoding='utf8').read().strip()"
It will be interpreted at the end of the notebookConfig.

services.jupyter.port.description: Port number Jupyter will be listening on.

services.jupyter.user.description:
Name of the user used to run the jupyter service.
For security reason, jupyter should really not be run as root.
If not set (jupyter), the service will create a jupyter user with appropriate settings.

services.keepalived.snmp.enableKeepalive.description: Enable SNMP handling of vrrp element of KEEPALIVED MIB.

services.keepalived.snmp.enableRfc.description: Enable SNMP handling of RFC2787 and RFC6527 VRRP MIBs.

services.keepalived.snmp.enableRfcV3.description: Enable SNMP handling of RFC6527 VRRP MIB.

services.keepalived.snmp.socket.description:
Socket to use for connecting to SNMP master agent. If this value is
set to null, keepalived's default will be used, which is
unix:/var/agentx/master, unless using a network namespace, when the
default is udp:localhost:705.

services.keepalived.vrrpInstances.<name>.description: Extra lines to be added verbatim to the vrrp_instance section.
Interface for inside_network, bound by vrrp.

VRRP will normally preempt a lower priority machine when a higher
priority machine comes online. "nopreempt" allows the lower priority
machine to maintain the master role, even when a higher priority machine
comes back online. NOTE: For this to work, the initial state of this
entry must be BACKUP.

For electing MASTER, highest priority wins. To be MASTER, make 50 more
than other machines.

Initial state. As soon as the other machine(s) come up, an election will
be held and the machine with the highest "priority" will become MASTER.
So the entry here doesn't matter a whole lot.
List of network interfaces to monitor for health tracking.
List of script names to invoke for health tracking.

Do not send VRRP adverts over VRRP multicast group. Instead it sends
adverts to the following list of ip addresses using unicast design
fashion. It can be cool to use VRRP FSM and features in a networking
environment where multicast is not supported! IP Addresses specified can
IPv4 as well as IPv6.

Default IP for binding vrrpd is the primary IP on interface. If you
want to hide location of vrrpd, use this IP as src_addr for unicast
vrrp packets.
IP address, optionally with a netmask: IPADDR[/MASK]
The broadcast address on the interface.
The name of the device to add the address to.

Each address may be tagged with a label string. In order to preserve
compatibility with Linux-2.0 net aliases, this string must coincide with
the name of the device or must be prefixed with the device name followed
by colon.
The scope of the area where this address is valid.

Arbitrary unique number 0..255. Used to differentiate multiple instances
of vrrpd running on the same NIC (and hence same socket).

Name of the vmac interface to use. keepalived will come up with a name
if you don't specify one.
Send/Recv VRRP messages from base interface instead of VMAC interface.

services.kmscon.enable.description:
Use kmscon as the virtual console instead of gettys.
kmscon is a kms/dri-based userspace virtual terminal implementation.
It supports a richer feature set than the standard linux console VT,
including full unicode support, and when the video card supports drm
should be much faster.

services.kmscon.hwRender.description: Whether to use 3D hardware acceleration to render the console.
