services.nextcloud.config.extraTrustedDo.description:
Trusted domains, from which the nextcloud installation will be
acessible.  You don't need to add
<literal>services.nextcloud.hostname</literal> here.

services.nextcloud.config.overwriteProto.description:
Force Nextcloud to always use HTTPS i.e. for link generation. Nextcloud
uses the currently used protocol by default, but when behind a reverse-proxy,
it may use <literal>http</literal> for everything although Nextcloud
may be served via HTTPS.

services.nextcloud.https.description: Enable if there is a TLS terminating proxy in front of nextcloud.

services.nextcloud.maxUploadSize.description:
Defines the upload limit for files. This changes the relevant options
in php.ini and nginx if enabled.

services.nextcloud.nginx.enable.description:
Whether to enable nginx virtual host management.
Further nginx configuration can be done by adapting <literal>services.nginx.virtualHosts.<name></literal>.
See <xref linkend="opt-services.nginx.virtualHosts"/> for further information.

services.nextcloud.phpOptions.description: Options for PHP's php.ini file for nextcloud.

services.nextcloud.poolConfig.description: Options for nextcloud's PHP pool. See the documentation on <literal>php-fpm.conf</literal> for details on configuration directives.

services.nextcloud.poolSettings.description: Options for nextcloud's PHP pool. See the documentation on <literal>php-fpm.conf</literal> for details on configuration directives.
services.nextcloud.poolSettings.type: attribute set of string or signed integer or booleans

services.nextcloud.skeletonDirectory.description:
The directory where the skeleton files are located. These files will be
copied to the data directory of new users. Leave empty to not copy any
skeleton files.

services.nextcloud.webfinger.description:
Enable this option if you plan on using the webfinger plugin.
The appropriate nginx rewrite rules will be added to your configuration.

services.nexus.enable.description: Whether to enable Sonatype Nexus3 OSS service.

services.nexus.home.description: Home directory of the Nexus3 instance.

services.nexus.jvmOpts.description:
Options for the JVM written to `nexus.jvmopts`.
Please refer to the docs (https://help.sonatype.com/repomanager3/installation/configuring-the-runtime-environment)
for further information.

services.nfs.server.createMountPoints.description: Whether to create the mount points in the exports file at startup time.

services.nfs.server.enable.description: Whether to enable the kernel's NFS server.

services.nfs.server.exports.description:
Contents of the /etc/exports file.  See
<citerefentry><refentrytitle>exports</refentrytitle>
<manvolnum>5</manvolnum></citerefentry> for the format.

services.nfs.server.extraNfsdConfig.description: Extra configuration options for the [nfsd] section of /etc/nfs.conf.

services.nfs.server.hostName.description:
Hostname or address on which NFS requests will be accepted.
Default is all.  See the <option>-H</option> option in
<citerefentry><refentrytitle>nfsd</refentrytitle>
<manvolnum>8</manvolnum></citerefentry>.

services.nfs.server.lockdPort.description:
Use a fixed port for the NFS lock manager kernel module
(<literal>lockd/nlockmgr</literal>).  This is useful if the
NFS server is behind a firewall.

services.nfs.server.mountdPort.description: Use fixed port for rpc.mountd, useful if server is behind firewall.

services.nfs.server.nproc.description: Number of NFS server threads.  Defaults to the recommended value of 8.

services.nfs.server.statdPort.description:
Use a fixed port for <command>rpc.statd</command>. This is
useful if the NFS server is behind a firewall.

services.nghttpx.backend-address-family.description:
Specify address family of backend connections. If "auto" is
given, both IPv4 and IPv6 are considered. If "IPv4" is given,
only IPv4 address is considered. If "IPv6" is given, only IPv6
address is considered.

Please see https://nghttp2.org/documentation/nghttpx.1.html#cmdoption-nghttpx--backend-address-family

services.nghttpx.backends.*.params.affin.description:
If "ip" is given, client IP based session affinity is
enabled. If "none" is given, session affinity is disabled.

Session affinity is enabled (by nghttpx) per-backend
pattern. If at least one backend has a non-"none" affinity,
then session affinity is enabled for all backend servers
sharing the same pattern.

It is advised to set affinity on all backends explicitly if
session affinity is desired. The session affinity may break if
one of the backend gets unreachable, or backend settings are
reloaded or replaced by API.

Please see https://nghttp2.org/documentation/nghttpx.1.html#cmdoption-nghttpx-b
for more detail.

services.nghttpx.backends.*.params.dns.description:
Name resolution of a backends host name is done at start up,
or configuration reload. If "dns" is true, name resolution
takes place dynamically.

This is useful if a backends address changes frequently. If
"dns" is true, name resolution of a backend's host name at
start up, or configuration reload is skipped.

Please see https://nghttp2.org/documentation/nghttpx.1.html#cmdoption-nghttpx-b
for more detail.

services.nghttpx.backends.*.params.fall.description:
If nghttpx cannot connect to the backend N times in a row, the
backend is assumed to be offline and is excluded from load
balancing. If N is 0 the backend is never excluded from load
balancing.

Please see https://nghttp2.org/documentation/nghttpx.1.html#cmdoption-nghttpx-b
for more detail.

services.nghttpx.backends.*.params.proto.description:
This option configures the protocol the backend server expects
to use.

Please see https://nghttp2.org/documentation/nghttpx.1.html#cmdoption-nghttpx-b
for more detail.

services.nghttpx.backends.*.params.redir.description:
If true, a backend match requires the frontend connection be
TLS encrypted. If it is not, nghttpx responds to the request
with a 308 status code and https URI the client should use
instead in the Location header.

The port number in the redirect URI is 443 by default and can
be changed using 'services.nghttpx.redirect-https-port'
option.

If at least one backend has "redirect-if-not-tls" set to true,
this feature is enabled for all backend servers with the same
pattern. It is advised to set "redirect-if-no-tls" parameter
to all backends explicitly if this feature is desired.

Please see https://nghttp2.org/documentation/nghttpx.1.html#cmdoption-nghttpx-b
for more detail.

services.nghttpx.backends.*.params.rise.description:
If the backend is excluded from load balancing, nghttpx will
periodically attempt to make a connection to the backend. If
the connection is successful N times in a row the backend is
re-included in load balancing. If N is 0 a backend is never
reconsidered for load balancing once it falls.

Please see https://nghttp2.org/documentation/nghttpx.1.html#cmdoption-nghttpx-b
for more detail.

services.nghttpx.backends.*.params.sni.description:
Override the TLS SNI field value. This value (in nghttpx)
defaults to the host value of the backend configuration.

Please see https://nghttp2.org/documentation/nghttpx.1.html#cmdoption-nghttpx-b
for more detail.

services.nghttpx.backends.*.params.tls.description:
This option determines whether nghttpx will negotiate its
connection with a backend server using TLS or not. The burden
is on the backend server to provide the TLS certificate!

Please see https://nghttp2.org/documentation/nghttpx.1.html#cmdoption-nghttpx-b
for more detail.

services.nghttpx.backends.*.patterns.description:
List of nghttpx backend patterns.

Please see https://nghttp2.org/documentation/nghttpx.1.html#cmdoption-nghttpx-b
for more information on the pattern syntax and nghttpxs behavior.

services.nghttpx.backends.*.server.description:
Backend server location specified as either a host:port pair
or a unix domain docket.

services.nghttpx.extraConfig.description:
Extra configuration options to be appended to the generated
configuration file.

services.nghttpx.frontends.description: A list of frontend listener specifications.

services.nghttpx.frontends.*.params.api.description:
Enable API access for this frontend. This enables you to
dynamically modify nghttpx at run-time therefore this feature
is disabled by default and should be turned on with care.

Please see https://nghttp2.org/documentation/nghttpx.1.html#cmdoption-nghttpx-f
for more detail.

services.nghttpx.frontends.*.params.heal.description:
Make this frontend a health monitor endpoint. Any request
received on this frontend is responded to with a 200 OK.

Please see https://nghttp2.org/documentation/nghttpx.1.html#cmdoption-nghttpx-f
for more detail.

services.nghttpx.frontends.*.params.prox.description:
Accept PROXY protocol version 1 on frontend connection.

Please see https://nghttp2.org/documentation/nghttpx.1.html#cmdoption-nghttpx-f
for more detail.

services.nghttpx.frontends.*.params.sni-.description:
When performing a match to select a backend server, SNI host
name received from the client is used instead of the request
host. See --backend option about the pattern match.

Please see https://nghttp2.org/documentation/nghttpx.1.html#cmdoption-nghttpx-f
for more detail.

services.nghttpx.frontends.*.params.tls.description:
Enable or disable TLS. If true (enabled) the key and
certificate must be configured for nghttpx.

Please see https://nghttp2.org/documentation/nghttpx.1.html#cmdoption-nghttpx-f
for more detail.

services.nghttpx.frontends.*.server.description:
Frontend server interface binding specification as either a
host:port pair or a unix domain docket.

NB: a host of "*" listens on all interfaces and includes IPv6
addresses.

services.nghttpx.rlimit-nofile.description:
Set maximum number of open files (RLIMIT_NOFILE) to <N>. If 0
is given, nghttpx does not set the limit.

Please see https://nghttp2.org/documentation/nghttpx.1.html#cmdoption-nghttpx--rlimit-nofile

services.nghttpx.single-process.description:
Run this program in a single process mode for debugging
purpose. Without this option, nghttpx creates at least 2
processes: master and worker processes. If this option is
used, master and worker are unified into a single
process. nghttpx still spawns additional process if neverbleed
is used. In the single process mode, the signal handling
feature is disabled.

Please see https://nghttp2.org/documentation/nghttpx.1.html#cmdoption-nghttpx--single-process

services.nghttpx.single-thread.description:
Run everything in one thread inside the worker process. This
feature is provided for better debugging experience, or for
the platforms which lack thread support. If threading is
disabled, this option is always enabled.

Please see https://nghttp2.org/documentation/nghttpx.1.html#cmdoption-nghttpx--single-thread

services.nghttpx.tls.description:
TLS certificate and key paths. Note that this does not enable
TLS for a frontend listener, to do so, a frontend
specification must set <literal>params.tls</literal> to true.

services.nghttpx.tls.crt.description: Path to the TLS certificate file.

services.nghttpx.tls.key.description: Path to the TLS key file.

services.nghttpx.workers.description:
Set the number of worker threads.

Please see https://nghttp2.org/documentation/nghttpx.1.html#cmdoption-nghttpx-n

services.nginx.appendConfig.description:
Configuration lines appended to the generated Nginx
configuration file. Commonly used by different modules
providing http snippets. <option>appendConfig</option>
can be specified more than once and it's value will be
concatenated (contrary to <option>config</option> which
can be set only once).

services.nginx.appendHttpConfig.description:
Configuration lines to be appended to the generated http block.
          This is mutually exclusive with using config and httpConfig for
          specifying the whole http block verbatim.

services.nginx.commonHttpConfig.description:
With nginx you must provide common http context definitions before
they are used, e.g. log_format, resolver, etc. inside of server
or location contexts. Use this attribute to set these definitions
at the appropriate location.

services.nginx.config.description:
Verbatim nginx.conf configuration.
          This is mutually exclusive with the structured configuration
          via virtualHosts and the recommendedXyzSettings configuration
          options. See appendConfig for appending to the generated http block.

services.nginx.enable.description: Whether to enable Nginx Web Server.

services.nginx.enableReload.description:
Reload nginx when configuration file changes (instead of restart).
The configuration file is exposed at <filename>/etc/nginx/nginx.conf</filename>.
See also <literal>systemd.services.*.restartIfChanged</literal>.

services.nginx.eventsConfig.description: Configuration lines to be set inside the events block.

services.nginx.gitweb.enable.description: If true, enable gitweb in nginx. Access it at http://yourserver/gitweb

services.nginx.group.description: Group account under which nginx runs.

services.nginx.httpConfig.description:
Configuration lines to be set inside the http block.
          This is mutually exclusive with the structured configuration
          via virtualHosts and the recommendedXyzSettings configuration
          options. See appendHttpConfig for appending to the generated http block.

services.nginx.logError.description:
Configures logging.
          The first parameter defines a file that will store the log. The
          special value stderr selects the standard error file. Logging to
          syslog can be configured by specifying the syslog: prefix.
          The second parameter determines the level of logging, and can be
          one of the following: debug, info, notice, warn, error, crit,
          alert, or emerg. Log levels above are listed in the order of
          increasing severity. Setting a certain log level will cause all
          messages of the specified and more severe log levels to be logged.
          If this parameter is omitted then error is used.

services.nginx.mapHashBucketSize.description:
Sets the bucket size for the map variables hash tables. Default
value depends on the processors cache line size.

services.nginx.mapHashMaxSize.description: Sets the maximum size of the map variables hash tables.

services.nginx.package.description:
Nginx package to use. This defaults to the stable version. Note
          that the nginx team recommends to use the mainline version which
          available in nixpkgs as <literal>nginxMainline</literal>.

services.nginx.preStart.default:
test -d /var/spool/nginx/logs || mkdir -m 750 -p /var/spool/nginx/logs
test `stat -c %a /var/spool/nginx` = "750" || chmod 750 /var/spool/nginx
test `stat -c %a /var/spool/nginx/logs` = "750" || chmod 750 /var/spool/nginx/logs
chown -R nginx:nginx /var/spool/nginx
services.nginx.preStart.description: Shell commands executed before the service's nginx is started.

services.nginx.proxyResolveWhileRunning.description:
Resolves domains of proxyPass targets at runtime
and not only at start, you have to set
services.nginx.resolver, too.

services.nginx.resolver.description: Configures name servers used to resolve names of upstream servers into addresses

services.nginx.resolver.ipv6.description:
By default, nginx will look up both IPv4 and IPv6 addresses while resolving.
If looking up of IPv6 addresses is not desired, the ipv6=off parameter can be
specified.

services.nginx.resolver.valid.description:
By default, nginx caches answers using the TTL value of a response.
An optional valid parameter allows overriding it

services.nginx.serverTokens.description: Show nginx version in headers and error pages.

services.nginx.sslCiphers.description: Ciphers to choose from when negotiating tls handshakes.

services.nginx.sso.configuration.description:
nginx-sso configuration
(<link xlink:href="https://github.com/Luzifer/nginx-sso/wiki/Main-Configuration">documentation</link>)
as a Nix attribute set.

services.nginx.stateDir.description: Directory holding all state for nginx to run.

services.nginx.statusPage.description: Enable status page reachable from localhost on http://127.0.0.1/nginx_status.

services.nginx.upstreams.description: Defines a group of servers to use as proxy target.

services.nginx.upstreams.<name>.extraCon.description: These lines go to the end of the upstream verbatim.

services.nginx.upstreams.<name>.servers.description: Defines the address and other parameters of the upstream servers.

services.nginx.upstreams.<name>.servers..description:
Marks the server as a backup server. It will be passed
requests when the primary servers are unavailable.

services.nginx.user.description: User account under which nginx runs.

services.nginx.virtualHosts.<name>.acmeF.description:
Host which to proxy requests to if acme challenge is not found. Useful
if you want multiple hosts to be able to verify the same domain name.

services.nginx.virtualHosts.<name>.acmeR.description: Directory for the acme challenge which is PUBLIC, don't put certs or keys in here

services.nginx.virtualHosts.<name>.addSS.description:
Whether to enable HTTPS in addition to plain HTTP. This will set defaults for
<literal>listen</literal> to listen on all interfaces on the respective default
ports (80, 443).

services.nginx.virtualHosts.<name>.basic.description:
Basic Auth protection for a vhost.

WARNING: This is implemented to store the password in plain text in the
nix store.
Basic Auth password file for a vhost.

services.nginx.virtualHosts.<name>.enabl.description:
Whether to ask Let's Encrypt to sign a certificate for this vhost.
Alternately, you can use an existing certificate through <option>useACMEHost</option>.

services.nginx.virtualHosts.<name>.extra.description: These lines go to the end of the vhost verbatim.

services.nginx.virtualHosts.<name>.force.description:
Whether to add a separate nginx server block that permanently redirects (301)
all plain HTTP traffic to HTTPS. This will set defaults for
<literal>listen</literal> to listen on all interfaces on the respective default
ports (80, 443), where the non-SSL listens are used for the redirect vhosts.

services.nginx.virtualHosts.<name>.globa.description:
If set, all requests for this host are redirected permanently to
the given hostname.

services.nginx.virtualHosts.<name>.http2.description:
Whether to enable HTTP 2.
Note that (as of writing) due to nginx's implementation, to disable
HTTP 2 you have to disable it on all vhosts that use a given
IP address / port.
If there is one server block configured to enable http2,then it is
enabled for all server blocks on this IP.
See https://stackoverflow.com/a/39466948/263061.

services.nginx.virtualHosts.<name>.liste.description:
Listen addresses and ports for this virtual host.
IPv6 addresses must be enclosed in square brackets.
Note: this option overrides <literal>addSSL</literal>
and <literal>onlySSL</literal>.
Extra parameters of this listen directive.

services.nginx.virtualHosts.<name>.locat.description: These lines go to the end of the location verbatim.

Order of this location block in relation to the others in the vhost.
The semantics are the same as with `lib.mkOrder`. Smaller values have
a greater priority.

Adds proxy_pass directive and sets recommended proxy headers if
recommendedProxySettings is enabled.
Whether to supporty proxying websocket connections with HTTP/1.1.
Adds a return directive, for e.g. redirections.

services.nginx.virtualHosts.<name>.onlyS.description:
Whether to enable HTTPS and reject plain HTTP connections. This will set
defaults for <literal>listen</literal> to listen on all interfaces on port 443.

services.nginx.virtualHosts.<name>.root.description: The path of the web root directory.

services.nginx.virtualHosts.<name>.serve.description: Additional names of virtual hosts served by this virtual host configuration.
Name of this virtual host. Defaults to attribute name in virtualHosts.

services.nginx.virtualHosts.<name>.sslCe.description: Path to server SSL certificate key.

services.nginx.virtualHosts.<name>.sslTr.description: Path to root SSL certificate for stapling and client certificates.

services.nginx.virtualHosts.<name>.useAC.description:
A host of an existing Let's Encrypt certificate to use.
This is useful if you have many subdomains and want to avoid hitting the
<link xlink:href="https://letsencrypt.org/docs/rate-limits/">rate limit</link>.
Alternately, you can generate a certificate through <option>enableACME</option>.
<emphasis>Note that this option does not create any certificates, nor it does add subdomains to existing ones  you will need to create them manually using  <xref linkend="opt-security.acme.certs"/>.</emphasis>

services.ngircd.enable.description: Whether to enable the ngircd IRC server.

services.nix-serve.bindAddress.description: IP address where nix-serve will bind its listening socket.

services.nix-serve.enable.description: Whether to enable nix-serve, the standalone Nix binary cache server.

services.nix-serve.extraParams.description: Extra command line parameters for nix-serve.

services.nix-serve.port.description: Port number where nix-serve will listen on.

services.nix-serve.secretKeyFile.description:
The path to the file used for signing derivation data.
Generate with:

```
nix-store --generate-binary-cache-key key-name secret-key-file public-key-file
```

Make sure user `nix-serve` has read access to the private key file.

For more details see <citerefentry><refentrytitle>nix-store</refentrytitle><manvolnum>1</manvolnum></citerefentry>.

services.nixops-dns.dnsmasq.description:
Enable dnsmasq forwarding to nixops-dns. This allows to use
nixops-dns for `services.nixops-dns.domain` resolution
while forwarding the rest of the queries to original resolvers.

services.nixops-dns.domain.description:
Fake domain name to resolve to NixOps virtual machines.

For example "ops" will resolve "vm.ops".

services.nixops-dns.enable.description:
Whether to enable the nixops-dns resolution
of NixOps virtual machines via dnsmasq and fake domain name.

services.nixops-dns.user.description:
The user the nixops-dns daemon should run as.
This should be the user, which is also used for nixops and
have the .nixops directory in its home.

services.nixosManual.browser.description: Browser used to show the manual.

services.nixosManual.showManual.description:
Whether to show the NixOS manual on one of the virtual
consoles.

services.nixosManual.ttyNumber.description: Virtual console on which to show the manual.

services.nntp-proxy.listenAddress.description: Proxy listen address (IPv6 literal addresses need to be enclosed in "[" and "]" characters)

services.nntp-proxy.prohibitPosting.description: Whether to prohibit posting to the upstream server

services.nntp-proxy.upstreamMaxConnectio.description: Upstream server maximum allowed concurrent connections

services.nntp-proxy.users.<name>.maxConn.description: Maximum number of concurrent connections to the proxy for this user

services.nntp-proxy.users.<name>.passwor.description: SHA-512 password hash (can be generated by mkpasswd -m sha-512 <password>)

services.novacomd.enable.description: Whether to enable Novacom service for connecting to WebOS devices.

services.nscd.config.default:
# We basically use nscd as a proxy for forwarding nss requests to appropriate
# nss modules, as we run nscd with LD_LIBRARY_PATH set to the directory
# containing all such modules
# Note that we can not use `enable-cache no` As this will actually cause nscd
# to just reject the nss requests it receives, which then causes glibc to
# fallback to trying to handle the request by itself. Which won't work as glibc
# is not aware of the path in which the nss modules live.  As a workaround, we
# have `enable-cache yes` with an explicit ttl of 0
server-user             nscd

enable-cache            passwd          yes
positive-time-to-live   passwd          0
negative-time-to-live   passwd          0
shared                  passwd          yes

enable-cache            group           yes
positive-time-to-live   group           0
negative-time-to-live   group           0
shared                  group           yes

enable-cache            netgroup        yes
positive-time-to-live   netgroup        0
negative-time-to-live   netgroup        0
shared                  netgroup        yes

enable-cache            hosts           yes
positive-time-to-live   hosts           600
negative-time-to-live   hosts           0
shared                  hosts           yes

enable-cache            services        yes
positive-time-to-live   services        0
negative-time-to-live   services        0
shared                  services        yes
services.nscd.config.description: Configuration to use for Name Service Cache Daemon.

services.nscd.enable.description: Whether to enable the Name Service Cache Daemon.

services.nsd.bind8Stats.description: Whether to enable BIND8 like statistics.

services.nsd.dnssecInterval.description: How often to check whether dnssec key rollover is required

services.nsd.enable.description: Whether to enable NSD authoritative DNS server.

services.nsd.hideVersion.description: Whether NSD should answer VERSION.BIND and VERSION.SERVER CHAOS class queries.

services.nsd.identity.description: Identify the server (CH TXT ID.SERVER entry).

services.nsd.interfaces.description: What addresses the server should listen to.

services.nsd.ipFreebind.description:
Whether to bind to nonlocal addresses and interfaces that are down.
Similar to ip-transparent.

services.nsd.ipTransparent.description: Allow binding to non local addresses.

services.nsd.ipv4.description: Whether to listen on IPv4 connections.

services.nsd.ipv4EDNSSize.description: Preferred EDNS buffer size for IPv4.

services.nsd.ipv6.description: Whether to listen on IPv6 connections.

services.nsd.ipv6EDNSSize.description: Preferred EDNS buffer size for IPv6.

services.nsd.keys.<name>.keyFile.description:
Path to the file which contains the actual base64 encoded
key. The key will be copied into "/var/lib/nsd/private" before
NSD starts. The copied file is only accessibly by the NSD
user.

services.nsd.logTimeAscii.description: Log time in ascii, if false then in unix epoch seconds.

services.nsd.port.description: Port the service should bind do.

services.nsd.ratelimit.ipv4PrefixLength.description: IPv4 prefix length. Addresses are grouped by netblock.

services.nsd.ratelimit.ipv6PrefixLength.description: IPv6 prefix length. Addresses are grouped by netblock.

services.nsd.ratelimit.ratelimit.description:
Max qps allowed from any query source.
0 means unlimited. With an verbosity of 2 blocked and
unblocked subnets will be logged.

services.nsd.ratelimit.size.description:
Size of the hashtable. More buckets use more memory but lower
the chance of hash hash collisions.

services.nsd.ratelimit.slip.description:
Number of packets that get discarded before replying a SLIP response.
0 disables SLIP responses. 1 will make every response a SLIP response.

services.nsd.ratelimit.whitelistRatelimi.description:
Max qps allowed from whitelisted sources.
0 means unlimited. Set the rrl-whitelist option for specific
queries to apply this limit instead of the default to them.

services.nsd.remoteControl.controlCertFi.description:
Path to the client certificate signed with the server certificate.
This file is used by nsd-control and generated by nsd-control-setup.

services.nsd.remoteControl.controlKeyFil.description:
Path to the client private key, which is used by nsd-control
but not by the server. This file is generated by nsd-control-setup.

services.nsd.remoteControl.enable.description: Whether to enable remote control via nsd-control.

services.nsd.remoteControl.interfaces.description: Which interfaces NSD should bind to for remote control.

services.nsd.remoteControl.port.description: Port number for remote control operations (uses TLS over TCP).

services.nsd.remoteControl.serverCertFil.description:
Path to the server self signed certificate, which is used by the server
but and by nsd-control. This file is generated by nsd-control-setup.

services.nsd.remoteControl.serverKeyFile.description:
Path to the server private key, which is used by the server
but not by nsd-control. This file is generated by nsd-control-setup.

services.nsd.reuseport.description:
Whether to enable SO_REUSEPORT on all used sockets. This lets multiple
processes bind to the same port. This speeds up operation especially
if the server count is greater than one and makes fast restarts less
prone to fail

services.nsd.rootServer.description:
Whether this server will be a root server (a DNS root server, you
usually don't want that).

services.nsd.roundRobin.description: Whether to enable round robin rotation of records.

services.nsd.serverCount.description: Number of NSD servers to fork. Put the number of CPUs to use here.

services.nsd.statistics.description:
Statistics are produced every number of seconds. Prints to log.
If null no statistics are logged.

services.nsd.tcpCount.description: Maximum number of concurrent TCP connections per server.

services.nsd.tcpQueryCount.description:
Maximum number of queries served on a single TCP connection.
0 means no maximum.

services.nsd.version.description:
The version string replied for CH TXT version.server and version.bind
queries. Will use the compiled package version on null.
See hideVersion for enabling/disabling this responses.

services.nsd.xfrdReloadTimeout.description: Number of seconds between reloads triggered by xfrd.

services.nsd.zonefilesCheck.description: Whether to check mtime of all zone files on start and sighup.

services.nsd.zones.description:
Define your zones here. Zones can cascade other zones and therefore
inherit settings from parent zones. Look at the definition of
children to learn about inheritance and child zones.
The given example will define 3 zones (example.(com|org|net).). Both
example.com. and example.org. inherit their configuration from
serverGroup1.

services.nsd.zones.<name>.allowAXFRFallb.description:
If NSD as secondary server should be allowed to AXFR if the primary
server does not allow IXFR.

services.nsd.zones.<name>.allowNotify.description:
Listed primary servers are allowed to notify this secondary server.
<screen><![CDATA[
Format: <ip> <key-name | NOKEY | BLOCKED>

<ip> either a plain IPv4/IPv6 address or range. Valid patters for ranges:
* 10.0.0.0/24            # via subnet size
* 10.0.0.0&255.255.255.0 # via subnet mask
* 10.0.0.1-10.0.0.254    # via range

A optional port number could be added with a '@':
* 2001:1234::1@1234

<key-name | NOKEY | BLOCKED>
* <key-name> will use the specified TSIG key
* NOKEY      no TSIG signature is required
* BLOCKED    notifies from non-listed or blocked IPs will be ignored
* ]]></screen>

services.nsd.zones.<name>.children.description:
Children zones inherit all options of their parents. Attributes
defined in a child will overwrite the ones of its parent. Only
leaf zones will be actually served. This way it's possible to
define maybe zones which share most attributes without
duplicating everything. This mechanism replaces nsd's patterns
in a save and functional way.

services.nsd.zones.<name>.data.description:
The actual zone data. This is the content of your zone file.
Use imports or pkgs.lib.readFile if you don't want this data in your config file.

services.nsd.zones.<name>.dnssecPolicy.a.description: Which algorithm to use for DNSSEC

services.nsd.zones.<name>.dnssecPolicy.c.description: The length of time to ensure that keys will be correct; no action will be taken to create new keys to be activated after this time.

services.nsd.zones.<name>.dnssecPolicy.k.description: Key policy for key signing keys
How long after deactivation to keep a key in the zone
How long in advance to publish new keys

services.nsd.zones.<name>.dnssecPolicy.z.description: Key policy for zone signing keys
How long after deactivation to keep a key in the zone
How long in advance to publish new keys

services.nsd.zones.<name>.maxRefreshSecs.description:
Limit refresh time for secondary zones. This is the timer which
checks to see if the zone has to be refetched when it expires.
Normally the value from the SOA record is used, but this  option
restricts that value.

services.nsd.zones.<name>.maxRetrySecs.description:
Limit retry time for secondary zones. This is the timeout after
a failed fetch attempt for the zone. Normally the value from
the SOA record is used, but this option restricts that value.

services.nsd.zones.<name>.minRefreshSecs.description: Limit refresh time for secondary zones.

services.nsd.zones.<name>.minRetrySecs.description: Limit retry time for secondary zones.

services.nsd.zones.<name>.notify.description:
This primary server will notify all given secondary servers about
zone changes.
<screen><![CDATA[
Format: <ip> <key-name | NOKEY>

<ip> a plain IPv4/IPv6 address with on optional port number (ip@port)

<key-name | NOKEY>
* <key-name> sign notifies with the specified key
* NOKEY      don't sign notifies
]]></screen>

services.nsd.zones.<name>.notifyRetry.description: Specifies the number of retries for failed notifies. Set this along with notify.

services.nsd.zones.<name>.outgoingInterf.description:
This address will be used for zone-transfere requests if configured
as a secondary server or notifications in case of a primary server.
Supply either a plain IPv4 or IPv6 address with an optional port
number (ip@port).

services.nsd.zones.<name>.provideXFR.description:
Allow these IPs and TSIG to transfer zones, addr TSIG|NOKEY|BLOCKED
address range 192.0.2.0/24, 1.2.3.4&255.255.0.0, 3.0.2.20-3.0.2.40

services.nsd.zones.<name>.zoneStats.description:
When set to something distinct to null NSD is able to collect
statistics per zone. All statistics of this zone(s) will be added
to the group specified by this given name. Use "%s" to use the zones
name as the group. The groups are output from nsd-control stats
and stats_noreset.

services.ntopng.configText.description:
Overridable configuration file contents to use for ntopng. By
default, use the contents automatically generated by NixOS.

services.ntopng.enable.description:
Enable ntopng, a high-speed web-based traffic analysis and flow
collection tool.

With the default configuration, ntopng monitors all network
interfaces and displays its findings at http://localhost:3000. Default username and password is admin/admin.

See the ntopng(8) manual page and http://www.ntop.org/products/ntop/
for more info.

Note that enabling ntopng will also enable redis (key-value
database server) for persistent data storage.

services.ntopng.extraConfig.description:
Configuration lines that will be appended to the generated ntopng
configuration file. Note that this mechanism does not work when the
manual <option>configText</option> option is used.

services.ntopng.http-port.description: Sets the HTTP port of the embedded web server.

services.ntopng.interfaces.description: List of interfaces to monitor. Use "any" to monitor all interfaces.

services.ntp.enable.description:
Whether to synchronise your machine's time using ntpd, as a peer in
the NTP network.
</para>
<para>
Disables <literal>systemd.timesyncd</literal> if enabled.

services.ntp.extraFlags.description: Extra flags passed to the ntpd command.

services.ntp.restrictDefault.description:
The restriction flags to be set by default.
</para>
<para>
The default flags prevent external hosts from using ntpd as a DDoS
reflector, setting system time, and querying OS/ntpd version. As
recommended in section 6.5.1.1.3, answer "No" of
http://support.ntp.org/bin/view/Support/AccessRestrictions

services.ntp.restrictSource.description:
The restriction flags to be set on source.
</para>
<para>
The default flags allow peers to be added by ntpd from configured
pool(s), but not by other means.

services.ntp.servers.description: The set of NTP servers from which to synchronise.

services.nullidentdmod.enable.description: Whether to enable the nullidentdmod identd daemon.

services.nullidentdmod.userid.description: User ID to return. Set to null to return a random string each time.

services.nullmailer.config.adminaddr.description:
If set, all recipients to users at either "localhost" (the literal string)
or the canonical host name (from the me control attribute) are remapped to this address.
This is provided to allow local daemons to be able to send email to
"somebody@localhost" and have it go somewhere sensible instead of being  bounced
by your relay host. To send to multiple addresses,
put them all on one line separated by a comma.

services.nullmailer.config.allmailfrom.description: If set, content will override the envelope sender on all messages.

services.nullmailer.config.defaultdomain.description:
The content of this attribute is appended to any host name that
does not contain a period (except localhost), including defaulthost
and idhost. Defaults to the value of the me attribute, if it exists,
otherwise the literal name defauldomain.

services.nullmailer.config.defaulthost.description:
The content of this attribute is appended to any address that
is missing a host name. Defaults to the value of the me control
attribute, if it exists, otherwise the literal name defaulthost.

services.nullmailer.config.doublebouncet.description:
If the original sender was empty (the original message was a
delivery status or disposition notification), the double bounce
is sent to the address in this attribute.

services.nullmailer.config.helohost.description:
Sets  the  environment variable $HELOHOST which is used by the
SMTP protocol module to set the parameter given to the HELO command.
Defaults to the value of the me configuration attribute.

services.nullmailer.config.idhost.description:
The content of this attribute is used when building the message-id
string for the message. Defaults to the canonicalized value of defaulthost.

services.nullmailer.config.maxpause.description:
The maximum time to pause between successive queue runs, in seconds.
Defaults to 24 hours (86400).

services.nullmailer.config.me.description:
The fully-qualifiled host name of the computer running nullmailer.
Defaults to the literal name me.

services.nullmailer.config.pausetime.description:
The minimum time to pause between successive queue runs when there
are messages in the queue, in seconds. Defaults to 1 minute (60).
Each time this timeout is reached, the timeout is doubled to a
maximum of maxpause. After new messages are injected, the timeout
is reset.  If this is set to 0, nullmailer-send will exit
immediately after going through the queue once (one-shot mode).

services.nullmailer.config.remotes.description: A list of remote servers to which to send each message. Each line contains a remote host name or address followed by an optional protocol string, separated by white space. See man 8 nullmailer-send for syntax and available options. WARNING: This is stored world-readable in the nix store. If you need to specify any secret credentials here, consider using the remotesFile option instead.

services.nullmailer.config.sendtimeout.description:
The  time to wait for a remote module listed above to complete sending
a message before killing it and trying again, in seconds.
Defaults to 1 hour (3600).  If this is set to 0, nullmailer-send
will wait forever for messages to complete sending.

services.nullmailer.group.description: Group to use to run nullmailer-send.

services.nullmailer.remotesFile.description: Path to the remotes control file. This file contains a list of remote servers to which to send each message. See man 8 nullmailer-send for syntax and available options.

services.nullmailer.setSendmail.description: Whether to set the system sendmail to nullmailer's.

services.nullmailer.user.description: User to use to run nullmailer-send.

services.nylon.<name?>.acceptInterface.description: Tell nylon which interface to listen for client requests on, default is "lo".

services.nylon.<name?>.allowedIPRanges.description:
Allowed client IP ranges are evaluated first, defaults to ARIN IPv4 private ranges:
  [ "192.168.0.0/16" "127.0.0.0/8" "172.16.0.0/12" "10.0.0.0/8" ]

services.nylon.<name?>.bindInterface.description: Tell nylon which interface to use as an uplink, default is "enp3s0f0".

services.nylon.<name?>.deniedIPRanges.description:
Denied client IP ranges, these gets evaluated after the allowed IP ranges, defaults to all IPv4 addresses:
  [ "0.0.0.0/0" ]
To block all other access than the allowed.

services.nylon.<name?>.enable.description: Enables nylon as a running service upon activation.

services.nylon.<name?>.logging.description: Enable logging, default is no logging.

services.nylon.<name?>.name.description: The name of this nylon instance.

services.nylon.<name?>.nrConnections.description: The number of allowed simultaneous connections to the daemon, default 10.

services.nylon.<name?>.port.description: What port to listen for client requests, default is 1080.

services.nylon.<name?>.verbosity.description: Enable verbose output, default is to not be verbose.

services.nzbget.user.description: User account under which NZBGet runs

services.oauth2_proxy.azure.tenant.description: Go to a tenant-specific or common (tenant-independent) endpoint.

services.oauth2_proxy.basicAuthPassword.description: The password to set when passing the HTTP Basic Auth header.

services.oauth2_proxy.cookie.domain.description: An optional cookie domain to force cookies to.

services.oauth2_proxy.cookie.name.description: The name of the cookie that the oauth_proxy creates.

services.oauth2_proxy.cookie.refresh.description: Refresh the cookie after this duration; 0 to disable.

services.oauth2_proxy.cookie.secret.description: The seed string for secure cookies.

services.oauth2_proxy.email.addresses.description: Line-separated email addresses that are allowed to authenticate.

services.oauth2_proxy.email.domains.description:
Authenticate emails with the specified domains. Use
<literal>*</literal> to authenticate any email.

services.oauth2_proxy.extraConfig.description: Extra config to pass to oauth2_proxy.

services.oauth2_proxy.github.org.description: Restrict logins to members of this organisation.

services.oauth2_proxy.github.team.description: Restrict logins to members of this team.

services.oauth2_proxy.google.adminEmail.description:
The Google Admin to impersonate for API calls.

Only users with access to the Admin APIs can access the Admin SDK
Directory API, thus the service account needs to impersonate one of
those users to access the Admin SDK Directory API.

See <link xlink:href="https://developers.google.com/admin-sdk/directory/v1/guides/delegation#delegate_domain-wide_authority_to_your_service_account" />.

services.oauth2_proxy.google.groups.description: Restrict logins to members of these Google groups.

services.oauth2_proxy.google.serviceAcco.description: The path to the service account JSON credentials.

services.oauth2_proxy.htpasswd.displayFo.description: Display username / password login form if an htpasswd file is provided.

services.oauth2_proxy.htpasswd.file.description:
Additionally authenticate against a htpasswd file. Entries must be
created with <literal>htpasswd -s</literal> for SHA encryption.

services.oauth2_proxy.httpAddress.description:
HTTPS listening address.  This module does not expose the port by
default. If you want this URL to be accessible to other machines, please
add the port to <literal>networking.firewall.allowedTCPPorts</literal>.

services.oauth2_proxy.keyFile.description:
oauth2_proxy allows passing sensitive configuration via environment variables.
Make a file that contains lines like
OAUTH2_PROXY_CLIENT_SECRET=asdfasdfasdf.apps.googleuserscontent.com
and specify the path here.

services.oauth2_proxy.loginURL.description:
Authentication endpoint.

You only need to set this if you are using a self-hosted provider (e.g.
Github Enterprise). If you're using a publicly hosted provider
(e.g github.com), then the default works.

services.oauth2_proxy.nginx.proxy.description: The address of the reverse proxy endpoint for oauth2_proxy

services.oauth2_proxy.nginx.virtualHosts.description: A list of nginx virtual hosts to put behind the oauth2 proxy

services.oauth2_proxy.passAccessToken.description: Pass OAuth access_token to upstream via X-Forwarded-Access-Token header.

services.oauth2_proxy.passBasicAuth.description: Pass HTTP Basic Auth, X-Forwarded-User and X-Forwarded-Email information to upstream.

services.oauth2_proxy.passHostHeader.description: Pass the request Host Header to upstream.

services.oauth2_proxy.proxyPrefix.description: The url root path that this proxy should be nested under.

services.oauth2_proxy.redeemURL.description:
Token redemption endpoint.

You only need to set this if you are using a self-hosted provider (e.g.
Github Enterprise). If you're using a publicly hosted provider
(e.g github.com), then the default works.

services.oauth2_proxy.setXauthrequest.description: Set X-Auth-Request-User and X-Auth-Request-Email response headers (useful in Nginx auth_request mode). Setting this to 'null' means using the upstream default (false).

services.oauth2_proxy.skipAuthRegexes.description:
Skip authentication for requests matching any of these regular
expressions.

services.oauth2_proxy.tls.httpsAddress.description:
<literal>addr:port</literal> to listen on for HTTPS clients.

Remember to add <literal>port</literal> to
<literal>allowedTCPPorts</literal> if you want other machines to be
able to connect to it.

services.oauth2_proxy.upstream.description:
The http url(s) of the upstream endpoint or <literal>file://</literal>
paths for static files. Routing is based on the path.
services.oauth2_proxy.upstream.type: list of strings or string convertible to it

services.oauth2_proxy.validateURL.description:
Access token validation endpoint.

You only need to set this if you are using a self-hosted provider (e.g.
Github Enterprise). If you're using a publicly hosted provider
(e.g github.com), then the default works.

services.ocserv.config.description:
Configuration content to start an OCServ server.

For a full configuration reference,please refer to the online documentation
(https://ocserv.gitlab.io/www/manual.html), the openconnect
recipes (https://github.com/openconnect/recipes) or `man ocserv`.
services.ocserv.config.example:
# configuration examples from $out/doc without explanatory comments.
# for a full reference please look at the installed man pages.
auth = "plain[passwd=./sample.passwd]"
tcp-port = 443
udp-port = 443
run-as-user = nobody
run-as-group = nogroup
socket-file = /run/ocserv-socket
server-cert = certs/server-cert.pem
server-key = certs/server-key.pem
keepalive = 32400
dpd = 90
mobile-dpd = 1800
switch-to-tcp-timeout = 25
try-mtu-discovery = false
cert-user-oid = 0.9.2342.19200300.100.1.1
tls-priorities = "NORMAL:%SERVER_PRECEDENCE:%COMPAT:-VERS-SSL3.0"
auth-timeout = 240
min-reauth-time = 300
max-ban-score = 80
ban-reset-time = 1200
cookie-timeout = 300
deny-roaming = false
rekey-time = 172800
rekey-method = ssl
use-occtl = true
pid-file = /run/ocserv.pid
device = vpns
predictable-ips = true
default-domain = example.com
ipv4-network = 192.168.1.0
ipv4-netmask = 255.255.255.0
dns = 192.168.1.2
ping-leases = false
route = 10.10.10.0/255.255.255.0
route = 192.168.0.0/255.255.0.0
no-route = 192.168.5.0/255.255.255.0
cisco-client-compat = true
dtls-legacy = true

[vhost:www.example.com]
auth = "certificate"
ca-cert = certs/ca.pem
server-cert = certs/server-cert-secp521r1.pem
server-key = cersts/certs/server-key-secp521r1.pem
ipv4-network = 192.168.2.0
ipv4-netmask = 255.255.255.0
cert-user-oid = 0.9.2342.19200300.100.1.1

services.octoprint.enable.description: Whether to enable OctoPrint, web interface for 3D printers.

services.octoprint.extraConfig.description: Extra options which are added to OctoPrint's YAML configuration file.

services.offlineimap.enable.description: Whether to enable OfflineIMAP, a software to dispose your mailbox(es) as a local Maildir(s).

services.offlineimap.install.description:
Whether to install a user service for Offlineimap. Once
the service is started, emails will be fetched automatically.

The service must be manually started for each user with
"systemctl --user start offlineimap" or globally through
<varname>services.offlineimap.enable</varname>.

services.offlineimap.onCalendar.description: How often is offlineimap started. Default is '*:0/3' meaning every 3 minutes. See systemd.time(7) for more information about the format.

services.offlineimap.path.description: List of derivations to put in Offlineimap's path.

services.offlineimap.timeoutStartSec.description: How long waiting for offlineimap before killing it. Default is '120sec' meaning every 2 minutes. See systemd.time(7) for more information about the format.

services.ofono.plugins.description: The list of plugins to install.

services.oidentd.enable.description:
Whether to enable oidentd, an implementation of the Ident
protocol (RFC 1413).  It allows remote systems to identify the
name of the user associated with a TCP connection.

services.openafsClient.afsdb.description: Resolve cells via AFSDB DNS records.

services.openafsClient.cache.chunksize.description:
Size of each cache chunk given in powers of
2. <literal>0</literal> resets the chunk size to its default
values (13 (8 KB) for memcache, 18-20 (256 KB to 1 MB) for
diskcache). Maximum value is 30. Important performance
parameter. Set to higher values when dealing with large files.

services.openafsClient.cache.diskless.description:
Use in-memory cache for diskless machines. Has no real
performance benefit anymore.

services.openafsClient.cellServDB.description:
This cell's database server records, added to the global
CellServDB. See CellServDB(5) man page for syntax. Ignored when
<literal>afsdb</literal> is set to <literal>true</literal>.

services.openafsClient.cellServDB.*.dnsn.description: DNS full-qualified domain name of a database server

services.openafsClient.cellServDB.*.ip.description: IP Address of a database server

services.openafsClient.daemons.description:
Number of daemons to serve user requests. Numbers higher than 6
usually do no increase performance. Default is sufficient for up
to five concurrent users.

services.openafsClient.enable.description: Whether to enable the OpenAFS client.

services.openafsClient.fakestat.description:
Return fake data on stat() calls. If <literal>true</literal>,
always do so. If <literal>false</literal>, only do so for
cross-cell mounts (as these are potentially expensive).

services.openafsClient.inumcalc.description:
Inode calculation method. <literal>compat</literal> is
computationally less expensive, but <literal>md5</literal> greatly
reduces the likelihood of inode collisions in larger scenarios
involving multiple cells mounted into one AFS space.

services.openafsClient.mountPoint.description:
Mountpoint of the AFS file tree, conventionally
<literal>/afs</literal>. When set to a different value, only
cross-cells that use the same value can be accessed.

services.openafsClient.packages.module.description: OpenAFS kernel module package. MUST match the userland package!

services.openafsClient.packages.programs.description: OpenAFS programs package. MUST match the kernel module package!

services.openafsClient.startDisconnected.description:
Start up in disconnected mode.  You need to execute
<literal>fs disco online</literal> (as root) to switch to
connected mode. Useful for roaming devices.

services.openafsServer.advertisedAddress.description: List of IP addresses this server is advertised under. See NetInfo(5)

services.openafsServer.cellName.description: Cell name, this server will serve.

services.openafsServer.cellServDB.description: Definition of all cell-local database server machines.

services.openafsServer.cellServDB.*.dnsn.description: DNS full-qualified domain name of a database server

services.openafsServer.cellServDB.*.ip.description: IP Address of a database server

services.openafsServer.dottedPrincipals.description:
If enabled, allow principal names containing (.) dots. Enabling
this has security implications!

services.openafsServer.enable.description:
Whether to enable the OpenAFS server. An OpenAFS server needs a
complex setup. So, be aware that enabling this service and setting
some options does not give you a turn-key-ready solution. You need
at least a running Kerberos 5 setup, as OpenAFS relies on it for
authentication. See the Guide "QuickStartUnix" coming with
<literal>pkgs.openafs.doc</literal> for complete setup
instructions.

services.openafsServer.package.description: OpenAFS package for the server binaries

services.openafsServer.roles.backup.buse.description: Arguments to the buserver process. See its man page.

services.openafsServer.roles.backup.cell.description:
Definition of all cell-local backup database server machines.
Use this when your cell uses less backup database servers than
other database server machines.
DNS full-qualified domain name of a database server
IP Address of a database server

services.openafsServer.roles.backup.enab.description:
Backup server role. Use in conjunction with the
<literal>database</literal> role to maintain the Backup
Database. Normally only used in conjunction with tape storage
or IBM's Tivoli Storage Manager.

services.openafsServer.roles.database.en.description:
Database server role, maintains the Volume Location Database,
Protection Database (and Backup Database, see
<literal>backup</literal> role). There can be multiple
servers in the database role for replication, which then need
reliable network connection to each other.

Servers in this role appear in AFSDB DNS records or the
CellServDB.

services.openafsServer.roles.database.pt.description: Arguments to the ptserver process. See its man page.

services.openafsServer.roles.database.vl.description: Arguments to the vlserver process. See its man page.

services.openafsServer.roles.fileserver..description: Fileserver role, serves files and volumes from its local storage.
Arguments to the dafileserver process. See its man page.
Arguments to the dasalvager process. See its man page.
Arguments to the salvageserver process. See its man page.
Arguments to the davolserver process. See its man page.

services.openafsServer.udpPacketSize.description:
UDP packet size to use in Bytes. Higher values can speed up
communications. The default of 1 MB is a sufficient in most
cases. Make sure to increase the kernel's UDP buffer size
accordingly via <literal>net.core(w|r|opt)mem_max</literal>
sysctl.

services.opendkim.domains.description:
Local domains set (see <literal>opendkim(8)</literal> for more information on datasets).
Messages from them are signed, not verified.

services.opendkim.enable.description: Whether to enable the OpenDKIM sender authentication system.

services.opendkim.keyPath.description:
The path that opendkim should put its generated private keys into.
The DNS settings will be found in this directory with the name selector.txt.

services.opendkim.socket.description: Socket which is used for communication with OpenDKIM.

services.openfire.enable.description: Whether to enable OpenFire XMPP server.

services.openfire.usePostgreSQL.description: Whether you use PostgreSQL service for your storage back-end.

services.openldap.configDir.description: Use this optional config directory instead of using slapd.conf

services.openldap.database.description:
Database type to use for the LDAP.
This setting will be ignored if configDir is set.

services.openldap.declarativeContents.description: Declarative contents for the LDAP database, in LDIF format. Note a few facts when using it. First, the database must be stored in the directory defined by dataDir. Second, all dataDir will be erased when starting the LDAP server. Third, modifications to the database are not prevented, they are just dropped on the next reboot of the server. Finally, performance-wise the database and indexes are rebuilt on each server startup, so this will slow down server startup, especially with large databases.
services.openldap.declarativeContents.example:
dn: dc=example,dc=org
objectClass: domain
dc: example

dn: ou=users,dc=example,dc=org
objectClass = organizationalUnit
ou: users

# ...

services.openldap.defaultSchemas.description:
Include the default schemas core, cosine, inetorgperson and nis.
This setting will be ignored if configDir is set.

services.openldap.enable.description: Whether to enable the ldap server.

example.text:
''
include ${pkgs.openldap.out}/etc/schema/core.schema
include ${pkgs.openldap.out}/etc/schema/cosine.schema
include ${pkgs.openldap.out}/etc/schema/inetorgperson.schema
include ${pkgs.openldap.out}/etc/schema/nis.schema

database bdb
suffix dc=example,dc=org
rootdn cn=admin,dc=example,dc=org
# NOTE: change after first start
rootpw secret
directory /var/db/openldap
''

services.openldap.extraDatabaseConfig.description:
slapd.conf configuration after the database option.
This setting will be ignored if configDir is set.
services.openldap.extraDatabaseConfig.example:
# Indices to maintain for this directory
# unique id so equality match only
index uid eq
# allows general searching on commonname, givenname and email
index cn,gn,mail eq,sub
# allows multiple variants on surname searching
index sn eq,sub
# sub above includes subintial,subany,subfinal
# optimise department searches
index ou eq
# if searches will include objectClass uncomment following
# index objectClass eq
# shows use of default index parameter
index default eq,sub
# indices missing - uses default eq,sub
index telephonenumber

# other database parameters
# read more in slapd.conf reference section
cachesize 10000
checkpoint 128 15

services.openldap.group.description: Group account under which slapd runs.

services.openldap.logLevel.description: The log level selector of slapd.

services.openldap.rootdn.description:
Specify the distinguished name that is not subject to access control
or administrative limit restrictions for operations on this database.
This setting will be ignored if configDir is set.

services.openldap.rootpw.description:
Password for the root user.
This setting will be ignored if configDir is set.
Using this option will store the root password in plain text in the
world-readable nix store. To avoid this the <literal>rootpwFile</literal> can be used.

services.openldap.rootpwFile.description:
Password file for the root user.
The file should contain the string <literal>rootpw</literal> followed by the password.
e.g.: <literal>rootpw mysecurepassword</literal>

services.openldap.suffix.description:
Specify the DN suffix of queries that will be passed to this backend
database.
This setting will be ignored if configDir is set.

services.openldap.urlList.description: URL list slapd should listen on.

services.openldap.user.description: User account under which slapd runs.

services.openntpd.enable.description: Whether to enable OpenNTP time synchronization server.

services.openntpd.extraOptions.description: Extra options used when launching openntpd.

services.openntpd.servers.description: The set of NTP servers from which to synchronise.

services.opensmtpd.addSendmailToSystemPa.description:
Whether to add OpenSMTPD's sendmail binary to the
system path or not.

services.opensmtpd.enable.description: Whether to enable the OpenSMTPD server.

services.opensmtpd.extraServerArgs.description:
Extra command line arguments provided when the smtpd process
is started.

services.opensmtpd.procPackages.description:
Packages to search for filters, tables, queues, and schedulers.

Add OpenSMTPD-extras here if you want to use the filters, etc. from
that package.

services.opensmtpd.serverConfiguration.description:
The contents of the smtpd.conf configuration file. See the
OpenSMTPD documentation for syntax information.
services.opensmtpd.serverConfiguration.example:
listen on lo
accept for any deliver to lmtp localhost:24

services.openssh.allowSFTP.description:
Whether to enable the SFTP subsystem in the SSH daemon.  This
enables the use of commands such as <command>sftp</command> and
<command>sshfs</command>.

services.openssh.authorizedKeysFiles.description: Files from which authorized keys are read.

services.openssh.challengeResponseAuthen.description: Specifies whether challenge/response authentication is allowed.

services.openssh.ciphers.description:
Allowed ciphers
</para>
<para>
Defaults to recommended settings from both
<link xlink:href="https://stribika.github.io/2015/01/04/secure-secure-shell.html" />
and
<link xlink:href="https://wiki.mozilla.org/Security/Guidelines/OpenSSH#Modern_.28OpenSSH_6.7.2B.29" />

services.openssh.enable.description:
Whether to enable the OpenSSH secure shell daemon, which
allows secure remote logins.

services.openssh.forwardX11.description: Whether to allow X11 connections to be forwarded.

services.openssh.gatewayPorts.description:
Specifies whether remote hosts are allowed to connect to
ports forwarded for the client.  See
<citerefentry><refentrytitle>sshd_config</refentrytitle>
<manvolnum>5</manvolnum></citerefentry>.

services.openssh.hostKeys.description:
NixOS can automatically generate SSH host keys.  This option
specifies the path, type and size of each key.  See
<citerefentry><refentrytitle>ssh-keygen</refentrytitle>
<manvolnum>1</manvolnum></citerefentry> for supported types
and sizes.

services.openssh.kexAlgorithms.description:
Allowed key exchange algorithms
</para>
<para>
Defaults to recommended settings from both
<link xlink:href="https://stribika.github.io/2015/01/04/secure-secure-shell.html" />
and
<link xlink:href="https://wiki.mozilla.org/Security/Guidelines/OpenSSH#Modern_.28OpenSSH_6.7.2B.29" />

services.openssh.listenAddresses.description:
List of addresses and ports to listen on (ListenAddress directive
in config). If port is not specified for address sshd will listen
on all ports specified by <literal>ports</literal> option.
NOTE: this will override default listening on all local addresses and port 22.
NOTE: setting this option won't automatically enable given ports
in firewall configuration.

services.openssh.listenAddresses.*.addr.description: Host, IPv4 or IPv6 address to listen to.

services.openssh.logLevel.description:
Gives the verbosity level that is used when logging messages from sshd(8). The possible values are:
QUIET, FATAL, ERROR, INFO, VERBOSE, DEBUG, DEBUG1, DEBUG2, and DEBUG3. The default is VERBOSE. DEBUG and DEBUG1
are equivalent. DEBUG2 and DEBUG3 each specify higher levels of debugging output. Logging with a DEBUG level
violates the privacy of users and is not recommended.

LogLevel VERBOSE logs user's key fingerprint on login.
Needed to have a clear audit track of which key was used to log in.

services.openssh.macs.description:
Allowed MACs
</para>
<para>
Defaults to recommended settings from both
<link xlink:href="https://stribika.github.io/2015/01/04/secure-secure-shell.html" />
and
<link xlink:href="https://wiki.mozilla.org/Security/Guidelines/OpenSSH#Modern_.28OpenSSH_6.7.2B.29" />

services.openssh.moduliFile.description:
Path to <literal>moduli</literal> file to install in
<literal>/etc/ssh/moduli</literal>. If this option is unset, then
the <literal>moduli</literal> file shipped with OpenSSH will be used.

services.openssh.openFirewall.description: Whether to automatically open the specified ports in the firewall.

services.openssh.passwordAuthentication.description: Specifies whether password authentication is allowed.

services.openssh.permitRootLogin.description: Whether the root user can login using ssh.

services.openssh.ports.description: Specifies on which ports the SSH daemon listens.
services.openssh.ports.type: list of 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)s

services.openssh.sftpFlags.description: Commandline flags to add to sftp-server.

services.openssh.startWhenNeeded.description:
If set, <command>sshd</command> is socket-activated; that
is, instead of having it permanently running as a daemon,
systemd will start an instance for each incoming connection.

services.openssh.useDns.description:
Specifies whether sshd(8) should look up the remote host name, and to check that the resolved host name for
the remote IP address maps back to the very same IP address.
If this option is set to no (the default) then only addresses and not host names may be used in
~/.ssh/authorized_keys from and sshd_config Match Host directives.

services.opentracker.extraOptions.description:
Configuration Arguments for opentracker
See https://erdgeist.org/arts/software/opentracker/ for all params

services.opentsdb.config.description: The contents of OpenTSDB's configuration file

services.opentsdb.group.description: Group account under which OpenTSDB runs.

services.opentsdb.user.description: User account under which OpenTSDB runs.

services.openvpn.servers.description:
Each attribute of this option defines a systemd service that
runs an OpenVPN instance.  These can be OpenVPN servers or
clients.  The name of each systemd service is
<literal>openvpn-<replaceable>name</replaceable>.service</literal>,
where <replaceable>name</replaceable> is the corresponding
attribute name.

services.openvpn.servers.<name>.authUser.description:
This option can be used to store the username / password credentials
with the "auth-user-pass" authentication method.

WARNING: Using this option will put the credentials WORLD-READABLE in the Nix store!
The password to store inside the credentials file.
The username to store inside the credentials file.

services.openvpn.servers.<name>.autoStar.description: Whether this OpenVPN instance should be started automatically.

services.openvpn.servers.<name>.config.description:
Configuration of this OpenVPN instance.  See
<citerefentry><refentrytitle>openvpn</refentrytitle><manvolnum>8</manvolnum></citerefentry>
for details.

To import an external config file, use the following definition:
<literal>config = "config /path/to/config.ovpn"</literal>

services.openvpn.servers.<name>.down.description: Shell commands executed when the instance is shutting down.

services.openvpn.servers.<name>.up.description: Shell commands executed when the instance is starting.

services.openvpn.servers.<name>.updateRe.description:
Use the script from the update-resolv-conf package to automatically
update resolv.conf with the DNS information provided by openvpn. The
script will be run after the "up" commands and before the "down" commands.

services.osquery.extraConfig.description: Extra config to be recursively merged into the JSON config file.

services.osquery.utc.description: Attempt to convert all UNIX calendar times to UTC.

services.osrm.address.description: IP address on which the web server will listen.

services.osrm.algorithm.description: Algorithm to use for the data. Must be one of CH, CoreCH, MLD

services.osrm.extraFlags.description: Extra command line arguments passed to osrm-routed

services.osrm.port.description: Port on which the web server will run.

services.ostinato.portList.exclude.description: A list of ports does not appear on the port list managed by drone.

services.ostinato.portList.include.description:
For a port to pass the filter and appear on the port list managed
by drone, it be allowed by this include list.

services.ostinato.rateAccuracy.description:
To ensure that the actual transmit rate is as close as possible to
the configured transmit rate, Drone runs a busy-wait loop.
While this provides the maximum accuracy possible, the CPU
utilization is 100% while the transmit is on. You can however,
sacrifice the accuracy to reduce the CPU load.

services.ostinato.rpcServer.address.description:
By default, the Drone RPC server will listen on all interfaces and
local IPv4 adresses for incoming connections from clients.  Specify
a single IPv4 or IPv6 address if you want to restrict that.
To listen on any IPv6 address, use ::

services.owamp.enable.description: Whether to enable Enable OWAMP server.

services.oxidized.configFile.description: Path to the oxidized configuration file.

example.text:
pkgs.writeText "oxidized-config.yml" ''
  ---
  debug: true
  use_syslog: true
  input:
    default: ssh
    ssh:
      secure: true
  interval: 3600
  model_map:
    dell: powerconnect
    hp: procurve
  source:
    default: csv
    csv:
      delimiter: !ruby/regexp /:/
      file: "/var/lib/oxidized/.config/oxidized/router.db"
      map:
        name: 0
        model: 1
        username: 2
        password: 3
  pid: "/var/lib/oxidized/.config/oxidized/pid"
  rest: 127.0.0.1:8888
  retries: 3
  # ... additional config
'';

services.oxidized.dataDir.description: State directory for the oxidized service.

services.oxidized.enable.description: Whether to enable the oxidized configuration backup service.

services.oxidized.group.description: Group under which the oxidized service runs.

services.oxidized.routerDB.description: Path to the file/database which contains the targets for oxidized.

services.oxidized.user.description: User under which the oxidized service runs.

services.packagekit.backend.description:
PackageKit supports multiple different backends and <literal>auto</literal> which
should do the right thing.
</para>
<para>
On NixOS however, we do not have a backend compatible with nix 2.0
(refer to <link xlink:href="https://github.com/NixOS/nix/issues/233">this issue</link> so we have to force
it to <literal>test_nop</literal> for now.

services.packagekit.enable.description:
Whether to enable PackageKit provides a cross-platform D-Bus abstraction layer for
installing software. Software utilizing PackageKit can install
software regardless of the package manager.
.

services.pantheon.contractor.enable.description: Whether to enable contractor, a desktop-wide extension service used by pantheon.

services.pantheon.files.enable.description: Whether to enable pantheon files daemon.

services.paperless.consumptionDir.description: Directory from which new documents are imported.

services.paperless.consumptionDirIsPubli.description: Whether all users can write to the consumption dir.

services.paperless.dataDir.description: Directory to store the Paperless data.

services.paperless.enable.description:
Enable Paperless.

When started, the Paperless database is automatically created if it doesn't
exist and updated if the Paperless package has changed.
Both tasks are achieved by running a Django migration.

services.paperless.extraConfig.description:
Extra paperless config options.

The config values are evaluated as double-quoted Bash string literals.

See <literal>paperless-src/paperless.conf.example</literal> for available options.

To enable user authentication, set <literal>PAPERLESS_DISABLE_LOGIN = "false"</literal>
and run the shell command <literal>$dataDir/paperless-manage createsuperuser</literal>.

To define secret options without storing them in /nix/store, use the following pattern:
<literal>PAPERLESS_PASSPHRASE = "$(< /etc/my_passphrase_file)"</literal>

services.paperless.manage.description:
A script to manage the Paperless instance.
It wraps Django's manage.py and is also available at
<literal>$dataDir/manage-paperless</literal>

services.paperless.ocrLanguages.description:
Languages available for OCR via Tesseract, specified as
<literal>ISO 639-2/T</literal> language codes.
If unset, defaults to all available languages.

services.parsoid.enable.description:
Whether to enable Parsoid -- bidirectional
wikitext parser.

services.parsoid.extraConfig.description: Extra configuration to add to parsoid configuration.

services.parsoid.wikis.type: list of string or attribute sets

services.pcscd.plugins.description: Plugin packages to be used for PCSC-Lite.

services.pcscd.readerConfig.description:
Configuration for devices that aren't hotpluggable.

See <citerefentry><refentrytitle>reader.conf</refentrytitle>
<manvolnum>5</manvolnum></citerefentry> for valid options.
services.pcscd.readerConfig.example:
FRIENDLYNAME      "Some serial reader"
DEVICENAME        /dev/ttyS0
LIBPATH           /path/to/serial_reader.so
CHANNELID         1

services.pdns-recursor.api.address.description: IP address Recursor REST API server will bind to.

services.pdns-recursor.api.allowFrom.description: IP address ranges of clients allowed to make API requests.

services.pdns-recursor.api.port.description: Port number Recursor REST API server will bind to.

services.pdns-recursor.dns.address.description: IP address Recursor DNS server will bind to.

services.pdns-recursor.dns.allowFrom.description: IP address ranges of clients allowed to make DNS queries.

services.pdns-recursor.dns.port.description: Port number Recursor DNS server will bind to.

services.pdns-recursor.dnssecValidation.description:
Controls the level of DNSSEC processing done by the PowerDNS Recursor.
See https://doc.powerdns.com/md/recursor/dnssec/ for a detailed explanation.

services.pdns-recursor.enable.description: Whether to enable PowerDNS Recursor, a recursive DNS server.

services.pdns-recursor.exportHosts.description: Whether to export names and IP addresses defined in /etc/hosts.

services.pdns-recursor.forwardZones.description: DNS zones to be forwarded to other authoritative servers.

services.pdns-recursor.forwardZonesRecur.description: DNS zones to be forwarded to other recursive servers.

services.pdns-recursor.luaConfig.description:
The content Lua configuration file for PowerDNS Recursor. See
<link xlink:href="https://doc.powerdns.com/recursor/lua-config/index.html"/>.

services.pdns-recursor.resolveDNSChainQu.description: Resolve <literal>.bit</literal> top-level domains using DNSChain and namecoin.

services.pdns-recursor.serveRFC1918.description:
Whether to directly resolve the RFC1918 reverse-mapping domains:
<literal>10.in-addr.arpa</literal>,
<literal>168.192.in-addr.arpa</literal>,
<literal>16-31.172.in-addr.arpa</literal>
This saves load on the AS112 servers.

services.pdns-recursor.settings.description:
PowerDNS Recursor settings. Use this option to configure Recursor
settings not exposed in a NixOS option or to bypass one.
See the full documentation at
<link xlink:href="https://doc.powerdns.com/recursor/settings.html"/>
for the available options.
services.pdns-recursor.settings.type: attribute set of null or signed integer or string or boolean or path or list of signed integer or string or boolean or pathss

services.pdnsd.extraConfig.description:
Extra configuration directives that should be added to
<literal>pdnsd.conf</literal>.

services.pdnsd.globalConfig.description:
Global configuration that should be added to the global directory
of <literal>pdnsd.conf</literal>.

services.pdnsd.serverConfig.description:
Server configuration that should be added to the server directory
of <literal>pdnsd.conf</literal>.

services.pfix-srsd.domain.description: The domain for which to enable srs

services.pfix-srsd.enable.description: Whether to run the postfix sender rewriting scheme daemon.

services.pfix-srsd.secretsFile.description:
The secret data used to encode the SRS address.
to generate, use a command like:
<literal>for n in $(seq 5); do dd if=/dev/urandom count=1 bs=1024 status=none | sha256sum | sed 's/  -$//' | sed 's/^/          /'; done</literal>

services.pgmanage.allowCustomConnections.description:
This tells pgmanage whether or not to allow anyone to use a custom
connection from the login screen.

services.pgmanage.connections.description:
pgmanage requires at least one PostgreSQL server be defined.
</para><para>
Detailed information about PostgreSQL connection strings is available at:
<link xlink:href="http://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/libpq-connect.html"/>
</para><para>
Note that you should not specify your user name or password. That
information will be entered on the login screen. If you specify a
username or password, it will be removed by pgmanage before attempting to
connect to a database.

services.pgmanage.enable.description: Whether to enable PostgreSQL Administration for the web.

services.pgmanage.localOnly.description:
This tells pgmanage whether or not to set the listening socket to local
addresses only.

services.pgmanage.loginGroup.description:
This tells pgmanage to only allow users in a certain PostgreSQL group to
login to pgmanage. Note that a connection will be made to PostgreSQL in
order to test if the user is a member of the login group.

services.pgmanage.loginTimeout.description:
Number of seconds of inactivity before user is automatically logged
out.

services.pgmanage.port.description: This tells pgmanage what port to listen on for browser requests.

services.pgmanage.sqlRoot.description:
This tells pgmanage where to put the SQL file history. All tabs are saved
to this location so that if you get disconnected from pgmanage you
don't lose your work.

services.pgmanage.superOnly.description:
This tells pgmanage whether or not to only allow super users to
login. The recommended value is true and will restrict users who are not
super users from logging in to any PostgreSQL instance through
pgmanage. Note that a connection will be made to PostgreSQL in order to
test if the user is a superuser.

services.pgmanage.tls.description:
These options tell pgmanage where the TLS Certificate and Key files
reside. If you use these options then you'll only be able to access
pgmanage through a secure TLS connection. These options are only
necessary if you wish to connect directly to pgmanage using a secure TLS
connection. As an alternative, you can set up pgmanage in a reverse proxy
configuration. This allows your web server to terminate the secure
connection and pass on the request to pgmanage. You can find help to set
up this configuration in:
<link xlink:href="https://github.com/pgManage/pgManage/blob/master/INSTALL_NGINX.md"/>

services.pgpkeyserver-lite.enable.description: Whether to enable pgpkeyserver-lite on a nginx vHost proxying to a gpg keyserver.

services.pgpkeyserver-lite.hkpAddress.description: Wich ip address the sks-keyserver is listening on.

services.pgpkeyserver-lite.hkpPort.description: Which port the sks-keyserver is listening on.

services.pgpkeyserver-lite.hostname.description: Which hostname to set the vHost to that is proxying to sks.

services.phpfpm.extraConfig.description:
Extra configuration that should be put in the global section of
the PHP-FPM configuration file. Do not specify the options
<literal>error_log</literal> or
<literal>daemonize</literal> here, since they are generated by
NixOS.

services.phpfpm.phpOptions.description: Options appended to the PHP configuration file <filename>php.ini</filename>.

services.phpfpm.phpPackage.description: The PHP package to use for running the PHP-FPM service.

services.phpfpm.pools.description:
PHP-FPM pools. If no pools are defined, the PHP-FPM
service is disabled.

services.phpfpm.pools.<name>.extraConfig.description:
Extra lines that go into the pool configuration.
See the documentation on <literal>php-fpm.conf</literal> for
details on configuration directives.

services.phpfpm.pools.<name>.group.description: Group account under which this pool runs.

services.phpfpm.pools.<name>.listen.description: The address on which to accept FastCGI requests.

services.phpfpm.pools.<name>.phpEnv.description: Environment variables used for this PHP-FPM pool.

services.phpfpm.pools.<name>.phpOptions.description: "Options appended to the PHP configuration file <filename>php.ini</filename> used for this PHP-FPM pool."

services.phpfpm.pools.<name>.phpPackage.description: The PHP package to use for running this PHP-FPM pool.

services.phpfpm.pools.<name>.settings.description:
