PHP-FPM pool directives. Refer to the "List of pool directives" section of
<link xlink:href="https://www.php.net/manual/en/install.fpm.configuration.php"/>
for details. Note that settings names must be enclosed in quotes (e.g.
<literal>"pm.max_children"</literal> instead of <literal>pm.max_children</literal>).
services.phpfpm.pools.<name>.settings.type: attribute set of string or signed integer or booleans

services.phpfpm.pools.<name>.socket.description:
Path to the unix socket file on which to accept FastCGI requests.
<note><para>This option is read-only and managed by NixOS.</para></note>

services.phpfpm.pools.<name>.user.description: User account under which this pool runs.

services.phpfpm.settings.description:
PHP-FPM global directives. Refer to the "List of global php-fpm.conf directives" section of
<link xlink:href="https://www.php.net/manual/en/install.fpm.configuration.php"/>
for details. Note that settings names must be enclosed in quotes (e.g.
<literal>"pm.max_children"</literal> instead of <literal>pm.max_children</literal>).
You need not specify the options <literal>error_log</literal> or
<literal>daemonize</literal> here, since they are generated by NixOS.
services.phpfpm.settings.type: attribute set of string or signed integer or booleans

services.physlock.allowAnyUser.description:
Whether to allow any user to lock the screen. This will install a
setuid wrapper to allow any user to start physlock as root, which
is a minor security risk. Call the physlock binary to use this instead
of using the systemd service.

Note that you might need to relog to have the correct binary in your
PATH upon changing this option.

services.physlock.disableSysRq.description: Whether to disable SysRq when locked with physlock.

services.physlock.enable.description:
Whether to enable the <command>physlock</command> screen locking mechanism.

Enable this and then run <command>systemctl start physlock</command>
to securely lock the screen.

This will switch to a new virtual terminal, turn off console
switching and disable SysRq mechanism (when
<option>services.physlock.disableSysRq</option> is set)
until the root or user password is given.

services.physlock.lockOn.extraTargets.description:
Other targets to lock the screen just before.

Useful if you want to e.g. both autologin to X11 so that
your <filename>~/.xsession</filename> gets executed and
still to have the screen locked so that the system can be
booted relatively unattended.

services.physlock.lockOn.hibernate.description: Whether to lock screen with physlock just before hibernate.

services.physlock.lockOn.suspend.description: Whether to lock screen with physlock just before suspend.

services.pipewire.socketActivation.description: Automatically run pipewire when connections are made to the pipewire socket.

services.plex.dataDir.description: The directory where Plex stores its data files.

services.plex.enable.description: Whether to enable Plex Media Server.

services.plex.extraPlugins.description:
A list of paths to extra plugin bundles to install in Plex's plugin
directory. Every time the systemd unit for Plex starts up, all of the
symlinks in Plex's plugin directory will be cleared and this module
will symlink all of the paths specified here to that directory. If
this behavior is undesired, set <option>managePlugins</option> to
false.

services.plex.managePlugins.description:
If set to true, this option will cause all of the symlinks in Plex's
plugin directory to be removed and symlinks for paths specified in
<option>extraPlugins</option> to be added.

services.plex.openFirewall.description: Open ports in the firewall for the media server.

services.plex.package.description:
The Plex package to use. Plex subscribers may wish to use their own
package here, pointing to subscriber-only server versions.

services.plex.user.description: User account under which Plex runs.

services.polipo.allowedClients.description: List of IP addresses or network addresses that may connect to Polipo.

services.polipo.enable.description: Whether to run the polipo caching web proxy.

services.polipo.extraConfig.description:
Polio configuration. Contents will be added
verbatim to the configuration file.

services.polipo.parentProxy.description:
Hostname and port number of an HTTP parent proxy;
it should have the form host:port.

services.polipo.proxyAddress.description: IP address on which Polipo will listen.

services.polipo.proxyPort.description: TCP port on which Polipo will listen.

services.polipo.socksParentProxy.description:
Hostname and port number of an SOCKS parent proxy;
it should have the form host:port.

services.postfix.aliasFiles.description: Aliases' tables to be compiled and placed into /var/lib/postfix/conf.

services.postfix.aliasMapType.description: The format the alias map should have. Use regexp if you want to use regular expressions.

services.postfix.config.description: The main.cf configuration file as key value set.
services.postfix.config.type: attribute set of boolean or string or list of stringss

services.postfix.destination.description:
Full (!) list of domains we deliver locally. Leave blank for
          acceptable Postfix default.

services.postfix.dnsBlacklistOverrides.description: contents of check_client_access for overriding dnsBlacklists

services.postfix.dnsBlacklists.description: dns blacklist servers to use with smtpd_client_restrictions

services.postfix.domain.description: Domain to use. Leave blank to use hostname minus first component.

services.postfix.enable.description: Whether to run the Postfix mail server.

services.postfix.enableHeaderChecks.description: Whether to enable postfix header checks

services.postfix.enableSmtp.description: Whether to enable smtp in master.cf.

services.postfix.extraAliases.description: Additional entries to put verbatim into aliases file, cf. man-page aliases(8).

services.postfix.extraConfig.description: Extra lines to be added verbatim to the main.cf configuration file.

services.postfix.extraMasterConf.description: Extra lines to append to the generated master.cf file.

services.postfix.group.description: What to call the Postfix group (must be used only for postfix).

services.postfix.headerChecks.*.action.description: The action to be executed when the pattern is matched

services.postfix.headerChecks.*.pattern.description: A regexp pattern matching the header

services.postfix.hostname.description:
Hostname to use. Leave blank to use just the hostname of machine.
          It should be FQDN.

services.postfix.localRecipients.description:
List of accepted local users. Specify a bare username, an
<literal>"@domain.tld"</literal> wild-card, or a complete
<literal>"user@domain.tld"</literal> address. If set, these names end
up in the local recipient map -- see the local(8) man-page -- and
effectively replace the system user database lookup that's otherwise
used by default.

services.postfix.lookupMX.description: Whether relay specified is just domain whose MX must be used.

services.postfix.mapFiles.description: Maps to be compiled and placed into /var/lib/postfix/conf.

services.postfix.masterConfig.description:
An attribute set of service options, which correspond to the service
definitions usually done within the Postfix
<filename>master.cf</filename> file.

services.postfix.masterConfig.<name>.arg.description:
Arguments to pass to the <option>command</option>. There is no shell
processing involved and shell syntax is passed verbatim to the
process.

services.postfix.masterConfig.<name>.chr.description:
Whether the service is chrooted to have only access to the
<option>services.postfix.queueDir</option> and the closure of
store paths specified by the <option>program</option> option.

services.postfix.masterConfig.<name>.com.description:
A program name specifying a Postfix service/daemon process.
By default it's the attribute <option>name</option>.

services.postfix.masterConfig.<name>.max.description:
The maximum number of processes to spawn for this service. If the
value is <literal>0</literal> it doesn't have any limit. If
<literal>null</literal> is given it uses the postfix default of
<literal>100</literal>.

services.postfix.masterConfig.<name>.nam.description: The name of the service to run. Defaults to the attribute set key.

services.postfix.masterConfig.<name>.pri.description:
Whether the service's sockets and storage directory is restricted to
be only available via the mail system. If <literal>null</literal> is
given it uses the postfix default <literal>true</literal>.

services.postfix.masterConfig.<name>.wak.description:
Automatically wake up the service after the specified number of
seconds. If <literal>0</literal> is given, never wake the service
up.

If set to <literal>false</literal> the component will only be woken
up if it is used. This is equivalent to postfix' notion of adding a
question mark behind the wakeup time in
<filename>master.cf</filename>

services.postfix.networks.description:
Net masks for trusted - allowed to relay mail to third parties -
          hosts. Leave empty to use mynetworks_style configuration or use
          default (localhost-only).

services.postfix.networksStyle.description:
Name of standard way of trusted network specification to use,
          leave blank if you specify it explicitly or if you want to use
          default (localhost-only).

services.postfix.origin.description: Origin to use in outgoing e-mail. Leave blank to use hostname.

services.postfix.postmasterAlias.description:
Who should receive postmaster e-mail. Multiple values can be added by
          separating values with comma.

services.postfix.recipientDelimiter.description: Delimiter for address extension: so mail to user+test can be handled by ~user/.forward+test

services.postfix.relayDomains.description: List of domains we agree to relay to. Default is empty.

services.postfix.relayPort.description: SMTP port for relay mail relay.

services.postfix.rootAlias.description:
Who should receive root e-mail. Blank for no redirection.
          Multiple values can be added by separating values with comma.

services.postfix.setSendmail.description: Whether to set the system sendmail to postfix's.

services.postfix.setgidGroup.description:
How to call postfix setgid group (for postdrop). Should
          be uniquely used group.

services.postfix.submissionOptions.description: Options for the submission config in master.cf

services.postfix.transport.description: Entries for the transport map, cf. man-page transport(8).

services.postfix.useSrs.description: Whether to enable sender rewriting scheme

services.postfix.user.description: What to call the Postfix user (must be used only for postfix).

services.postfix.virtual.description: Entries for the virtual alias map, cf. man-page virtual(8).

services.postfix.virtualMapType.description: What type of virtual alias map file to use. Use <literal>"regexp"</literal> for regular expressions.

services.postgresql.authentication.description:
Defines how users authenticate themselves to the server. By
default, "trust" access to local users will always be granted
along with any other custom options. If you do not want this,
set this option using "lib.mkForce" to override this
behaviour.

services.postgresql.enableTCPIP.description:
Whether PostgreSQL should listen on all network interfaces.
If disabled, the database can only be accessed via its Unix
domain socket or via TCP connections to localhost.

services.postgresql.ensureDatabases.description:
Ensures that the specified databases exist.
This option will never delete existing databases, especially not when the value of this
option is changed. This means that databases created once through this option or
otherwise have to be removed manually.

services.postgresql.ensureUsers.description:
Ensures that the specified users exist and have at least the ensured permissions.
The PostgreSQL users will be identified using peer authentication. This authenticates the Unix user with the
same name only, and that without the need for a password.
This option will never delete existing users or remove permissions, especially not when the value of this
option is changed. This means that users created and permissions assigned once through this option or
otherwise have to be removed manually.

services.postgresql.ensureUsers.*.ensure.description: Permissions to ensure for the user, specified as an attribute set. The attribute names specify the database and tables to grant the permissions for. The attribute values specify the permissions to grant. You may specify one or multiple comma-separated SQL privileges here. For more information on how to specify the target and on which privileges exist, see the GRANT syntax. The attributes are used as GRANT ${attrName} ON ${attrValue}.

services.postgresql.ensureUsers.*.name.description: Name of the user to ensure.

services.postgresql.extraConfig.description: Additional text to be appended to <filename>postgresql.conf</filename>.

services.postgresql.extraPlugins.description:
List of PostgreSQL plugins. PostgreSQL version for each plugin should
match version for <literal>services.postgresql.package</literal> value.

services.postgresql.identMap.description:
Defines the mapping from system users to database users.

The general form is:

map-name system-username database-username

services.postgresql.initialScript.description: A file containing SQL statements to execute on first startup.

services.postgresql.port.description: The port on which PostgreSQL listens.

services.postgresqlBackup.backupAll.description:
Backup all databases using pg_dumpall.
This option is mutual exclusive to
<literal>services.postgresqlBackup.databases</literal>.
The resulting backup dump will have the name all.sql.gz.
This option is the default if no databases are specified.

services.postgresqlBackup.databases.description: List of database names to dump.

services.postgresqlBackup.location.description: Location to put the gzipped PostgreSQL database dumps.

services.postgresqlBackup.pgdumpOptions.description:
Command line options for pg_dump. This options is not used
if <literal>config.services.postgresqlBackup.backupAll</literal> is enabled.
Note that config.services.postgresqlBackup.backupAll is also active,
when no databases where specified.

services.postgresqlBackup.startAt.description:
This option defines (see <literal>systemd.time</literal> for format) when the
databases should be dumped.
The default is to update at 01:15 (at night) every day.

services.postgresqlWalReceiver.receivers.description:
PostgreSQL WAL receivers.
Stream write-ahead logs from a PostgreSQL server using <command>pg_receivewal</command> (formerly <command>pg_receivexlog</command>).
See <link xlink:href="https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/app-pgreceivewal.html">the man page</link> for more information.

Enables gzip compression of write-ahead logs, and specifies the compression level
(<literal>0</literal> through <literal>9</literal>, <literal>0</literal> being no compression and <literal>9</literal> being best compression).
The suffix <literal>.gz</literal> will automatically be added to all filenames.

This option requires PostgreSQL >= 10.

Specifies parameters used to connect to the server, as a connection string.
See <link xlink:href="https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/libpq-connect.html#LIBPQ-CONNSTRING">Section 34.1.1 of the PostgreSQL manual</link> for more information.

Because <command>pg_receivewal</command> doesn't connect to any particular database in the cluster,
database name in the connection string will be ignored.
Directory to write the output to.

Environment variables passed to the service.
Usable parameters are listed in <link xlink:href="https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/libpq-envars.html">Section 34.14 of the PostgreSQL manual</link>.
A list of extra arguments to pass to the <command>pg_receivewal</command> command.

Require <command>pg_receivewal</command> to use an existing replication slot (see
<link xlink:href="https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/warm-standby.html#STREAMING-REPLICATION-SLOTS">Section 26.2.6 of the PostgreSQL manual</link>).
When this option is used, <command>pg_receivewal</command> will report a flush position to the server,
indicating when each segment has been synchronized to disk so that the server can remove that segment if it is not otherwise needed.

When the replication client of <command>pg_receivewal</command> is configured on the server as a synchronous standby,
then using a replication slot will report the flush position to the server, but only when a WAL file is closed.
Therefore, that configuration will cause transactions on the primary to wait for a long time and effectively not work satisfactorily.
The option <option>synchronous</option> must be specified in addition to make this work correctly.

Specifies the number of seconds between status packets sent back to the server.
This allows for easier monitoring of the progress from server.
A value of zero disables the periodic status updates completely,
although an update will still be sent when requested by the server, to avoid timeout disconnect.

Flush the WAL data to disk immediately after it has been received.
Also send a status packet back to the server immediately after flushing, regardless of <option>statusInterval</option>.

This option should be specified if the replication client of <command>pg_receivewal</command> is configured on the server as a synchronous standby,
to ensure that timely feedback is sent to the server.

services.postgrey.IPv4CIDR.description: Strip N bits from IPv4 addresses if lookupBySubnet is true

services.postgrey.IPv6CIDR.description: Strip N bits from IPv6 addresses if lookupBySubnet is true

services.postgrey.autoWhitelist.description: Whitelist clients after successful delivery of N messages

services.postgrey.enable.description: Whether to run the Postgrey daemon

services.postgrey.greylistAction.description: Response status for greylisted messages (see access(5))

services.postgrey.greylistHeader.default: X-Greylist: delayed %%t seconds by postgrey-%%v at %%h; %%d
services.postgrey.greylistHeader.description: Prepend header to greylisted mails; use %%t for seconds delayed due to greylisting, %%v for the version of postgrey, %%d for the date, and %%h for the host

services.postgrey.greylistText.description: Response status text for greylisted messages; use %%s for seconds left until greylisting is over and %%r for mail domain of recipient

services.postgrey.lookupBySubnet.description: Strip the last N bits from IP addresses, determined by IPv4CIDR and IPv6CIDR

services.postgrey.maxAge.description: Delete entries from whitelist if they haven't been seen for N days

services.postgrey.privacy.description: Store data using one-way hash functions (SHA1)

services.postgrey.retryWindow.description: Allow N days for the first retry. Use string with appended 'h' to specify time in hours

services.postsrsd.enable.description: Whether to enable the postsrsd SRS server for Postfix.

services.postsrsd.excludeDomains.description: Origin domains to exclude from rewriting in addition to primary domain

services.postsrsd.forwardPort.description: Port for the forward SRS lookup

services.postsrsd.reversePort.description: Port for the reverse SRS lookup

services.postsrsd.secretsFile.description: Secret keys used for signing and verification

services.postsrsd.separator.description: First separator character in generated addresses

services.postsrsd.timeout.description: Timeout for idle client connections in seconds

services.powerdns.enable.description: Whether to enable Powerdns domain name server.

services.powerdns.extraConfig.description:
Extra lines to be added verbatim to pdns.conf.
Powerdns will chroot to /var/lib/powerdns.
So any file, powerdns is supposed to be read,
should be in /var/lib/powerdns and needs to specified
relative to the chroot.

services.pppd.peers.<name>.autostart.description: Whether the PPP session is automatically started at boot time.

services.pppd.peers.<name>.config.description: pppd configuration for this peer, see the pppd(8) man page.

services.pppd.peers.<name>.enable.description: Whether to enable this PPP peer.

services.pptpd.clientIpRange.description: The range from which client IPs are drawn.

services.pptpd.enable.description: Whether to enable pptpd, the Point-to-Point Tunneling Protocol daemon.

services.pptpd.extraPppdOptions.description: Adds extra lines to the pppd options file.

services.pptpd.extraPptpdOptions.description: Adds extra lines to the pptpd configuration file.

services.pptpd.maxClients.description: The maximum number of simultaneous connections.

services.prayer.enable.description: Whether to run the prayer webmail http server.

services.prayer.extraConfig.description: Extra configuration. Contents will be added verbatim to the configuration file.

services.prayer.port.description: Port the prayer http server is listening to.

services.prey.deviceKey.description:
<literal>Device key</literal> obtained by visiting
<link xlink:href="https://panel.preyproject.com/devices" />
and clicking on your device.

services.prey.enable.description:
Enables the <link xlink:href="http://preyproject.com/" />
shell client. Be sure to specify both API and device keys.
Once enabled, a <command>cron</command> job will run every 15
minutes to report status information.

services.printing.browsedConf.description:
The contents of the configuration. file of the CUPS Browsed daemon
(<filename>cups-browsed.conf</filename>)

services.printing.browsing.description: Specifies whether shared printers are advertised.

services.printing.clientConf.description:
The contents of the client configuration.
(<filename>client.conf</filename>)

services.printing.defaultShared.description: Specifies whether local printers are shared by default.

services.printing.drivers.description:
CUPS drivers to use. Drivers provided by CUPS, cups-filters,
Ghostscript and Samba are added unconditionally. If this list contains
Gutenprint (i.e. a derivation with
<literal>meta.isGutenprint = true</literal>) the PPD files in
<filename>/var/lib/cups/ppd</filename> will be updated automatically
to avoid errors due to incompatible versions.

example.text: with pkgs; [ gutenprint hplip splix cups-googlecloudprint ]

services.printing.enable.description: Whether to enable printing support through the CUPS daemon.

services.printing.extraConf.description:
Extra contents of the configuration file of the CUPS daemon
(<filename>cupsd.conf</filename>).

services.printing.extraFilesConf.description:
Extra contents of the configuration file of the CUPS daemon
(<filename>cups-files.conf</filename>).

services.printing.listenAddresses.description: A list of addresses and ports on which to listen.

services.printing.snmpConf.description:
The contents of <filename>/etc/cups/snmp.conf</filename>. See "man
cups-snmp.conf" for a complete description.

services.printing.startWhenNeeded.description:
If set, CUPS is socket-activated; that is,
instead of having it permanently running as a daemon,
systemd will start it on the first incoming connection.

services.printing.webInterface.description: Specifies whether the web interface is enabled.

services.privoxy.actionsFiles.description:
List of paths to Privoxy action files.
These paths may either be absolute or relative to the privoxy configuration directory.

services.privoxy.enable.description: Whether to enable the Privoxy non-caching filtering proxy.

services.privoxy.enableEditActions.description: Whether or not the web-based actions file editor may be used.

services.privoxy.extraConfig.description: Extra configuration. Contents will be added verbatim to the configuration file.

services.privoxy.filterFiles.description:
List of paths to Privoxy filter files.
These paths may either be absolute or relative to the privoxy configuration directory.

services.privoxy.listenAddress.description: Address the proxy server is listening to.

services.prometheus.alertmanager.configT.description:
Alertmanager configuration as YAML text. If non-null, this option
defines the text that is written to alertmanager.yml. If null, the
contents of alertmanager.yml is generated from the structured config
options.

services.prometheus.alertmanager.configu.description: Alertmanager configuration as nix attribute set.

services.prometheus.alertmanager.extraFl.description: Extra commandline options when launching the Alertmanager.

services.prometheus.alertmanager.listenA.description:
Address to listen on for the web interface and API. Empty string will listen on all interfaces.
"localhost" will listen on 127.0.0.1 (but not ::1).

services.prometheus.alertmanager.logForm.description: If set use a syslog logger or JSON logging.

services.prometheus.alertmanager.logLeve.description: Only log messages with the given severity or above.

services.prometheus.alertmanager.openFir.description: Open port in firewall for incoming connections.

services.prometheus.alertmanager.package.description: Package that should be used for alertmanager.

services.prometheus.alertmanager.port.description: Port to listen on for the web interface and API.

services.prometheus.alertmanager.webExte.description:
The URL under which Alertmanager is externally reachable (for example, if Alertmanager is served via a reverse proxy).
Used for generating relative and absolute links back to Alertmanager itself.
If the URL has a path portion, it will be used to prefix all HTTP endoints served by Alertmanager.
If omitted, relevant URL components will be derived automatically.

services.prometheus.alertmanagerNotifica.description: The capacity of the queue for pending alert manager notifications.

services.prometheus.alertmanagerTimeout.description: Alert manager HTTP API timeout (in seconds).

services.prometheus.exporters.wireguard..description: Whether to enable the prometheus wireguard exporter.
Extra commandline options to pass to the wireguard exporter.

Specify a filter for iptables to use when
<option>services.prometheus.exporters.wireguard.openFirewall</option>
is true. It is used as `ip46tables -I nixos-fw <option>firewallFilter</option> -j nixos-fw-accept`.

Group under which the wireguard exporter shall be run.
Has no effect when <option>systemd.services.prometheus-wireguard-exporter.serviceConfig.DynamicUser</option> is true.
Open port in firewall for incoming connections.

By default, all allowed IPs and subnets are comma-separated in the
<literal>allowed_ips</literal> field. With this option enabled,
a single IP and subnet will be listed in fields like <literal>allowed_ip_0</literal>,
<literal>allowed_ip_1</literal> and so on.

User name under which the wireguard exporter shall be run.
Has no effect when <option>systemd.services.prometheus-wireguard-exporter.serviceConfig.DynamicUser</option> is true.
Whether to enable Verbose logging mode for prometheus-wireguard-exporter.

Path to the Wireguard Config to
<link xlink:href="https://github.com/MindFlavor/prometheus_wireguard_exporter/tree/2.0.0#usage">add the peer's name to the stats of a peer</link>.

Please note that <literal>networking.wg-quick</literal> is required for this feature
as <literal>networking.wireguard</literal> uses
<citerefentry><refentrytitle>wg</refentrytitle><manvolnum>8</manvolnum></citerefentry>
to set the peers up.
Whether or not the remote IP of a WireGuard peer should be exposed via prometheus.

services.prometheus.scrapeConfigs.*.hono.description:
Controls how Prometheus handles conflicts between labels
that are already present in scraped data and labels that
Prometheus would attach server-side ("job" and "instance"
labels, manually configured target labels, and labels
generated by service discovery implementations).

If honor_labels is set to "true", label conflicts are
resolved by keeping label values from the scraped data and
ignoring the conflicting server-side labels.

If honor_labels is set to "false", label conflicts are
resolved by renaming conflicting labels in the scraped data
to "exported_<original-label>" (for example
"exported_instance", "exported_job") and then attaching
server-side labels. This is useful for use cases such as
federation, where all labels specified in the target should
be preserved.

Defaults to <literal>false</literal> in prometheus
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

honor_timestamps controls whether Prometheus respects the timestamps present
in scraped data.

If honor_timestamps is set to <literal>true</literal>, the timestamps of the metrics exposed
by the target will be used.

If honor_timestamps is set to <literal>false</literal>, the timestamps of the metrics exposed
by the target will be ignored.

Defaults to <literal>true</literal> in prometheus
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.prometheus.scrapeConfigs.*.job_.description: The job name assigned to scraped metrics by default.

services.prometheus.scrapeConfigs.*.metr.description:

Defaults to <literal>/metrics</literal> in prometheus
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.prometheus.scrapeConfigs.*.para.type: null or attribute set of list of stringss

services.prometheus.scrapeConfigs.*.rela.description:
Action to perform based on regex matching.

Defaults to <literal>replace</literal> in prometheus
when set to <literal>null</literal>.
Modulus to take of the hash of the source label values.

Regular expression against which the extracted value is matched.

Defaults to <literal>(.*)</literal> in prometheus
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

Replacement value against which a regex replace is performed if the
regular expression matches.

Defaults to <literal>$1</literal> in prometheus
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

Separator placed between concatenated source label values.

Defaults to <literal>;</literal> in prometheus
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

The source labels select values from existing labels. Their content
is concatenated using the configured separator and matched against
the configured regular expression.

Label to which the resulting value is written in a replace action.
It is mandatory for replace actions.

services.prometheus.scrapeConfigs.*.samp.description:
Per-scrape limit on number of scraped samples that will be accepted.
If more than this number of samples are present after metric relabelling
the entire scrape will be treated as failed. 0 means no limit.

Defaults to <literal>0</literal> in prometheus
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.rabbitmq.config.description:
Verbatim advanced configuration file contents using the Erlang syntax.
This is also known as the <literal>advanced.config</literal> file or the old config format.

<literal>configItems</literal> is preferred whenever possible. However, nested
data structures can only be expressed properly using the <literal>config</literal> option.

The contents of this option will be merged into the <literal>configItems</literal>
by RabbitMQ at runtime to form the final configuration.

See the second table on http://www.rabbitmq.com/configure.html#config-items
For the distinct formats, see http://www.rabbitmq.com/configure.html#config-file-formats

services.rabbitmq.configItems.description:
Configuration options in RabbitMQ's new config file format,
which is a simple key-value format that can not express nested
data structures. This is known as the <literal>rabbitmq.conf</literal> file,
although outside NixOS that filename may have Erlang syntax, particularly
prior to RabbitMQ 3.7.0.

If you do need to express nested data structures, you can use
<literal>config</literal> option. Configuration from <literal>config</literal>
will be merged into these options by RabbitMQ at runtime to
form the final configuration.

See http://www.rabbitmq.com/configure.html#config-items
For the distinct formats, see http://www.rabbitmq.com/configure.html#config-file-formats

services.rabbitmq.cookie.description:
Erlang cookie is a string of arbitrary length which must
be the same for several nodes to be allowed to communicate.
Leave empty to generate automatically.

services.rabbitmq.enable.description:
Whether to enable the RabbitMQ server, an Advanced Message

services.rabbitmq.listenAddress.description:
IP address on which RabbitMQ will listen for AMQP
connections.  Set to the empty string to listen on all
interfaces.  Note that RabbitMQ creates a user named
<literal>guest</literal> with password
<literal>guest</literal> by default, so you should delete
this user if you intend to allow external access.

Together with 'port' setting it's mostly an alias for
configItems."listeners.tcp.1" and it's left for backwards
compatibility with previous version of this module.

`/proc/filesystems` (e.g., "minix", "ext2", "ext3", "jfs", "xfs", 
"reiserfs", "msdos", "proc", "nfs", "iso9660"). For bind mounts 
(when options include either bind or rbind), the type is a dummy,
often "none" (not listed in /proc/filesystems).

services.redshift.temperature.night.description:
Colour temperature to use at night, between
<literal>1000</literal> and <literal>25000</literal> K.

services.redsocks.chroot.description:
Chroot under which to run redsocks. Log file is opened before
chroot, but if logging to syslog /etc/localtime may be required.

services.redsocks.log.description:
Where to send logs.

Possible values are:
  - stderr
  - file:/path/to/file
  - syslog:FACILITY where FACILITY is any of "daemon", "local0",
  etc.

services.redsocks.log_info.description: Log start and end of client sessions.

services.redsocks.redsocks.description:
Local port to proxy associations to be performed.

The example shows how to configure a proxy to handle port 80 as HTTP
relay, and all other ports as HTTP connect.

services.redsocks.redsocks.*.disclose_sr.description:
Way to disclose client IP to the proxy.
  - "false": do not disclose
http-connect supports the following ways:
  - "X-Forwarded-For": add header "X-Forwarded-For: IP"
  - "Forwarded_ip": add header "Forwarded: for=IP" (see RFC7239)
  - "Forwarded_ipport": add header 'Forwarded: for="IP:port"'

services.redsocks.redsocks.*.doNotRedire.description:
Iptables filters that if matched will get the packet off of
redsocks.

services.redsocks.redsocks.*.ip.description:
IP on which redsocks should listen. Defaults to 127.0.0.1 for
security reasons.

services.redsocks.redsocks.*.password.description:
Password to send to proxy. WARNING, this will end up
world-readable in the store! Awaiting
https://github.com/NixOS/nix/issues/8 to be able to fix.

services.redsocks.redsocks.*.port.description: Port on which redsocks should listen.

services.redsocks.redsocks.*.proxy.description:
Proxy through which redsocks should forward incoming traffic.
Example: "example.org:8080"

services.redsocks.redsocks.*.redirectCon.description:
Conditions to make outbound packets go through this redsocks
instance.

If set to false, no packet will be forwarded. If set to true,
all packets will be forwarded (except packets excluded by
redirectInternetOnly).

If set to a string, this is an iptables filter that will be
matched against packets before getting them into redsocks. For
example, setting it to "--dport 80" will only send
packets to port 80 to redsocks. Note "-p tcp" is always
implicitly added, as udp can only be proxied through redudp or
the like.

services.redsocks.redsocks.*.redirectInt.description: Exclude all non-globally-routable IPs from redsocks

services.resilio.apiKey.description: API key, which enables the developer API.

services.resilio.checkForUpdates.description:
Determines whether to check for updates and alert the user
about them in the UI.

services.resilio.deviceName.description: Name of the Resilio Sync device.

services.resilio.directoryRoot.description: Default directory to add folders in the web UI.

services.resilio.enable.description:
If enabled, start the Resilio Sync daemon. Once enabled, you can
interact with the service through the Web UI, or configure it in your
NixOS configuration.

services.resilio.enableWebUI.description:
Enable Web UI for administration. Bound to the specified
<literal>httpListenAddress</literal> and
<literal>httpListenPort</literal>.

services.resilio.listeningPort.description: Listening port. Defaults to 0 which randomizes the port.

services.resilio.sharedFolders.description:
Shared folder list. If enabled, web UI must be
disabled. Secrets can be generated using <literal>rslsync
--generate-secret</literal>. Note that this secret will be
put inside the Nix store, so it is realistically not very
secret.

If you would like to be able to modify the contents of this
directories, it is recommended that you make your user a
member of the <literal>resilio</literal> group.

Directories in this list should be in the
<literal>resilio</literal> group, and that group must have
write access to the directory. It is also recommended that
<literal>chmod g+s</literal> is applied to the directory
so that any sub directories created will also belong to
the <literal>resilio</literal> group. Also,
<literal>setfacl -d -m group:resilio:rwx</literal> and
<literal>setfacl -m group:resilio:rwx</literal> should also
be applied so that the sub directories are writable by
the group.

services.resilio.storagePath.description:
Where BitTorrent Sync will store it's database files (containing
things like username info and licenses). Generally, you should not
need to ever change this.

services.resolved.dnssec.description:
If set to
<variablelist>
<varlistentry>
  <term><literal>"true"</literal></term>
  <listitem><para>
    all DNS lookups are DNSSEC-validated locally (excluding
    LLMNR and Multicast DNS). Note that this mode requires a
    DNS server that supports DNSSEC. If the DNS server does
    not properly support DNSSEC all validations will fail.
  </para></listitem>
</varlistentry>
<varlistentry>
  <term><literal>"allow-downgrade"</literal></term>
  <listitem><para>
    DNSSEC validation is attempted, but if the server does not
    support DNSSEC properly, DNSSEC mode is automatically
    disabled. Note that this mode makes DNSSEC validation
    vulnerable to "downgrade" attacks, where an attacker might
    be able to trigger a downgrade to non-DNSSEC mode by
    synthesizing a DNS response that suggests DNSSEC was not
    supported.
  </para></listitem>
</varlistentry>
<varlistentry>
  <term><literal>"false"</literal></term>
  <listitem><para>
    DNS lookups are not DNSSEC validated.
  </para></listitem>
</varlistentry>
</variablelist>

services.resolved.domains.description:
A list of domains. These domains are used as search suffixes
when resolving single-label host names (domain names which
contain no dot), in order to qualify them into fully-qualified
domain names (FQDNs).

For compatibility reasons, if this setting is not specified,
the search domains listed in
<filename>/etc/resolv.conf</filename> are used instead, if
that file exists and any domains are configured in it.

services.resolved.enable.description: Whether to enable the systemd DNS resolver daemon.

services.resolved.extraConfig.description: Extra config to append to resolved.conf.

services.resolved.fallbackDns.description:
A list of IPv4 and IPv6 addresses to use as the fallback DNS servers.
If this option is empty, a compiled-in list of DNS servers is used instead.

services.resolved.llmnr.description:
Controls Link-Local Multicast Name Resolution support
(RFC 4795) on the local host.

If set to

<variablelist>
<varlistentry>
  <term><literal>"true"</literal></term>
  <listitem><para>
    Enables full LLMNR responder and resolver support.
  </para></listitem>
</varlistentry>
<varlistentry>
  <term><literal>"false"</literal></term>
  <listitem><para>
    Disables both.
  </para></listitem>
</varlistentry>
<varlistentry>
  <term><literal>"resolve"</literal></term>
  <listitem><para>
    Only resolution support is enabled, but responding is disabled.
  </para></listitem>
</varlistentry>
</variablelist>

services.restic.backups.description: Periodic backups to create with Restic.

services.restic.server.appendOnly.description:

This mode allows creation of new backups but prevents deletion and modification of existing backups.
This can be useful when backing up systems that have a potential of being hacked.

A local PostgreSQL database is initialized automatically.

services.riak.distributedCookie.description:
Cookie for distributed node communication.  All nodes in the
same cluster should use the same cookie or they will not be able to
communicate.

services.riak.extraAdvancedConfig.description: Additional text to be appended to <filename>advanced.config</filename>.

services.riemann-dash.config.description: Contents added to the end of the riemann-dash configuration file.

services.riemann-dash.dataDir.description:
Location of the riemann-base dir. The dashboard configuration file is

A list of commandline-switches forwarded to a riemann-tool.

services.rippleDataApi.couchdb.create.description: Whether to create couchdb database needed by ripple data api.

ledger data (or "full" for no limit).

If set, then require administrative RPC call "can_delete"
to enable online deletion of ledger records.

services.rippled.ips.description:
List of hostnames or ips where the Ripple protocol is served.
For a starter list, you can either copy entries from:
https://ripple.com/ripple.txt or if you prefer you can let it
 default to r.ripple.com 51235

A port may optionally be specified after adding a space to the
address. By convention, if known, IPs are listed in from most
to least trusted.

services.rippled.ipsFixed.description:
List of IP addresses or hostnames to which rippled should always
attempt to maintain peer connections with. This is useful for
manually forming private networks, for example to configure a
validation server that connects to the Ripple network through a
public-facing server, or for building a set of cluster peers.

A port may optionally be specified after adding a space to the address

services.rippled.ledgerHistory.description:

to maintain while running.

services.rippled.nodeDb.advisoryDelete.description:
If set, then require administrative RPC call "can_delete"
to enable online deletion of ledger records.

services.rippled.nodeDb.onlineDelete.description: Enable automatic purging of older ledger information.

services.rippled.nodeSize.description:
Rippled size of the node you are running.
"tiny", "small", "medium", "large", and "huge"

services.rippled.ports.<name>.admin.description: A comma-separated list of admin IP addresses.

services.rippled.ports.<name>.password.description: When set, these credentials will be required on HTTP/S requests.

services.rippled.ports.<name>.ssl.cert.description:
Specifies the path to the SSL certificate file in PEM format.

services.rippled.ports.<name>.ssl.chain.description:
If you need a certificate chain, specify the path to the
certificate chain here. The chain may include the end certificate.

services.rippled.ports.<name>.ssl.key.description: Specifies the filename holding the SSL key in PEM format.

services.rippled.ports.<name>.user.description: When set, these credentials will be required on HTTP/S requests.

services.rippled.sntpServers.description: IP address or domain of NTP servers to use for time synchronization.;

If set, then require administrative RPC call "can_delete"
to enable online deletion of ledger records.

The minimum number of trusted validations a ledger must have before

services.rippled.validators.description:
List of nodes to always accept as validators. Nodes are specified by domain

postgresql user and database yourself, with appropriate

Whether to enable roundcube.

Also enables nginx virtual host management.
Further nginx configuration can be done by adapting <literal>services.nginx.virtualHosts.<name></literal>.
See <xref linkend="opt-services.nginx.virtualHosts"/> for further information.

Whether to enable `rpcbind', an ONC RPC directory service

services.rsnapshot.cronIntervals.description:
Periodicity at which intervals should be run by cron.
Note that the intervals also have to exist in configuration
as retain options.

services.rsnapshot.extraConfig.description:
rsnapshot configuration option in addition to the defaults from
rsnapshot and this module.

Note that tabs are required to separate option arguments, and
directory names require trailing slashes.

The "extra" in the option name might be a little misleading right
now, as it is required to get a functional configuration.
services.rsnapshot.extraConfig.example:
retains	hourly	24
retain	daily	365
backup	/home/	localhost/

services.rspamd.overrides.<name>.enable.description:

services.rspamd.user.description: User to use when no root privileges are required.

<literal>r2e new</literal>.

This set contains key-value associations that will be set in the

services.rss2email.interval.description: How often to check the feeds, in systemd interval format

services.rss2email.to.description: Mail address to which to send emails

IP address the daemon will listen on; rsyncd will listen on

services.rsyncd.extraConfig.description:

The user to run the daemon as.

services.rsyslogd.defaultConfig.default:
# "local1" is used for dhcpd messages.
local1.*                     -/var/log/dhcpd

mail.*                       -/var/log/mail

*.=warning;*.=err            -/var/log/warn
*.crit                        /var/log/warn

*.*;mail.none;local1.none    -/var/log/messages
services.rsyslogd.defaultConfig.description:
The default <filename>syslog.conf</filename> file configures a
fairly standard setup of log files, which can be extended by
means of <varname>extraConfig</varname>.

services.rsyslogd.enable.description:
Whether to enable syslogd.  Note that systemd also logs
syslog messages, so you normally don't need to run syslogd.

services.rsyslogd.extraConfig.description:
Additional text appended to <filename>syslog.conf</filename>,
i.e. the contents of <varname>defaultConfig</varname>.

services.sabnzbd.enable.description: Whether to enable the sabnzbd server.

services.samba.configText.description:

Whether to enable Samba, which provides file and print
services to Windows clients through the SMB/CIFS protocol.

<note>
  <para>If you use the firewall consider adding the following:</para>
<programlisting>
  networking.firewall.allowedTCPPorts = [ 139 445 ];
  networking.firewall.allowedUDPPorts = [ 137 138 ];
</programlisting>
</note>

services.samba.enableNmbd.description:
Whether to enable Samba's nmbd, which replies to NetBIOS over IP name
service requests. It also participates in the browsing protocols
which make up the Windows "Network Neighborhood" view.

services.samba.enableWinbindd.description:
Whether to enable Samba's winbindd, which provides a number of services
to the Name Service Switch capability found in most modern C libraries,
to arbitrary applications via PAM and ntlm_auth and to Samba itself.

services.samba.extraConfig.description: Additional global section and extra section lines go in here.
services.samba.extraConfig.example:
guest account = nobody
map to guest = bad user

services.samba.invalidUsers.description: List of users who are denied to login via Samba.

services.samba.nsswins.description:
Whether to enable the WINS NSS (Name Service Switch) plug-in.
Enabling it allows applications to resolve WINS/NetBIOS names (a.k.a.
Windows machine names) by transparently querying the winbindd daemon.

services.samba.package.description: Defines which package should be used for the samba server.

services.samba.shares.description:
A set describing shared resources.
See <command>man smb.conf</command> for options.
services.samba.shares.type: attribute set of attribute set of unspecifiedss

services.samba.syncPasswordsByPam.description:
Enabling this will add a line directly after pam_unix.so.
Whenever a password is changed the samba password will be updated as well.
However, you still have to add the samba password once, using smbpasswd -a user.
If you don't want to maintain an extra password database, you still can send plain text
passwords which is not secure.

services.saned.enable.description:
Enable saned network daemon for remote connection to scanners.

saned would be runned from <literal>scanner</literal> user; to allow
access to hardware that doesn't have <literal>scanner</literal> group
you should add needed groups to this user.

services.scollector.bosunHost.description:
Host and port of the bosun server that will store the collected

An attribute set mapping the frequency of collection to a list of
binaries that should be executed at that frequency. You can use "0"
to run a binary forever.

services.scollector.extraConfig.description: Extra scollector configuration added to the end of scollector.toml

services.scollector.group.description: Group account under which scollector runs.

services.scollector.user.description: User account under which scollector runs.

services.searx.configFile.description:
The path of the Searx server configuration file. If no file

services.searx.enable.description: Whether to enable the searx server. See https://github.com/asciimoo/searx.

The Seeks server configuration. If it is not specified,

services.seeks.enable.description: Whether to enable the Seeks server.

services.selfoss.database.host.description: Host of the database (has no effect if type is "sqlite").

services.selfoss.database.name.description: Name of the existing database (has no effect if type is "sqlite").

services.selfoss.database.password.description: The database user's password (has no effect if type is "sqlite").

services.selfoss.database.port.description:
The database's port. If not set, the default ports will be
provided (5432 and 3306 for pgsql and mysql respectively)
(has no effect if type is "sqlite").

services.selfoss.database.type.description: Database to store feeds. Supported are sqlite, pgsql and mysql.

services.selfoss.database.user.description:
The database user. The user must exist and has access to
the specified database (has no effect if type is "sqlite").

services.selfoss.pool.description:
Name of existing phpfpm pool that is used to run web-application.
If not specified a pool will be created automatically with
default values.

services.selfoss.user.description: User account under which both the service and the web-application run.

services.serviio.dataDir.description: The directory where serviio stores its state, data, etc.

services.serviio.enable.description: Whether to enable the Serviio Media Server.

services.shadowsocks.enable.description: Whether to run shadowsocks-libev shadowsocks server.

services.shadowsocks.localAddress.description: Local addresses to which the server binds.
services.shadowsocks.localAddress.type: list of strings or string convertible to it

services.shadowsocks.passwordFile.description: Password file with a password for connecting clients.

services.shairport-sync.arguments.description:
Arguments to pass to the daemon. Defaults to a local pulseaudio
server.

services.shairport-sync.enable.description:
Enable the shairport-sync daemon.

Running with a local system-wide or remote pulseaudio server
is recommended.

services.shairport-sync.user.description:
User account name under which to run shairport-sync. The account
will be created.

services.shellinabox.certDirectory.description:
The daemon will look in this directory far any certificates.
If the browser negotiated a Server Name Identification the daemon
will look for a matching certificate-SERVERNAME.pem file. If no SNI
handshake takes place, it will fall back on using the certificate in the
certificate.pem file.

If no suitable certificate is installed, shellinaboxd will attempt to
create a new self-signed certificate. This will only succeed if, after
dropping privileges, shellinaboxd has write permissions for this
directory.

services.shellinabox.enableSSL.description: Whether or not to enable SSL (https) support.

services.shellinabox.extraOptions.description:
A list of strings to be appended to the command line arguments
for shellinaboxd. Please see the manual page
<link xlink:href="https://code.google.com/p/shellinabox/wiki/shellinaboxd_man"/>
for a full list of available arguments.

services.shellinabox.user.description:
User to run shellinaboxd as. If started as root, the server drops
privileges by changing to nobody, unless overridden by the
<literal>--user</literal> option.

services.shibboleth-sp.enable.description: Whether to enable the shibboleth service

services.shibboleth-sp.fastcgi.enable.description: Whether to include the shibauthorizer and shibresponder FastCGI processes

services.shibboleth-sp.fastcgi.shibAutho.description: Port for shibauthorizer FastCGI proccess to bind to

services.shibboleth-sp.fastcgi.shibRespo.description: Port for shibauthorizer FastCGI proccess to bind to

services.shout.config.description:
Shout <filename>config.js</filename> contents as attribute set (will be
converted to JSON to generate the configuration file).

The options defined here will be merged to the default configuration file.

Documentation: http://shout-irc.com/docs/server/configuration.html

services.shout.configFile.description:
Contents of Shout's <filename>config.js</filename> file.

Used for backward compatibility, recommended way is now to use
the <literal>config</literal> option.

Documentation: http://shout-irc.com/docs/server/configuration.html

services.shout.enable.description: Whether to enable Shout web IRC client.

services.shout.listenAddress.description: IP interface to listen on for http connections.

services.shout.port.description: TCP port to listen on for http connections.

services.shout.private.description:
Make your shout instance private. You will need to configure user
accounts by adding entries in <filename>/var/lib/shout/users</filename>.

services.sickbeard.dataDir.description: Path where to store data files.

services.sickbeard.enable.description: Whether to enable the sickbeard server.

services.sickbeard.group.description: Group to run the service as

services.sickbeard.package.description:
Enable <literal>pkgs.sickrage</literal> or <literal>pkgs.sickgear</literal>
as an alternative to SickBeard

services.sickbeard.port.type: 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

services.sickbeard.user.description: User to run the service as

services.siproxd.enable.description:
Whether to enable the Siproxd SIP 
	  proxy/masquerading daemon.

services.siproxd.extraConfig.description: Extra configuration to add to siproxd configuration.

services.siproxd.hostsAllowReg.description: Acess control list for incoming SIP registrations.

services.siproxd.hostsAllowSip.description: Acess control list for incoming SIP traffic.

services.siproxd.hostsDenySip.description:
Acess control list for denying incoming
	   SIP registrations and traffic.

services.siproxd.rtpDscp.description:
DSCP (differentiated services) value to be assigned
to RTP packets. Allows QOS aware routers to handle 
different types traffic with different priorities.

services.siproxd.rtpPortHigh.description: Top of UDP port range for incoming and outgoing RTP traffic

services.siproxd.rtpPortLow.description: Bottom of UDP port range for incoming and outgoing RTP traffic

services.siproxd.rtpTimeout.description:
Timeout for an RTP stream. If for the specified 
number of seconds no data is relayed on an active
stream, it is considered dead and will be killed.

services.siproxd.sipDscp.description:
DSCP (differentiated services) value to be assigned
to SIP packets. Allows QOS aware routers to handle 
different types traffic with different priorities.

services.siproxd.sipListenPort.description: Port to listen for incoming SIP messages.

services.sks.dataDir.description:
Data directory (-basedir) for SKS, where the database and all
configuration files are located (e.g. KDB, PTree, membership and
sksconf).

services.sks.enable.description:
Whether to enable SKS (synchronizing key server for OpenPGP) and start the database
server. You need to create "${dataDir}/dump/*.gpg" for the initial
import.

services.sks.extraDbConfig.description:
Set contents of the files "KDB/DB_CONFIG" and "PTree/DB_CONFIG" within
the ${dataDir} directory. This is used to configure options for the
database for the sks key server.

Documentation of available options are available in the file named
"sampleConfig/DB_CONFIG" in the following repository:
https://bitbucket.org/skskeyserver/sks-keyserver/src

services.sks.hkpAddress.description:
Domain names, IPv4 and/or IPv6 addresses to listen on for HKP
requests.

services.sks.hkpPort.type: 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

services.sks.webroot.description:
Source directory (will be symlinked, if not null) for the files the
built-in webserver should serve. SKS (${pkgs.sks.webSamples})
provides the following examples: "HTML5", "OpenPKG", and "XHTML+ES".
The index file can be named index.html, index.htm, index.xhtm, or
index.xhtml. Files with the extensions .css, .es, .js, .jpg, .jpeg,
.png, or .gif are supported. Subdirectories and filenames with
anything other than alphanumeric characters and the '.' character
will be ignored.

services.skydns.domain.description: Skydns default domain if not specified by etcd config.

services.skydns.etcd.caCert.description: Skydns path of TLS certificate authority public key.

services.skydns.etcd.machines.description: Skydns list of etcd endpoints to connect to.

services.skydns.etcd.tlsKey.description: Skydns path of TLS client certificate - private key.

services.skydns.etcd.tlsPem.description: Skydns path of TLS client certificate - public key.

services.skydns.extraConfig.description: Skydns attribute set of extra config options passed as environemnt variables.

services.skydns.nameservers.description: Skydns list of nameservers to forward DNS requests to when not authoritative for a domain.

services.slimserver.dataDir.description:
The directory where slimserver stores its state, tag cache,
playlists etc.

services.slurm.client.enable.description: Whether to enable slurm client daemon.

services.slurm.clusterName.description: Necessary to distinguish accounting records in a multi-cluster environment.

services.slurm.controlAddr.description:
Name that ControlMachine should be referred to in establishing a
communications path.

services.slurm.controlMachine.description:
The short hostname of the machine where SLURM control functions are
executed (i.e. the name returned by the command "hostname -s", use "tux001"
rather than "tux001.my.com").

services.slurm.dbdserver.dbdHost.description:
Hostname of the machine where <literal>slurmdbd</literal>
is running (i.e. name returned by <literal>hostname -s</literal>).

services.slurm.enableSrunX11.description:
If enabled srun will accept the option "--x11" to allow for X11 forwarding
from within an interactive session or a batch job. This activates the
slurm-spank-x11 module. Note that this option also enables
'services.openssh.forwardX11' on the client.

This option requires slurm to be compiled without native X11 support.

services.slurm.enableStools.description:
Wether to provide a slurm.conf file.
Enable this option if you do not run a slurm daemon on this host
(i.e. <literal>server.enable</literal> and <literal>client.enable</literal> are <literal>false</literal>)
but you still want to run slurm commands from this host.

services.slurm.extraCgroupConfig.description:
Extra configuration for <literal>cgroup.conf</literal>. This file is
used when <literal>procTrackType=proctrack/cgroup</literal>.

services.slurm.extraConfig.description:
Extra configuration options that will be added verbatim at
the end of the slurm configuration file.

services.slurm.extraConfigPaths.description:
Slurm expects config files for plugins in the same path
as <literal>slurm.conf</literal>. Add extra nix store
paths that should be merged into same directory as
<literal>slurm.conf</literal>.

services.slurm.extraPlugstackConfig.description: Extra configuration that will be added to the end of <literal>plugstack.conf</literal>.

services.slurm.nodeName.description:
Name that SLURM uses to refer to a node (or base partition for BlueGene
systems). Typically this would be the string that "/bin/hostname -s"
returns. Note that now you have to write node's parameters after the name.

services.slurm.package.description: The package to use for slurm binaries.

services.slurm.partitionName.description:
Name by which the partition may be referenced. Note that now you have
to write the partition's parameters after the name.

services.slurm.procTrackType.description:
Plugin to be used for process tracking on a job step basis.
The slurmd daemon uses this mechanism to identify all processes
which are children of processes it spawns for a user job step.

services.slurm.server.enable.description:
Wether to enable the slurm control daemon.
Note that the standard authentication method is "munge".
The "munge" service needs to be provided with a password file in order for
slurm to work properly (see <literal>services.munge.password</literal>).

services.slurm.stateSaveLocation.description: Directory into which the Slurm controller, slurmctld, saves its state.

services.slurm.user.description:
Set this option when you want to run the slurmctld daemon
as something else than the default slurm user "slurm".
Note that the UID of this user needs to be the same
on all nodes.

services.smartd.autodetect.description:
Whenever smartd should monitor all devices connected to the
machine at the time it's being started (the default).

Set to false to monitor the devices listed in
<option>services.smartd.devices</option> only.

services.smartd.defaults.autodetected.description:
Like <option>services.smartd.defaults.monitored</option>, but for the
autodetected devices.

services.smartd.defaults.monitored.description:
Common default options for explicitly monitored (listed in
<option>services.smartd.devices</option>) devices.

The default value turns on monitoring of all the things (see
<literal>man 5 smartd.conf</literal>).

The example also turns on SMART Automatic Offline Testing on
startup, and schedules short self-tests daily, and long
self-tests weekly.

services.smartd.devices.*.options.description: Options that determine how smartd monitors the device.

services.smartd.enable.description: Whether to enable smartd daemon from <literal>smartmontools</literal> package.

services.smartd.extraOptions.description:
Extra command-line options passed to the <literal>smartd</literal>
daemon on startup.

(See <literal>man 8 smartd</literal>.)

services.smartd.notifications.mail.maile.description:
Sendmail-compatible binary to be used to send the messages.

You should probably enable
<option>services.postfix</option> or some other MTA for
this to work.

services.smartd.notifications.test.description: Whenever to send a test notification on startup.

services.smartd.notifications.wall.enabl.description: Whenever to send wall notifications to all users.

services.smartd.notifications.x11.displa.description: DISPLAY to send X11 notifications to.

services.smartd.notifications.x11.enable.description: Whenever to send X11 xmessage notifications.

from = smokealert@company.xy

+someloss
type = loss
# in percent
pattern = >0%,*12*,>0%,*12*,>0%
comment = loss 3 times  in a row;

services.smokeping.config.description: Full smokeping config supplied by the user. Overrides and replaces any other configuration supplied.

step     = 300
pings    = 20
# consfn mrhb steps total
AVERAGE  0.5   1  1008
AVERAGE  0.5  12  4320
    MIN  0.5  12  4320
    MAX  0.5  12  4320
AVERAGE  0.5 144   720
    MAX  0.5 144   720
    MIN  0.5 144   720
services.smokeping.databaseConfig.description:
Configure the ping frequency and retention of the rrd files.
          Once set, changing the interval will require deletion or migration of all
          the collected data.

example.text:
# near constant pings.
step     = 30
pings    = 20
# consfn mrhb steps total
AVERAGE  0.5   1  10080
AVERAGE  0.5  12  43200
    MIN  0.5  12  43200
    MAX  0.5  12  43200
AVERAGE  0.5 144   7200
    MAX  0.5 144   7200
    MIN  0.5 144   7200

services.smokeping.extraConfig.description: Any additional customization not already included.

services.smokeping.hostName.description: DNS name for the urls generated in the cgi.

services.smokeping.imgUrl.description: Base url for images generated in the cgi.

services.smokeping.linkStyle.description: DNS name for the urls generated in the cgi.

services.smokeping.mailHost.description: Use this SMTP server to send alerts

services.smokeping.owner.description: Real name of the owner of the instance

services.smokeping.port.description: TCP port to use for the web server.

services.smokeping.presentationConfig.default:
+ charts
menu = Charts
title = The most interesting destinations
++ stddev
sorter = StdDev(entries=>4)
title = Top Standard Deviation
menu = Std Deviation
format = Standard Deviation %f
++ max
sorter = Max(entries=>5)
title = Top Max Roundtrip Time
menu = by Max
format = Max Roundtrip Time %f seconds
++ loss
sorter = Loss(entries=>5)
title = Top Packet Loss
menu = Loss
format = Packets Lost %f
++ median
sorter = Median(entries=>5)
title = Top Median Roundtrip Time
menu = by Median
format = Median RTT %f seconds
+ overview
width = 600
height = 50
range = 10h
+ detail
width = 600
height = 200
unison_tolerance = 2
"Last 3 Hours"    3h
"Last 30 Hours"   30h
"Last 10 Days"    10d
"Last 360 Days"   360d

services.smokeping.presentationTemplate.description: Default page layout for the web UI.

services.smokeping.sendmail.description: Use this sendmail compatible script to deliver alerts

services.smokeping.smokeMailTemplate.description: Specify the smokemail template for alerts.

services.smokeping.targetConfig.default:
probe = FPing
					menu = Top
					title = Network Latency Grapher
					remark = Welcome to the SmokePing website of xxx Company. \
									 Here you will learn all about the latency of our network.
					+ Local
					menu = Local
					title = Local Network
					++ LocalMachine
					menu = Local Machine
					title = This host
					host = localhost

services.smokeping.user.description: User that runs smokeping and (optionally) thttpd

services.snapper.cleanupInterval.description:
Cleanup interval.

The format is described in
<citerefentry><refentrytitle>systemd.time</refentrytitle>
<manvolnum>7</manvolnum></citerefentry>.

services.snapper.configs.<name>.extraCon.description:
Additional configuration next to SUBVOLUME and FSTYPE.
See man:snapper-configs(5).

services.snapper.configs.<name>.fstype.description: Filesystem type. Only btrfs is stable and tested.

services.snapper.configs.<name>.subvolum.description:
Path of the subvolume or mount point.
This path is a subvolume and has to contain a subvolume named
.snapshots.
See also man:snapper(8) section PERMISSIONS.

services.snapper.filters.description: Global display difference filter. See man:snapper(8) for more details.

services.snapper.snapshotInterval.description:
Snapshot interval.

The format is described in
<citerefentry><refentrytitle>systemd.time</refentrytitle>
<manvolnum>7</manvolnum></citerefentry>.

services.snapserver.controlPort.type: 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

services.snapserver.openFirewall.description: Whether to automatically open the specified ports in the firewall.

services.snapserver.port.description: The port that snapclients can connect to.
services.snapserver.port.type: 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

services.snapserver.streams.description: The definition for an input source.

services.snapserver.streams.<name>.query.description: Key-value pairs that convey additional parameters about a stream.

services.sniproxy.config.description: sniproxy.conf configuration excluding the daemon username and pid file.

services.sniproxy.logDir.description: Location of the log directory for sniproxy.

services.sniproxy.user.description: User account under which sniproxy runs.

services.softether.enable.description: Whether to enable SoftEther VPN services.

services.softether.vpnbridge.enable.description: Whether to enable SoftEther VPN Bridge.

services.softether.vpnclient.down.description: Shell commands executed when the Virtual Network Adapter(s) is/are shutting down.

services.softether.vpnclient.enable.description: Whether to enable SoftEther VPN Client.

services.softether.vpnclient.up.description: Shell commands executed when the Virtual Network Adapter(s) is/are starting.

services.softether.vpnserver.enable.description: Whether to enable SoftEther VPN Server.

services.solr.extraJavaOptions.description: Extra command line options given to the java process running Solr.

services.solr.group.description: Group under which Solr is ran.

services.solr.package.description:
Which Solr package to use. This defaults to version 7.x if
<literal>system.stateVersion < 19.09</literal> and version 8.x
otherwise.

services.solr.port.description: Port on which Solr is ran.

services.solr.stateDir.description: The solr home directory containing config, data, and logging files.

services.solr.user.description: User under which Solr is ran.

services.sonarr.dataDir.description: The directory where Sonarr stores its data files.

services.sonarr.openFirewall.description: Open ports in the firewall for the Sonarr web interface

services.sonarr.user.description: User account under which Sonaar runs.
