Set to <literal>null</literal> to disable checkpointing.

services.tarsnap.archives.<name>.directo.description: List of filesystem paths to archive.

services.tarsnap.archives.<name>.exclude.description: Exclude files and directories matching these patterns.

services.tarsnap.archives.<name>.explici.description: Whether to follow symlinks specified as archives.

services.tarsnap.archives.<name>.followS.description: Whether to follow all symlinks in archive trees.

services.tarsnap.archives.<name>.include.description:
Include only files and directories matching these
patterns (the empty list includes everything).

Exclusions have precedence over inclusions.

services.tarsnap.archives.<name>.keyfile.description:
Set a specific keyfile for this archive. This defaults to
<literal>"/root/tarsnap.key"</literal> if left unspecified.

Use this option if you want to run multiple backups
concurrently - each archive must have a unique key. You can
generate a write-only key derived from your master key (which
is recommended) using <literal>tarsnap-keymgmt(1)</literal>.

Note: every archive must have an individual master key. You
must generate multiple keys with
<literal>tarsnap-keygen(1)</literal>, and then generate write
only keys from those.

The keyfile name should be given as a string and not a path, to
avoid the key being copied into the Nix store.

services.tarsnap.archives.<name>.lowmem.description:
Reduce memory consumption by not caching small files.
Possibly beneficial if the average file size is smaller
than 1 MB and the number of files is lower than the
total amount of RAM in KB.

services.tarsnap.archives.<name>.maxbw.description:
Abort archival if upstream bandwidth usage in bytes
exceeds this threshold.

services.tarsnap.archives.<name>.maxbwRa.description: Download bandwidth rate limit in bytes.
Upload bandwidth rate limit in bytes.

services.tarsnap.archives.<name>.period.description:
Create archive at this interval.

The format is described in
<citerefentry><refentrytitle>systemd.time</refentrytitle>
<manvolnum>7</manvolnum></citerefentry>.

services.tarsnap.archives.<name>.printSt.description:
Print global archive statistics upon completion.
The output is available via
<command>systemctl status tarsnap-archive-name</command>.

services.tarsnap.archives.<name>.verbose.description: Whether to produce verbose logging output.

services.tarsnap.archives.<name>.verylow.description:
Reduce memory consumption by a factor of 2 beyond what
<literal>lowmem</literal> does, at the cost of significantly
slowing down the archiving process.

services.tarsnap.keyfile.description:
The keyfile which associates this machine with your tarsnap
account.
Create the keyfile with <command>tarsnap-keygen</command>.

Note that each individual archive (specified below) may also have its
own individual keyfile specified. Tarsnap does not allow multiple
concurrent backups with the same cache directory and key (starting a
new backup will cause another one to fail). If you have multiple
archives specified, you should either spread out your backups to be
far apart, or specify a separate key for each archive. By default
every archive defaults to using
<literal>"/root/tarsnap.key"</literal>.

It's recommended for backups that you generate a key for every archive
using <literal>tarsnap-keygen(1)</literal>, and then generate a
write-only tarsnap key using <literal>tarsnap-keymgmt(1)</literal>,
and keep your master key(s) for a particular machine off-site.

The keyfile name should be given as a string and not a path, to
avoid the key being copied into the Nix store.

services.taskserver.allowedClientIDs.description:
A list of regular expressions that are matched against the reported
client id (such as <literal>task 2.3.0</literal>).

The values <literal>all</literal> or <literal>none</literal> have
special meaning. Overidden by any entry in the option
<option>services.taskserver.disallowedClientIDs</option>.

services.taskserver.ciphers.description:
List of GnuTLS ciphers to use. See the GnuTLS documentation about
priority strings at <link xlink:href="https://gnutls.org/manual/html_node/Priority-Strings.html"/> for full details.

services.taskserver.config.description:
Configuration options to pass to Taskserver.

The options here are the same as described in <citerefentry>
  <refentrytitle>taskdrc</refentrytitle>
  <manvolnum>5</manvolnum>
</citerefentry>, but with one difference:

The <literal>server</literal> option is
<literal>server.listen</literal> here, because the
<literal>server</literal> option would collide with other options
like <literal>server.cert</literal> and we would run in a type error
(attribute set versus string).

Nix types like integers or booleans are automatically converted to
the right values Taskserver would expect.

services.taskserver.confirmation.description: Determines whether certain commands are confirmed.

services.taskserver.disallowedClientIDs.description:
A list of regular expressions that are matched against the reported
client id (such as <literal>task 2.3.0</literal>).

The values <literal>all</literal> or <literal>none</literal> have
special meaning. Any entry here overrides those in
<option>services.taskserver.allowedClientIDs</option>.

services.taskserver.enable.description:
Whether to enable the Taskwarrior server.

More instructions about NixOS in conjuction with Taskserver can be
found in the NixOS manual at
<olink targetdoc="manual" targetptr="module-taskserver"/>.

services.taskserver.extensions.description:
Fully qualified path of the Taskserver extension scripts.
Currently there are none.

services.taskserver.fqdn.description:
The fully qualified domain name of this server, which is also used
as the common name in the certificates.

services.taskserver.ipLog.description: Logs the IP addresses of incoming requests.

services.taskserver.listenHost.description:
The address (IPv4, IPv6 or DNS) to listen on.

If the value is something else than <literal>localhost</literal> the
port defined by <option>listenPort</option> is automatically added to
<option>networking.firewall.allowedTCPPorts</option>.

services.taskserver.organisations.description:
An attribute set where the keys name the organisation and the values
are a set of lists of <option>users</option> and
<option>groups</option>.

services.taskserver.organisations.<name>.description: A list of group names that belong to the organization.
A list of user names that belong to the organization.

services.taskserver.pki.auto.bits.description:
The bit size for generated keys.

<note><para>
This option is for the automatically handled CA and will be ignored if any
of the <option>services.taskserver.pki.manual.*</option> options are set.
</para></note>

services.taskserver.pki.auto.expiration..description:
The expiration time of the CA certificate in days or <literal>null</literal> for no
expiration time.


<note><para>
This option is for the automatically handled CA and will be ignored if any
of the <option>services.taskserver.pki.manual.*</option> options are set.
</para></note>

The expiration time of client certificates in days or <literal>null</literal> for no
expiration time.


<note><para>
This option is for the automatically handled CA and will be ignored if any
of the <option>services.taskserver.pki.manual.*</option> options are set.
</para></note>

The expiration time of the certificate revocation list (CRL) in days or <literal>null</literal> for no
expiration time.


<note><para>
This option is for the automatically handled CA and will be ignored if any
of the <option>services.taskserver.pki.manual.*</option> options are set.
</para></note>

The expiration time of the server certificate in days or <literal>null</literal> for no
expiration time.


<note><para>
This option is for the automatically handled CA and will be ignored if any
of the <option>services.taskserver.pki.manual.*</option> options are set.
</para></note>

services.taskserver.pki.manual.ca.cert.description:
Fully qualified path to the CA certificate.
<note><para>
Setting this option will prevent automatic CA creation and handling.
</para></note>

services.taskserver.pki.manual.server.ce.description:
Fully qualified path to the server certificate.
<note><para>
Setting this option will prevent automatic CA creation and handling.
</para></note>

services.taskserver.pki.manual.server.cr.description:
Fully qualified path to the server certificate revocation list.
<note><para>
Setting this option will prevent automatic CA creation and handling.
</para></note>

services.taskserver.pki.manual.server.ke.description:
Fully qualified path to the server key.
<note><para>
Setting this option will prevent automatic CA creation and handling.
</para></note>

services.taskserver.queueSize.description:
Size of the connection backlog, see <citerefentry>
  <refentrytitle>listen</refentrytitle>
  <manvolnum>2</manvolnum>
</citerefentry>.

services.taskserver.requestLimit.description: Size limit of incoming requests, in bytes.

services.taskserver.trust.description:
Determines how client certificates are validated.

The value <literal>allow all</literal> performs no client
certificate validation. This is not recommended. The value
<literal>strict</literal> causes the client certificate to be
validated against a CA.

services.tautulli.configFile.description: The location of Tautulli's config file.

services.tautulli.dataDir.description: The directory where Tautulli stores its data files.

services.tautulli.enable.description: Whether to enable Tautulli Plex Monitor.

services.tautulli.user.description: User account under which Tautulli runs.

services.tcsd.conformanceCred.description:
Path to the conformance credential for your TPM.
See also the platformCred option

services.tcsd.enable.description:
Whether to enable tcsd, a Trusted Computing management service
that provides TCG Software Stack (TSS).  The tcsd daemon is
the only portal to the Trusted Platform Module (TPM), a hardware
chip on the motherboard.

services.tcsd.endorsementCred.description:
Path to the endorsement credential for your TPM.
See also the platformCred option

services.tcsd.firmwarePCRs.description: PCR indices used in the TPM for firmware measurements.

services.tcsd.group.description: Group account under which tcsd runs.

services.tcsd.kernelPCRs.description: PCR indices used in the TPM for kernel measurements.

services.tcsd.platformCred.description:
Path to the platform credential for your TPM. Your TPM
manufacturer may have provided you with a set of credentials
(certificates) that should be used when creating identities
using your TPM. When a user of your TPM makes an identity,
this credential will be encrypted as part of that process.
See the 1.1b TPM Main specification section 9.3 for information
on this process.

services.tcsd.stateDir.description:
The location of the system persistent storage file.
The system persistent storage file holds keys and data across
restarts of the TCSD and system reboots.

services.tcsd.user.description: User account under which tcsd runs.

services.teamspeak3.dataDir.description: Directory to store TS3 database and other state/data files.

services.teamspeak3.defaultVoicePort.description: Default UDP port for clients to connect to virtual servers - used for first virtual server, subsequent ones will open on incrementing port numbers by default.

services.teamspeak3.enable.description: Whether to run the Teamspeak3 voice communication server daemon.

services.teamspeak3.fileTransferIP.description: IP on which the server instance will listen for incoming file transfer connections. Defaults to any IP.

services.teamspeak3.fileTransferPort.description: TCP port opened for file transfers.

services.teamspeak3.logPath.description: Directory to store log files in.

services.teamspeak3.queryIP.description: IP on which the server instance will listen for incoming ServerQuery connections. Defaults to any IP.

services.teamspeak3.queryPort.description: TCP port opened for ServerQuery connections.

services.teamspeak3.voiceIP.description: IP on which the server instance will listen for incoming voice connections. Defaults to any IP.

services.tedicross.config.description:
<filename>settings.yaml</filename> configuration as a Nix attribute set.
Secret tokens should be specified using <option>environmentFile</option>
instead of this world-readable file.

services.tedicross.enable.description: Whether to enable the TediCross Telegram-Discord bridge service.

services.tedicross.environmentFile.description:
File containing environment variables to be passed to the TediCross service,
in which secret tokens can be specified securely using the
<literal>TELEGRAM_BOT_TOKEN</literal> and <literal>DISCORD_BOT_TOKEN</literal>
keys.

services.telepathy.enable.description:
Whether to enable Telepathy service, a communications framework
that enables real-time communication via pluggable protocol backends.

services.terraria.autoCreatedWorldSize.description:
Specifies the size of the auto-created world if <literal>worldPath</literal> does not
point to an existing world.

services.terraria.banListPath.description: The path to the ban list.

services.terraria.enable.description:
If enabled, starts a Terraria server. The server can be connected to via <literal>tmux -S /var/lib/terraria/terraria.sock attach</literal>
for administration by users who are a part of the <literal>terraria</literal> group (use <literal>C-b d</literal> shortcut to detach again).

services.terraria.maxPlayers.description: Sets the max number of players (between 1 and 255).

services.terraria.messageOfTheDay.description: Set the server message of the day text.

services.terraria.noUPnP.description: Disables automatic Universal Plug and Play.

services.terraria.password.description: Sets the server password. Leave <literal>null</literal> for no password.

services.terraria.port.description: Specifies the port to listen on.

services.terraria.secure.description: Adds additional cheat protection to the server.

services.terraria.worldPath.description:
The path to the world file (<literal>.wld</literal>) which should be loaded.
If no world exists at this path, one will be created with the size
specified by <literal>autoCreatedWorldSize</literal>.

services.tftpd.enable.description:
Whether to enable tftpd, a Trivial File Transfer Protocol server.
The server will be run as an xinetd service.

services.tftpd.path.description: Where the tftp server files are stored.

services.thanos.compact.arguments.description:
Arguments to the <literal>thanos compact</literal> command.

Defaults to a list of arguments formed by converting the structured
options of <option>services.thanos.compact</option> to a list of arguments.

Overriding this option will cause none of the structured options to have
any effect. So only set this if you know what you're doing!

services.thanos.compact.block-sync-concu.description:
Number of goroutines to use when syncing block metadata from object storage.

Defaults to <literal>20</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.compact.compact.concurre.description:
Number of goroutines to use when compacting groups.

Defaults to <literal>1</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.compact.consistency-dela.description:
Minimum age of fresh (non-compacted) blocks before they are being
processed. Malformed blocks older than the maximum of consistency-delay
and 30m0s will be removed.

Defaults to <literal>30m</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.compact.enable.description: Whether to enable the Thanos compactor which continuously compacts blocks in an object store bucket.

services.thanos.compact.http-address.description:
Listen <literal>host:port</literal> for HTTP endpoints.

Defaults to <literal>0.0.0.0:10902</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.compact.log.level.description:
Log filtering level.

Defaults to <literal>info</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.compact.objstore.config.description:
Object store configuration.

When not <literal>null</literal> the attribute set gets converted to
a YAML file and stored in the Nix store. The option
<option>objstore.config-file</option> will default to its path.

If <option>objstore.config-file</option> is set this option has no effect.

services.thanos.compact.objstore.config-.default:
if config.services.thanos.<cmd>.objstore.config == null then null
else toString (toYAML "objstore.yaml" config.services.thanos.<cmd>.objstore.config);
services.thanos.compact.objstore.config-.description: Path to YAML file that contains object store configuration.

services.thanos.compact.retention.resolu.description:
How long to retain samples of resolution 2 (1 hour) in bucket.

<literal>0d</literal> - disables this retention

Defaults to <literal>0d</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

How long to retain samples of resolution 1 (5 minutes) in bucket.

<literal>0d</literal> - disables this retention

Defaults to <literal>0d</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

How long to retain raw samples in bucket.

<literal>0d</literal> - disables this retention

Defaults to <literal>0d</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.compact.startAt.description:
When this option is set to a <literal>systemd.time</literal>
specification the Thanos compactor will run at the specified period.

When this option is <literal>null</literal> the Thanos compactor service
will run continuously. So it will not exit after all compactions have
been processed but wait for new work.

services.thanos.compact.stateDir.description:
Data directory relative to <literal>/var/lib</literal>
in which to cache blocks and process compactions.

services.thanos.compact.tracing.config.description:
Tracing configuration.

When not <literal>null</literal> the attribute set gets converted to
a YAML file and stored in the Nix store. The option
<option>tracing.config-file</option> will default to its path.

If <option>tracing.config-file</option> is set this option has no effect.

services.thanos.compact.tracing.config-f.default:
if config.services.thanos.<cmd>.tracing.config == null then null
else toString (toYAML "tracing.yaml" config.services.thanos.<cmd>.tracing.config);
services.thanos.compact.tracing.config-f.description: Path to YAML file that contains tracing configuration.

services.thanos.downsample.arguments.description:
Arguments to the <literal>thanos downsample</literal> command.

Defaults to a list of arguments formed by converting the structured
options of <option>services.thanos.downsample</option> to a list of arguments.

Overriding this option will cause none of the structured options to have
any effect. So only set this if you know what you're doing!

services.thanos.downsample.enable.description: Whether to enable the Thanos downsampler which continuously downsamples blocks in an object store bucket.

services.thanos.downsample.log.level.description:
Log filtering level.

Defaults to <literal>info</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.downsample.objstore.conf.description:
Object store configuration.

When not <literal>null</literal> the attribute set gets converted to
a YAML file and stored in the Nix store. The option
<option>objstore.config-file</option> will default to its path.

If <option>objstore.config-file</option> is set this option has no effect.

services.thanos.downsample.objstore.conf.default:
if config.services.thanos.<cmd>.objstore.config == null then null
else toString (toYAML "objstore.yaml" config.services.thanos.<cmd>.objstore.config);
services.thanos.downsample.objstore.conf.description: Path to YAML file that contains object store configuration.

services.thanos.downsample.stateDir.description:
Data directory relative to <literal>/var/lib</literal>
in which to cache blocks and process downsamplings.

services.thanos.downsample.tracing.confi.description:
Tracing configuration.

When not <literal>null</literal> the attribute set gets converted to
a YAML file and stored in the Nix store. The option
<option>tracing.config-file</option> will default to its path.

If <option>tracing.config-file</option> is set this option has no effect.

services.thanos.downsample.tracing.confi.default:
if config.services.thanos.<cmd>.tracing.config == null then null
else toString (toYAML "tracing.yaml" config.services.thanos.<cmd>.tracing.config);
services.thanos.downsample.tracing.confi.description: Path to YAML file that contains tracing configuration.

services.thanos.package.description: The thanos package that should be used.

services.thanos.query.arguments.description:
Arguments to the <literal>thanos query</literal> command.

Defaults to a list of arguments formed by converting the structured
options of <option>services.thanos.query</option> to a list of arguments.

Overriding this option will cause none of the structured options to have
any effect. So only set this if you know what you're doing!

services.thanos.query.enable.description: Whether to enable the Thanos query node exposing PromQL enabled Query API with data retrieved from multiple store nodes.

services.thanos.query.grpc-address.description:
Listen <literal>ip:port</literal> address for gRPC endpoints (StoreAPI).

Make sure this address is routable from other components.

Defaults to <literal>0.0.0.0:10901</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.query.grpc-client-server.description:
Server name to verify the hostname on the returned gRPC certificates.
See <link xlink:href="https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4366#section-3.1"/>

services.thanos.query.grpc-client-tls-ca.description: TLS CA Certificates to use to verify gRPC servers

services.thanos.query.grpc-client-tls-ce.description: TLS Certificates to use to identify this client to the server

services.thanos.query.grpc-client-tls-ke.description: TLS Key for the client's certificate

services.thanos.query.grpc-client-tls-se.description: Use TLS when talking to the gRPC server

services.thanos.query.grpc-server-tls-ce.description: TLS Certificate for gRPC server, leave blank to disable TLS

services.thanos.query.grpc-server-tls-cl.description:
TLS CA to verify clients against.

If no client CA is specified, there is no client verification on server side.
(tls.NoClientCert)

services.thanos.query.grpc-server-tls-ke.description: TLS Key for the gRPC server, leave blank to disable TLS

services.thanos.query.http-address.description:
Listen <literal>host:port</literal> for HTTP endpoints.

Defaults to <literal>0.0.0.0:10902</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.query.log.level.description:
Log filtering level.

Defaults to <literal>info</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.query.query.auto-downsam.description:
Enable automatic adjustment (step / 5) to what source of data should
be used in store gateways if no
<literal>max_source_resolution</literal> param is specified.

services.thanos.query.query.default-eval.description:
Set default evaluation interval for sub queries.

Defaults to <literal>1m</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.query.query.max-concurre.description:
Maximum number of queries processed concurrently by query node.

Defaults to <literal>20</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.query.query.partial-resp.description:
Enable partial response for queries if no
<literal>partial_response</literal> param is specified.

services.thanos.query.query.replica-labe.description:
Label to treat as a replica indicator along which data is
deduplicated.

Still you will be able to query without deduplication using
<literal>dedup=false</literal> parameter.

services.thanos.query.query.timeout.description:
Maximum time to process query by query node.

Defaults to <literal>2m</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.query.selector-labels.description: Query selector labels that will be exposed in info endpoint.

services.thanos.query.store.addresses.description:
Addresses of statically configured store API servers.

The scheme may be prefixed with <literal>dns+</literal> or
<literal>dnssrv+</literal> to detect store API servers through
respective DNS lookups.

services.thanos.query.store.response-tim.description:
If a Store doesn't send any data in this specified duration then a
Store will be ignored and partial data will be returned if it's
enabled. <literal>0</literal> disables timeout.

Defaults to <literal>0ms</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.query.store.sd-dns-inter.description:
Interval between DNS resolutions.

Defaults to <literal>30s</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.query.store.sd-files.description:
Path to files that contain addresses of store API servers. The path
can be a glob pattern.

services.thanos.query.store.sd-interval.description:
Refresh interval to re-read file SD files. It is used as a resync fallback.

Defaults to <literal>5m</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.query.store.unhealthy-ti.description:
Timeout before an unhealthy store is cleaned from the store UI page.

Defaults to <literal>5m</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.query.tracing.config.description:
Tracing configuration.

When not <literal>null</literal> the attribute set gets converted to
a YAML file and stored in the Nix store. The option
<option>tracing.config-file</option> will default to its path.

If <option>tracing.config-file</option> is set this option has no effect.

services.thanos.query.tracing.config-fil.default:
if config.services.thanos.<cmd>.tracing.config == null then null
else toString (toYAML "tracing.yaml" config.services.thanos.<cmd>.tracing.config);
services.thanos.query.tracing.config-fil.description: Path to YAML file that contains tracing configuration.

services.thanos.query.web.external-prefi.description:
Static prefix for all HTML links and redirect URLs in the UI query web
interface.

Actual endpoints are still served on / or the
<option>web.route-prefix</option>. This allows thanos UI to be served
behind a reverse proxy that strips a URL sub-path.

services.thanos.query.web.prefix-header.description:
Name of HTTP request header used for dynamic prefixing of UI links and
redirects.

This option is ignored if the option
<literal>web.external-prefix</literal> is set.

Security risk: enable this option only if a reverse proxy in front of
thanos is resetting the header.

The setting <literal>web.prefix-header="X-Forwarded-Prefix"</literal>
can be useful, for example, if Thanos UI is served via Traefik reverse
proxy with <literal>PathPrefixStrip</literal> option enabled, which
sends the stripped prefix value in <literal>X-Forwarded-Prefix</literal>
header. This allows thanos UI to be served on a sub-path.

services.thanos.query.web.route-prefix.description:
Prefix for API and UI endpoints.

This allows thanos UI to be served on a sub-path. This option is
analogous to <option>web.route-prefix</option> of Promethus.

services.thanos.receive.arguments.description:
Arguments to the <literal>thanos receive</literal> command.

Defaults to a list of arguments formed by converting the structured
options of <option>services.thanos.receive</option> to a list of arguments.

Overriding this option will cause none of the structured options to have
any effect. So only set this if you know what you're doing!

services.thanos.receive.enable.description: Whether to enable the Thanos receiver which accept Prometheus remote write API requests and write to local tsdb (EXPERIMENTAL, this may change drastically without notice).

services.thanos.receive.grpc-address.description:
Listen <literal>ip:port</literal> address for gRPC endpoints (StoreAPI).

Make sure this address is routable from other components.

Defaults to <literal>0.0.0.0:10901</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.receive.grpc-server-tls-.description: TLS Certificate for gRPC server, leave blank to disable TLS

TLS CA to verify clients against.

If no client CA is specified, there is no client verification on server side.
(tls.NoClientCert)
TLS Key for the gRPC server, leave blank to disable TLS

services.thanos.receive.http-address.description:
Listen <literal>host:port</literal> for HTTP endpoints.

Defaults to <literal>0.0.0.0:10902</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.receive.labels.description:
External labels to announce.

This flag will be removed in the future when handling multiple tsdb
instances is added.

services.thanos.receive.log.level.description:
Log filtering level.

Defaults to <literal>info</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.receive.objstore.config.description:
Object store configuration.

When not <literal>null</literal> the attribute set gets converted to
a YAML file and stored in the Nix store. The option
<option>objstore.config-file</option> will default to its path.

If <option>objstore.config-file</option> is set this option has no effect.

services.thanos.receive.objstore.config-.default:
if config.services.thanos.<cmd>.objstore.config == null then null
else toString (toYAML "objstore.yaml" config.services.thanos.<cmd>.objstore.config);
services.thanos.receive.objstore.config-.description: Path to YAML file that contains object store configuration.

services.thanos.receive.remote-write.add.description:
Address to listen on for remote write requests.

Defaults to <literal>0.0.0.0:19291</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.receive.stateDir.description: Data directory relative to <literal>/var/lib</literal> of TSDB.

services.thanos.receive.tracing.config.description:
Tracing configuration.

When not <literal>null</literal> the attribute set gets converted to
a YAML file and stored in the Nix store. The option
<option>tracing.config-file</option> will default to its path.

If <option>tracing.config-file</option> is set this option has no effect.

services.thanos.receive.tracing.config-f.default:
if config.services.thanos.<cmd>.tracing.config == null then null
else toString (toYAML "tracing.yaml" config.services.thanos.<cmd>.tracing.config);
services.thanos.receive.tracing.config-f.description: Path to YAML file that contains tracing configuration.

services.thanos.receive.tsdb.retention.description:
How long to retain raw samples on local storage.

<literal>0d</literal> - disables this retention

Defaults to <literal>15d</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.rule.alert.label-drop.description:
Labels by name to drop before sending to alertmanager.

This allows alert to be deduplicated on replica label.

Similar Prometheus alert relabelling

services.thanos.rule.alert.query-url.description: The external Thanos Query URL that would be set in all alerts 'Source' field.

services.thanos.rule.alertmanagers.send-.description:
Timeout for sending alerts to alertmanager.

Defaults to <literal>10s</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.rule.alertmanagers.urls.description:
Alertmanager replica URLs to push firing alerts.

Ruler claims success if push to at least one alertmanager from
discovered succeeds. The scheme may be prefixed with
<literal>dns+</literal> or <literal>dnssrv+</literal> to detect
Alertmanager IPs through respective DNS lookups. The port defaults to
<literal>9093</literal> or the SRV record's value. The URL path is
used as a prefix for the regular Alertmanager API path.

services.thanos.rule.arguments.description:
Arguments to the <literal>thanos rule</literal> command.

Defaults to a list of arguments formed by converting the structured
options of <option>services.thanos.rule</option> to a list of arguments.

Overriding this option will cause none of the structured options to have
any effect. So only set this if you know what you're doing!

services.thanos.rule.enable.description: Whether to enable the Thanos ruler service which evaluates Prometheus rules against given Query nodes, exposing Store API and storing old blocks in bucket.

services.thanos.rule.eval-interval.description:
The default evaluation interval to use.

Defaults to <literal>30s</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.rule.grpc-address.description:
Listen <literal>ip:port</literal> address for gRPC endpoints (StoreAPI).

Make sure this address is routable from other components.

Defaults to <literal>0.0.0.0:10901</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.rule.grpc-server-tls-cer.description: TLS Certificate for gRPC server, leave blank to disable TLS

services.thanos.rule.grpc-server-tls-cli.description:
TLS CA to verify clients against.

If no client CA is specified, there is no client verification on server side.
(tls.NoClientCert)

services.thanos.rule.grpc-server-tls-key.description: TLS Key for the gRPC server, leave blank to disable TLS

services.thanos.rule.http-address.description:
Listen <literal>host:port</literal> for HTTP endpoints.

Defaults to <literal>0.0.0.0:10902</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.rule.labels.description:
Labels to be applied to all generated metrics.

Similar to external labels for Prometheus,
used to identify ruler and its blocks as unique source.

services.thanos.rule.log.level.description:
Log filtering level.

Defaults to <literal>info</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.rule.objstore.config.description:
Object store configuration.

When not <literal>null</literal> the attribute set gets converted to
a YAML file and stored in the Nix store. The option
<option>objstore.config-file</option> will default to its path.

If <option>objstore.config-file</option> is set this option has no effect.

services.thanos.rule.objstore.config-fil.default:
if config.services.thanos.<cmd>.objstore.config == null then null
else toString (toYAML "objstore.yaml" config.services.thanos.<cmd>.objstore.config);
services.thanos.rule.objstore.config-fil.description: Path to YAML file that contains object store configuration.

services.thanos.rule.query.addresses.description:
Addresses of statically configured query API servers.

The scheme may be prefixed with <literal>dns+</literal> or
<literal>dnssrv+</literal> to detect query API servers through
respective DNS lookups.

services.thanos.rule.query.sd-dns-interv.description:
Interval between DNS resolutions.

Defaults to <literal>30s</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.rule.query.sd-files.description:
Path to file that contain addresses of query peers.
The path can be a glob pattern.

services.thanos.rule.query.sd-interval.description:
Refresh interval to re-read file SD files. (used as a fallback)

Defaults to <literal>5m</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.rule.rule-files.description: Rule files that should be used by rule manager. Can be in glob format.

services.thanos.rule.tracing.config.description:
Tracing configuration.

When not <literal>null</literal> the attribute set gets converted to
a YAML file and stored in the Nix store. The option
<option>tracing.config-file</option> will default to its path.

If <option>tracing.config-file</option> is set this option has no effect.

services.thanos.rule.tracing.config-file.default:
if config.services.thanos.<cmd>.tracing.config == null then null
else toString (toYAML "tracing.yaml" config.services.thanos.<cmd>.tracing.config);
services.thanos.rule.tracing.config-file.description: Path to YAML file that contains tracing configuration.

services.thanos.rule.tsdb.block-duration.description:
Block duration for TSDB block.

Defaults to <literal>2h</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.rule.tsdb.retention.description:
Block retention time on local disk.

Defaults to <literal>48h</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.rule.web.external-prefix.description:
Static prefix for all HTML links and redirect URLs in the UI query web
interface.

Actual endpoints are still served on / or the
<option>web.route-prefix</option>. This allows thanos UI to be served
behind a reverse proxy that strips a URL sub-path.

services.thanos.rule.web.prefix-header.description:
Name of HTTP request header used for dynamic prefixing of UI links and
redirects.

This option is ignored if the option
<option>web.external-prefix</option> is set.

Security risk: enable this option only if a reverse proxy in front of
thanos is resetting the header.

The header <literal>X-Forwarded-Prefix</literal> can be useful, for
example, if Thanos UI is served via Traefik reverse proxy with
<literal>PathPrefixStrip</literal> option enabled, which sends the
stripped prefix value in <literal>X-Forwarded-Prefix</literal>
header. This allows thanos UI to be served on a sub-path.

services.thanos.rule.web.route-prefix.description:
Prefix for API and UI endpoints.

This allows thanos UI to be served on a sub-path.

This option is analogous to <literal>--web.route-prefix</literal> of Promethus.

services.thanos.sidecar.arguments.description:
Arguments to the <literal>thanos sidecar</literal> command.

Defaults to a list of arguments formed by converting the structured
options of <option>services.thanos.sidecar</option> to a list of arguments.

Overriding this option will cause none of the structured options to have
any effect. So only set this if you know what you're doing!

services.thanos.sidecar.enable.description: Whether to enable the Thanos sidecar for Prometheus server.

services.thanos.sidecar.grpc-address.description:
Listen <literal>ip:port</literal> address for gRPC endpoints (StoreAPI).

Make sure this address is routable from other components.

Defaults to <literal>0.0.0.0:10901</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.sidecar.grpc-server-tls-.description: TLS Certificate for gRPC server, leave blank to disable TLS

TLS CA to verify clients against.

If no client CA is specified, there is no client verification on server side.
(tls.NoClientCert)
TLS Key for the gRPC server, leave blank to disable TLS

services.thanos.sidecar.http-address.description:
Listen <literal>host:port</literal> for HTTP endpoints.

Defaults to <literal>0.0.0.0:10902</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.sidecar.log.level.description:
Log filtering level.

Defaults to <literal>info</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.sidecar.objstore.config.description:
Object store configuration.

When not <literal>null</literal> the attribute set gets converted to
a YAML file and stored in the Nix store. The option
<option>objstore.config-file</option> will default to its path.

If <option>objstore.config-file</option> is set this option has no effect.

services.thanos.sidecar.objstore.config-.default:
if config.services.thanos.<cmd>.objstore.config == null then null
else toString (toYAML "objstore.yaml" config.services.thanos.<cmd>.objstore.config);
services.thanos.sidecar.objstore.config-.description: Path to YAML file that contains object store configuration.

services.thanos.sidecar.prometheus.url.description:
URL at which to reach Prometheus's API.

For better performance use local network.

Defaults to <literal>http://localhost:9090</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.sidecar.reloader.config-.description: Output file for environment variable substituted config file.
Config file watched by the reloader.

services.thanos.sidecar.reloader.rule-di.description: Rule directories for the reloader to refresh.

services.thanos.sidecar.tracing.config.description:
Tracing configuration.

When not <literal>null</literal> the attribute set gets converted to
a YAML file and stored in the Nix store. The option
<option>tracing.config-file</option> will default to its path.

If <option>tracing.config-file</option> is set this option has no effect.

services.thanos.sidecar.tracing.config-f.default:
if config.services.thanos.<cmd>.tracing.config == null then null
else toString (toYAML "tracing.yaml" config.services.thanos.<cmd>.tracing.config);
services.thanos.sidecar.tracing.config-f.description: Path to YAML file that contains tracing configuration.

services.thanos.store.arguments.description:
Arguments to the <literal>thanos store</literal> command.

Defaults to a list of arguments formed by converting the structured
options of <option>services.thanos.store</option> to a list of arguments.

Overriding this option will cause none of the structured options to have
any effect. So only set this if you know what you're doing!

services.thanos.store.block-sync-concurr.description:
Number of goroutines to use when syncing blocks from object storage.

Defaults to <literal>20</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.store.chunk-pool-size.description:
Maximum size of concurrently allocatable bytes for chunks.

Defaults to <literal>2GB</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.store.enable.description: Whether to enable the Thanos store node giving access to blocks in a bucket provider..

services.thanos.store.grpc-address.description:
Listen <literal>ip:port</literal> address for gRPC endpoints (StoreAPI).

Make sure this address is routable from other components.

Defaults to <literal>0.0.0.0:10901</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.store.grpc-server-tls-ce.description: TLS Certificate for gRPC server, leave blank to disable TLS

services.thanos.store.grpc-server-tls-cl.description:
TLS CA to verify clients against.

If no client CA is specified, there is no client verification on server side.
(tls.NoClientCert)

services.thanos.store.grpc-server-tls-ke.description: TLS Key for the gRPC server, leave blank to disable TLS

services.thanos.store.http-address.description:
Listen <literal>host:port</literal> for HTTP endpoints.

Defaults to <literal>0.0.0.0:10902</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.store.index-cache-size.description:
Maximum size of items held in the index cache.

Defaults to <literal>250MB</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.store.log.level.description:
Log filtering level.

Defaults to <literal>info</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.store.objstore.config.description:
Object store configuration.

When not <literal>null</literal> the attribute set gets converted to
a YAML file and stored in the Nix store. The option
<option>objstore.config-file</option> will default to its path.

If <option>objstore.config-file</option> is set this option has no effect.

services.thanos.store.objstore.config-fi.default:
if config.services.thanos.<cmd>.objstore.config == null then null
else toString (toYAML "objstore.yaml" config.services.thanos.<cmd>.objstore.config);
services.thanos.store.objstore.config-fi.description: Path to YAML file that contains object store configuration.

services.thanos.store.stateDir.description:
Data directory relative to <literal>/var/lib</literal>
in which to cache remote blocks.

services.thanos.store.store.grpc.series-.description:
Maximum number of concurrent Series calls.

Defaults to <literal>20</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

Maximum amount of samples returned via a single Series call.

<literal>0</literal> means no limit.

NOTE: for efficiency we take 120 as the number of samples in chunk (it
cannot be bigger than that), so the actual number of samples might be
lower, even though the maximum could be hit.

Defaults to <literal>0</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.store.sync-block-duratio.description:
Repeat interval for syncing the blocks between local and remote view.

Defaults to <literal>3m</literal> in Thanos
when set to <literal>null</literal>.

services.thanos.store.tracing.config.description:
Tracing configuration.

When not <literal>null</literal> the attribute set gets converted to
a YAML file and stored in the Nix store. The option
<option>tracing.config-file</option> will default to its path.

If <option>tracing.config-file</option> is set this option has no effect.

services.thanos.store.tracing.config-fil.default:
if config.services.thanos.<cmd>.tracing.config == null then null
else toString (toYAML "tracing.yaml" config.services.thanos.<cmd>.tracing.config);
services.thanos.store.tracing.config-fil.description: Path to YAML file that contains tracing configuration.

services.thelounge.enable.description: Whether to enable The Lounge web IRC client.

services.thelounge.extraConfig.description:
The Lounge's <filename>config.js</filename> contents as attribute set (will be
converted to JSON to generate the configuration file).

The options defined here will be merged to the default configuration file.
Note: In case of duplicate configuration, options from <option>extraConfig</option> have priority.

Documentation: <link xlink:href="https://thelounge.chat/docs/server/configuration" />

services.thelounge.port.description: TCP port to listen on for http connections.
services.thelounge.port.type: 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

services.thelounge.private.description:
Make your The Lounge instance private. You will need to configure user
accounts by using the (<command>thelounge</command>) command or by adding
entries in <filename>/var/lib/thelounge/users</filename>. You might need to restart
The Lounge after making changes to the state directory.

services.thermald.enable.description: Whether to enable thermald, the temperature management daemon.

services.thinkfan.enable.description: Whether to enable thinkfan, fan controller for IBM/Lenovo ThinkPads.

services.thinkfan.fan.description:
Specifies the fan we want to use.
On anything other than a Thinkpad you'll probably
use some PWM control file in /sys/class/hwmon.
A sysfs fan would be specified like this:
  pwm_fan /sys/class/hwmon/hwmon2/device/pwm1

services.thinkfan.levels.description:
(LEVEL, LOW, HIGH)
LEVEL is the fan level to use (0-7 with thinkpad_acpi).
LOW is the temperature at which to step down to the previous level.
HIGH is the temperature at which to step up to the next level.
All numbers are integers.

services.thinkfan.sensors.description:
thinkfan can read temperatures from three possible sources:

  /proc/acpi/ibm/thermal
    Which is provided by the thinkpad_acpi kernel
    module (keyword tp_thermal)

  /sys/class/hwmon/*/temp*_input
    Which may be provided by any hwmon drivers (keyword
    hwmon)

  S.M.A.R.T. (requires smartSupport to be enabled)
    Which reads the temperature directly from the hard
    disk using libatasmart (keyword atasmart)

Multiple sensors may be added, in which case they will be
numbered in their order of appearance.

services.thinkfan.smartSupport.description:
Whether to build thinkfan with SMART support to read temperatures 
directly from hard disks.

services.throttled.enable.description: Whether to enable fix for Intel CPU throttling.

services.tiddlywiki.enable.description: Whether to enable TiddlyWiki nodejs server.

services.tiddlywiki.listenOptions.description:
Parameters passed to <literal>--listen</literal> command.
Refer to <link xlink:href="https://tiddlywiki.com/#WebServer"/>
for details on supported values.

services.timesyncd.enable.description: Enables the systemd NTP client daemon.

services.timesyncd.servers.description: The set of NTP servers from which to synchronise.

services.tinc.networks.description:
Defines the tinc networks which will be started.
Each network invokes a different daemon.

services.tinc.networks.<name>.bindToAddr.description: The ip address to bind to (both listen on and send packets from).

services.tinc.networks.<name>.chroot.description:
Change process root directory to the directory where the config file is located (/etc/tinc/netname/), for added security.
The chroot is performed after all the initialization is done, after writing pid files and opening network sockets.

Note that tinc can't run scripts anymore (such as tinc-down or host-up), unless it is setup to be runnable inside chroot environment.

services.tinc.networks.<name>.debugLevel.description:
The amount of debugging information to add to the log. 0 means little
logging while 5 is the most logging. <command>man tincd</command> for
more details.

services.tinc.networks.<name>.ed25519Pri.description: Path of the private ed25519 keyfile.

services.tinc.networks.<name>.extraConfi.description: Extra lines to add to the tinc service configuration file.

services.tinc.networks.<name>.hosts.description:
The name of the host in the network as well as the configuration for that host.
This name should only contain alphanumerics and underscores.
services.tinc.networks.<name>.hosts.type: attribute set of strings concatenated with "\n"s

services.tinc.networks.<name>.interfaceT.description: The type of virtual interface used for the network connection

services.tinc.networks.<name>.listenAddr.description: The ip address to listen on for incoming connections.

services.tinc.networks.<name>.name.description:
The name of the node which is used as an identifier when communicating
with the remote nodes in the mesh. If null then the hostname of the system
is used to derive a name (note that tinc may replace non-alphanumeric characters in
hostnames by underscores).

services.tinc.networks.<name>.package.description: The package to use for the tinc daemon's binary.

services.tinydns.data.description: The DNS data to serve, in the format described by tinydns-data(8)

services.tinydns.enable.description: Whether to run the tinydns dns server

services.tinydns.ip.description: IP address on which to listen for connections

services.tlp.enable.description: Whether to enable the TLP daemon.

services.tomcat.axis2.enable.description: Whether to enable an Apache Axis2 container

services.tomcat.axis2.services.description: List containing AAR files or directories with AAR files which are web services to be deployed on Axis2

services.tomcat.baseDir.description:
Location where Tomcat stores configuration files, web applications
and logfiles. Note that it is partially cleared on each service startup
if `purifyOnStart` is enabled.

services.tomcat.catalinaOpts.description: Parameters to pass to the Java Virtual Machine which spawns the Catalina servlet container

services.tomcat.commonLibs.description: List containing JAR files or directories with JAR files which are libraries shared by the web applications and the servlet container

services.tomcat.extraConfigFiles.description: Extra configuration files to pull into the tomcat conf directory

services.tomcat.extraEnvironment.description: Environment Variables to pass to the tomcat service

services.tomcat.extraGroups.description: Defines extra groups to which the tomcat user belongs.

services.tomcat.group.description: Group account under which Apache Tomcat runs.

services.tomcat.javaOpts.description: Parameters to pass to the Java Virtual Machine which spawns Apache Tomcat

services.tomcat.logPerVirtualHost.description: Whether to enable logging per virtual host.

services.tomcat.purifyOnStart.description:
On startup, the `baseDir` directory is populated with various files,
subdirectories and symlinks. If this option is enabled, these items
(except for the `logs` and `work` subdirectories) are first removed.
This prevents interference from remainders of an old configuration
(libraries, webapps, etc.), so it's recommended to enable this option.

services.tomcat.serverXml.description:
Verbatim server.xml configuration.
          This is mutually exclusive with the virtualHosts options.

services.tomcat.sharedLibs.description: List containing JAR files or directories with JAR files which are libraries shared by the web applications

services.tomcat.user.description: User account under which Apache Tomcat runs.

services.tomcat.virtualHosts.description: List consisting of a virtual host name and a list of web applications to deploy on each virtual host

services.tomcat.virtualHosts.*.webapps.description:
List containing web application WAR files and/or directories containing
web applications and configuration files for the virtual host.

services.tomcat.webapps.description: List containing WAR files or directories with WAR files which are web applications to be deployed on Tomcat

services.tor.client.dns.automapHostsSuff.description: List of suffixes to use with automapHostsOnResolve

services.tor.client.dns.enable.description: Whether to enable tor dns resolver

services.tor.client.dns.listenAddress.description: Bind tor dns to this address.

services.tor.client.enable.description:
Whether to enable Tor daemon to route application
connections.  You might want to disable this if you plan
running a dedicated Tor relay.

services.tor.client.privoxy.enable.description:
Whether to enable and configure the system Privoxy to use Tor's
faster port, suitable for HTTP.

To have anonymity, protocols need to be scrubbed of identifying
information, and this can be accomplished for HTTP by Privoxy.

Privoxy can also be useful for KDE torification. A good setup would be:
setting SOCKS proxy to the default Tor port, providing maximum
circuit isolation where possible; and setting HTTP proxy to Privoxy
to route HTTP traffic over faster, but less isolated port.

services.tor.client.socksListenAddress.description:
Bind to this address to listen for connections from
Socks-speaking applications. Provides strong circuit
isolation, separate circuit per IP address.

services.tor.client.socksListenAddressFa.description:
Bind to this address to listen for connections from
Socks-speaking applications. Same as
<option>socksListenAddress</option> but uses weaker
circuit isolation to provide performance suitable for a
web browser.

services.tor.client.socksPolicy.description:
Entry policies to allow/deny SOCKS requests based on IP
address. First entry that matches wins. If no SocksPolicy
is set, we accept all (and only) requests from
<option>socksListenAddress</option>.

services.tor.client.transparentProxy.ena.description: Whether to enable tor transparent proxy

services.tor.client.transparentProxy.lis.description: Bind transparent proxy to this address.

services.tor.controlPort.description:
If set, Tor will accept connections on the specified port
and allow them to control the tor process.
services.tor.controlPort.type: null or signed integer or string

services.tor.controlSocket.enable.description:
Wheter to enable Tor control socket. Control socket is created
in <literal>/run/tor/control</literal>

services.tor.enable.description:
Enable the Tor daemon. By default, the daemon is run without
relay, exit, bridge or client connectivity.

services.tor.enableGeoIP.description:
Whenever to configure Tor daemon to use GeoIP databases.

Disabling this will disable by-country statistics for
bridges and relays and some client and third-party software
functionality.

services.tor.extraConfig.description:
Extra configuration. Contents will be added verbatim to the
configuration file at the end.

services.tor.hiddenServices.description:
A set of static hidden services that terminate their Tor
circuits at this node.

Every element in this set declares a virtual onion host.

You can specify your onion address by putting corresponding
private key to an appropriate place in /var/lib/tor.

For services without private keys in /var/lib/tor Tor
daemon will generate random key pairs (which implies random
onion addresses) on restart. The latter could take a while,
please be patient.

<note><para>
  Hidden services can be useful even if you don't intend to
  actually <emphasis>hide</emphasis> them, since they can
  also be seen as a kind of NAT traversal mechanism.

  E.g. the example will make your sshd, whatever runs on
  "8080" and your mail server available from anywhere where
  the Tor network is available (which, with the help from
  bridges, is pretty much everywhere), even if both client
  and server machines are behind NAT you have no control
  over.
</para></note>
services.tor.hiddenServices.type: list or attribute set of submodules

services.tor.hiddenServices.<name?>.auth.description: If configured, the hidden service is accessible for authorized clients only.

Either <literal>"basic"</literal> for a general-purpose authorization protocol
or <literal>"stealth"</literal> for a less scalable protocol
that also hides service activity from unauthorized clients.

Only clients that are listed here are authorized to access the hidden service.
Generated authorization data can be found in <filename>/var/lib/tor/onion/$name/hostname</filename>.
Clients need to put this authorization data in their configuration file using <literal>HidServAuth</literal>.
services.tor.hiddenServices.<name?>.auth.type: non-empty list of string matching the pattern [A-Za-z0-9+-_]+s

services.tor.hiddenServices.<name?>.map.description: Port mapping for this hidden service.

services.tor.hiddenServices.<name?>.name.description:
Name of this tor hidden service.

This is purely descriptive.

After restarting Tor daemon you should be able to
find your .onion address in
<literal>/var/lib/tor/onion/$name/hostname</literal>.

services.tor.hiddenServices.<name?>.vers.description: Rendezvous service descriptor version to publish for the hidden service. Currently, versions 2 and 3 are supported. (Default: 2)

services.tor.relay.accountingMax.description:
Specify maximum bandwidth allowed during an accounting period. This
allows you to limit overall tor bandwidth over some time period.
See the <literal>AccountingMax</literal> option by looking at the
tor manual <citerefentry><refentrytitle>tor</refentrytitle>
<manvolnum>1</manvolnum></citerefentry> for more.

Note this limit applies individually to upload and
download; if you specify <literal>"500 GBytes"</literal>
here, then you may transfer up to 1 TBytes of overall
bandwidth (500 GB upload, 500 GB download).

services.tor.relay.accountingStart.description:
Specify length of an accounting period. This allows you to limit
overall tor bandwidth over some time period. See the
<literal>AccountingStart</literal> option by looking at the tor
manual <citerefentry><refentrytitle>tor</refentrytitle>
<manvolnum>1</manvolnum></citerefentry> for more.

services.tor.relay.address.description:
The IP address or full DNS name for advertised address of your relay.
Leave unset and Tor will guess.

services.tor.relay.bandwidthBurst.description:
Specify this to allow bursts of the bandwidth usage of relayed (server)
traffic. The average usage will still be as specified in relayBandwidthRate.
Your own traffic is still unthrottled. Units: bytes/second.

services.tor.relay.bandwidthRate.description:
Specify this to limit the bandwidth usage of relayed (server)
traffic. Your own traffic is still unthrottled. Units: bytes/second.

services.tor.relay.contactInfo.description:
Contact information for the relay owner (e.g. a mail
address and GPG key ID).

services.tor.relay.enable.description:
Whether to enable relaying TOR traffic for others.

See <link xlink:href="https://www.torproject.org/docs/tor-doc-relay" />
for details.

Setting this to true requires setting
<option>services.tor.relay.role</option>
and
<option>services.tor.relay.port</option>
options.

services.tor.relay.exitPolicy.description:
A comma-separated list of exit policies. They're
considered first to last, and the first match wins. If you
want to _replace_ the default exit policy, end this with
either a reject *:* or an accept *:*. Otherwise, you're
_augmenting_ (prepending to) the default exit policy.
Leave commented to just use the default, which is
available in the man page or at
<link xlink:href="https://www.torproject.org/documentation.html" />.

Look at
<link xlink:href="https://www.torproject.org/faq-abuse.html#TypicalAbuses" />
for issues you might encounter if you use the default
exit policy.

If certain IPs and ports are blocked externally, e.g. by
your firewall, you should update your exit policy to
reflect this -- otherwise Tor users will be told that
those destinations are down.

services.tor.relay.nickname.description: A unique handle for your TOR relay.

services.tor.relay.port.description:
What port to advertise for Tor connections. This corresponds to the
<literal>ORPort</literal> section in the Tor manual; see
<citerefentry><refentrytitle>tor</refentrytitle>
<manvolnum>1</manvolnum></citerefentry> for more details.

At a minimum, you should just specify the port for the
relay to listen on; a common one like 143, 22, 80, or 443
to help Tor users who may have very restrictive port-based
firewalls.

services.tor.relay.role.description:
Your role in Tor network. There're several options:

<variablelist>
<varlistentry>
  <term><literal>exit</literal></term>
  <listitem>
    <para>
      An exit relay. This allows Tor users to access regular
      Internet services through your public IP.
    </para>

    <important><para>
      Running an exit relay may expose you to abuse
      complaints. See
      <link xlink:href="https://www.torproject.org/faq.html.en#ExitPolicies" />
      for more info.
    </para></important>

    <para>
      You can specify which services Tor users may access via
      your exit relay using <option>exitPolicy</option> option.
    </para>
  </listitem>
</varlistentry>

<varlistentry>
  <term><literal>relay</literal></term>
  <listitem>
    <para>
      Regular relay. This allows Tor users to relay onion
      traffic to other Tor nodes, but not to public
      Internet.
    </para>

    <important><para>
      Note that some misconfigured and/or disrespectful
      towards privacy sites will block you even if your
      relay is not an exit relay. That is, just being listed
      in a public relay directory can have unwanted
      consequences.

      Which means you might not want to use
      this role if you browse public Internet from the same
      network as your relay, unless you want to write
      e-mails to those sites (you should!).
    </para></important>

    <para>
      See
      <link xlink:href="https://www.torproject.org/docs/tor-doc-relay.html.en" />
      for more info.
    </para>
  </listitem>
</varlistentry>

<varlistentry>
  <term><literal>bridge</literal></term>
  <listitem>
    <para>
      Regular bridge. Works like a regular relay, but
      doesn't list you in the public relay directory and
      hides your Tor node behind obfs4proxy.
    </para>

    <para>
      Using this option will make Tor advertise your bridge
      to users through various mechanisms like
      <link xlink:href="https://bridges.torproject.org/" />, though.
    </para>

    <important>
      <para>
        WARNING: THE FOLLOWING PARAGRAPH IS NOT LEGAL ADVICE.
        Consult with your lawer when in doubt.
      </para>

      <para>
        This role should be safe to use in most situations
        (unless the act of forwarding traffic for others is
        a punishable offence under your local laws, which
        would be pretty insane as it would make ISP
        illegal).
      </para>
    </important>

    <para>
      See <link xlink:href="https://www.torproject.org/docs/bridges.html.en" />
      for more info.
    </para>
  </listitem>
</varlistentry>

<varlistentry>
  <term><literal>private-bridge</literal></term>
  <listitem>
    <para>
      Private bridge. Works like regular bridge, but does
      not advertise your node in any way.
    </para>

    <para>
      Using this role means that you won't contribute to Tor
      network in any way unless you advertise your node
      yourself in some way.
    </para>

    <para>
      Use this if you want to run a private bridge, for
      example because you'll give out your bridge address
      manually to your friends.
    </para>

    <para>
      Switching to this role after measurable time in
      "bridge" role is pretty useless as some Tor users
      would have learned about your node already. In the
      latter case you can still change
      <option>port</option> option.
    </para>

    <para>
      See <link xlink:href="https://www.torproject.org/docs/bridges.html.en" />
      for more info.
    </para>
  </listitem>
</varlistentry>
</variablelist>

services.tor.torsocks.allowInbound.description:
Set Torsocks to accept inbound connections. If set to
<literal>true</literal>, listen() and accept() will be
allowed to be used with non localhost address.

services.tor.torsocks.enable.description:
Whether to build <literal>/etc/tor/torsocks.conf</literal>
containing the specified global torsocks configuration.

services.tor.torsocks.fasterServer.description:
IP/Port of the Tor SOCKS server for torsocks-faster wrapper suitable for HTTP.
Currently, hostnames are NOT supported by torsocks.

services.tor.torsocks.onionAddrRange.description:
Tor hidden sites do not have real IP addresses. This
specifies what range of IP addresses will be handed to the
application as "cookies" for .onion names.  Of course, you
should pick a block of addresses which you aren't going to
ever need to actually connect to. This is similar to the
MapAddress feature of the main tor daemon.

services.tor.torsocks.server.description:
IP/Port of the Tor SOCKS server. Currently, hostnames are
NOT supported by torsocks.

services.tor.torsocks.socks5Password.description:
SOCKS5 password. The <literal>TORSOCKS_PASSWORD</literal>
environment variable overrides this option if it is set.

services.tor.torsocks.socks5Username.description:
SOCKS5 username. The <literal>TORSOCKS_USERNAME</literal>
environment variable overrides this option if it is set.

services.tor.tsocks.config.description:
Extra configuration. Contents will be added verbatim to TSocks
configuration file.

services.tor.tsocks.enable.description:
Whether to build tsocks wrapper script to relay application traffic via Tor.

<important>
  <para>You shouldn't use this unless you know what you're
  doing because your installation of Tor already comes with
  its own superior (doesn't leak DNS queries)
  <literal>torsocks</literal> wrapper which does pretty much
  exactly the same thing as this.</para>
</important>

services.tor.tsocks.server.description: IP address of TOR client to use.

services.torque.mom.enable.description: Whether to enable torque computing node.

services.tox-node.enable.description: Whether to enable Tox Node service.

services.tox-node.keysFile.description: Path to the file where DHT keys are stored.

services.tox-node.motd.default: Hi from tox-rs! I'm up {{uptime}}. TCP: incoming {{tcp_packets_in}}, outgoing {{tcp_packets_out}}, UDP: incoming {{udp_packets_in}}, outgoing {{udp_packets_out}}

services.tox-node.tcpAddresses.description: TCP addresses to run TCP relay.

services.tox-node.tcpConnectionLimit.description: Maximum number of active TCP connections relay can hold

services.tox-node.udpAddress.description: UDP address to run DHT node.

services.toxBootstrapd.enable.description: Whether to enable the Tox DHT bootstrap daemon.

services.toxBootstrapd.extraConfig.description:
Configuration for bootstrap daemon.
See <link xlink:href="https://github.com/irungentoo/toxcore/blob/master/other/bootstrap_daemon/tox-bootstrapd.conf"/>
and <link xlink:href="http://wiki.tox.im/Nodes"/>.

services.toxvpn.auto_add_peers.description: peers to automacally connect to on startup

services.toxvpn.enable.description: Whether to enable toxvpn running on startup.

services.toxvpn.port.description: udp port for toxcore, port-forward to help with connectivity if you run many nodes behind one NAT

services.traefik.configFile.description:
Path to verbatim traefik.toml to use.
(Using that option has precedence over <literal>configOptions</literal>)

services.traefik.dataDir.description: Location for any persistent data traefik creates, ie. acme

services.traefik.enable.description: Whether to enable Traefik web server.

services.traefik.group.description:
Set the group that traefik runs under.
For the docker backend this needs to be set to <literal>docker</literal> instead.

services.transmission.enable.description:
Whether or not to enable the headless Transmission BitTorrent daemon.

Transmission daemon can be controlled via the RPC interface using
transmission-remote or the WebUI (http://localhost:9091/ by default).

Torrents are downloaded to /var/lib/transmission/Downloads by default and are
accessible to users in the "transmission" group.

services.transmission.group.description: Group account under which Transmission runs.

services.transmission.home.description: The directory where transmission will create files.

services.transmission.port.description: TCP port number to run the RPC/web interface.

services.transmission.settings.description:
Attribute set whos fields overwrites fields in settings.json (each
time the service starts). String values must be quoted, integer and
boolean values must not.

See https://github.com/transmission/transmission/wiki/Editing-Configuration-Files
for documentation.

services.transmission.user.description: User account under which Transmission runs.

services.trezord.emulator.port.description: Listening port for the Trezor emulator.
services.trezord.emulator.port.type: 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

services.trezord.enable.description: Enable Trezor bridge daemon, for use with Trezor hardware bitcoin wallets.

services.triggerhappy.bindings.*.keys.description: List of keys to match.  Key names as defined in linux/input-event-codes.h

services.triggerhappy.enable.description: Whether to enable the <command>triggerhappy</command> hotkey daemon.

services.triggerhappy.extraConfig.description: Literal contents to append to the end of <command>triggerhappy</command> configuration file.

services.tsmBackup.autoTime.description:
The backup service will be invoked
automatically at the given date/time,
which must be in the format described in
<citerefentry><refentrytitle>systemd.time</refentrytitle><manvolnum>5</manvolnum></citerefentry>.
The default <literal>null</literal>
disables automatic backups.
services.tsmBackup.autoTime.type: null or string matching the pattern .+

services.tsmBackup.command.description:
The actual command passed to the
<literal>dsmc</literal> executable to start the backup.

services.tsmBackup.enable.description:
Whether to enable automatic backups with the
IBM Spectrum Protect (Tivoli Storage Manager, TSM) client.
This also enables
<option>programs.tsmClient.enable</option>
.

services.tsmBackup.servername.description:
Create a systemd system service
<literal>tsm-backup.service</literal> that starts
a backup based on the given servername's stanza.
Note that this server's
<option>passwdDir</option> will default to
<filename>/var/lib/tsm-backup/password</filename>
(but may be overridden);
also, the service will use
<filename>/var/lib/tsm-backup</filename> as
<literal>HOME</literal> when calling
<literal>dsmc</literal>.

services.tt-rss.auth.autoCreate.description:
Allow authentication modules to auto-create users in tt-rss internal
database when authenticated successfully.

services.tt-rss.auth.autoLogin.description:
Automatically login user on remote or other kind of externally supplied
authentication, otherwise redirect to login form as normal.
If set to true, users won't be able to set application language
and settings profile.

services.tt-rss.database.createLocally.description: Create the database and database user locally.

services.tt-rss.database.host.description: Host of the database. Leave null to use Unix domain socket.

services.tt-rss.database.port.description:
The database's port. If not set, the default ports will be provided (5432
and 3306 for pgsql and mysql respectively).

services.tt-rss.database.type.description: Database to store feeds. Supported are pgsql and mysql.

services.tt-rss.database.user.description:
The database user. The user must exist and has access to
the specified database.

services.tt-rss.email.fromAddress.description:
Address for sending outgoing mail. This applies to password reset
notifications, digest emails and any other mail.

services.tt-rss.email.fromName.description:
Name for sending outgoing mail. This applies to password reset
notifications, digest emails and any other mail.

services.tt-rss.email.login.description: SMTP authentication login used when sending outgoing mail.

services.tt-rss.email.password.description: SMTP authentication password used when sending outgoing mail.

services.tt-rss.email.security.description:
Used to select a secure SMTP connection. Allowed values: ssl, tls,
or empty.

services.tt-rss.email.server.description:
Hostname:port combination to send outgoing mail. Blank - use system
MTA.

services.tt-rss.enableGZipOutput.description:
Selectively gzip output to improve wire performance. This requires
PHP Zlib extension on the server.
Enabling this can break tt-rss in several httpd/php configurations,
if you experience weird errors and tt-rss failing to start, blank pages
after login, or content encoding errors, disable it.

services.tt-rss.feedCryptKey.description:
Key used for encryption of passwords for password-protected feeds
in the database. A string of 24 random characters. If left blank, encryption
is not used. Requires mcrypt functions.
Warning: changing this key will make your stored feed passwords impossible
to decrypt.

services.tt-rss.forceArticlePurge.description:
When this option is not 0, users ability to control feed purging
intervals is disabled and all articles (which are not starred)
older than this amount of days are purged.

services.tt-rss.logDestination.description:
Log destination to use. Possible values: sql (uses internal logging
you can read in Preferences -> System), syslog - logs to system log.
Setting this to blank uses PHP logging (usually to http server
error.log).

services.tt-rss.pluginPackages.description:
List of plugins to install. The list elements are expected to
be derivations. All elements in this derivation are automatically
copied to the <literal>plugins.local</literal> directory.

services.tt-rss.plugins.description:
List of plugins to load automatically for all users.
System plugins have to be specified here. Please enable at least one
authentication plugin here (auth_*).
Users may enable other user plugins from Preferences/Plugins but may not
disable plugins specified in this list.
Disabling auth_internal in this list would automatically disable
reset password link on the login form.

services.tt-rss.pool.description:
Name of existing phpfpm pool that is used to run web-application.
If not specified a pool will be created automatically with
default values.

services.tt-rss.pubSubHubbub.enable.description:
Enable client PubSubHubbub support in tt-rss. When disabled, tt-rss
won't try to subscribe to PUSH feed updates.

services.tt-rss.pubSubHubbub.hub.description:
URL to a PubSubHubbub-compatible hub server. If defined, "Published
articles" generated feed would automatically become PUSH-enabled.

services.tt-rss.registration.enable.description:
Allow users to register themselves. Please be aware that allowing
random people to access your tt-rss installation is a security risk
and potentially might lead to data loss or server exploit. Disabled
by default.

services.tt-rss.registration.maxUsers.description:
Maximum amount of users which will be allowed to register on this
system. 0 - no limit.

services.tt-rss.registration.notifyAddre.description: Email address to send new user notifications to.

services.tt-rss.selfUrlPath.description:
Full URL of your tt-rss installation. This should be set to the
location of tt-rss directory, e.g. http://example.org/tt-rss/
You need to set this option correctly otherwise several features
including PUSH, bookmarklets and browser integration will not work properly.

services.tt-rss.sessionCookieLifetime.description:
Default lifetime of a session (e.g. login) cookie. In seconds,
0 means cookie will be deleted when browser closes.

services.tt-rss.simpleUpdateMode.description:
Enables fallback update mode where tt-rss tries to update feeds in
background while tt-rss is open in your browser.
If you don't have a lot of feeds and don't want to or can't run
background processes while not running tt-rss, this method is generally
viable to keep your feeds up to date.
Still, there are more robust (and recommended) updating methods
available, you can read about them here: http://tt-rss.org/wiki/UpdatingFeeds

services.tt-rss.singleUserMode.description:
Operate in single user mode, disables all functionality related to
multiple users and authentication. Enabling this assumes you have
your tt-rss directory protected by other means (e.g. http auth).

services.tt-rss.sphinx.index.description:
Index names in Sphinx configuration. Example configuration
files are available on tt-rss wiki.

services.tt-rss.sphinx.server.description: Hostname:port combination for the Sphinx server.

services.tt-rss.themePackages.description:
List of themes to install. The list elements are expected to
be derivations. All elements in this derivation are automatically
copied to the <literal>themes.local</literal> directory.

services.tt-rss.user.description: User account under which both the update daemon and the web-application run.

services.tt-rss.virtualHost.description: Name of the nginx virtualhost to use and setup. If null, do not setup any virtualhost.

services.tumbler.enable.description: Whether to enable Tumbler, A D-Bus thumbnailer service.

services.tzupdate.enable.description:
Enable the tzupdate timezone updating service. This provides
a one-shot service which can be activated with systemctl to 
update the timezone.

services.u9fs.enable.description: Whether to run the u9fs 9P server for Unix.

services.u9fs.extraArgs.description:
Extra arguments to pass on invocation,
see <command>man 4 u9fs</command>

services.u9fs.listenStreams.description:
Sockets to listen for clients on.
See <command>man 5 systemd.socket</command> for socket syntax.

services.udev.extraHwdb.description:
Additional <command>hwdb</command> files. They'll be written
into file <filename>10-local.hwdb</filename>. Thus they are
read before all other files.

services.udev.extraRules.description:
Additional <command>udev</command> rules. They'll be written
into file <filename>99-local.rules</filename>. Thus they are
read and applied after all other rules.

services.udev.packages.description:
List of packages containing <command>udev</command> rules.
All files found in
<filename><replaceable>pkg</replaceable>/etc/udev/rules.d</filename> and
<filename><replaceable>pkg</replaceable>/lib/udev/rules.d</filename>
will be included.

services.udev.path.description:
Packages added to the <envar>PATH</envar> environment variable when
executing programs from Udev rules.

services.udisks2.enable.description:
Whether to enable Udisks, a DBus service that allows
applications to query and manipulate storage devices.

services.uhub.aclConfig.description: Contents of user ACL configuration file.

services.uhub.address.description: Address to bind the hub to.

services.uhub.enable.description: Whether to enable the uhub ADC hub.
