services.uhub.plugins.authSqlite.enable.description: Whether to enable the Sqlite authentication database plugin

services.uhub.plugins.authSqlite.file.description: Path to user database. Use the uhub-passwd utility to create the database and add/remove users.

services.uhub.plugins.history.connect.description: The number of chat history messages to send when users connect (0 = do not send any history).

services.uhub.plugins.history.default.description: When !history is provided without arguments, then this default number of messages are returned.

services.uhub.plugins.history.enable.description: Whether to enable the history plugin.

services.uhub.plugins.history.max.description: The maximum number of messages to keep in history

services.uhub.plugins.logging.enable.description: Whether to enable the logging plugin.

services.uhub.plugins.logging.syslog.description: If true then the system log is used instead of writing to file.

services.uhub.plugins.welcome.enable.description: Whether to enable the welcome plugin.

services.uhub.plugins.welcome.motd.description:
Welcome message displayed to clients after connecting
and with the <literal>!motd</literal> command.

services.uhub.plugins.welcome.rules.description: Rules message, displayed to clients with the <literal>!rules</literal> command.

services.uhub.port.description: TCP port to bind the hub to.

services.unbound.allowedAccess.description: What networks are allowed to use unbound as a resolver.

services.unbound.enable.description: Whether to enable Unbound domain name server.

services.unbound.enableRootTrustAnchor.description: Use and update root trust anchor for DNSSEC validation.

services.unbound.forwardAddresses.description: What servers to forward queries to.

services.unbound.interfaces.description: What addresses the server should listen on.

services.unclutter-xfixes.enable.description: Enable unclutter-xfixes to hide your mouse cursor when inactive.

services.unclutter-xfixes.extraOptions.description: More arguments to pass to the unclutter-xfixes command.

services.unclutter-xfixes.threshold.description: Minimum number of pixels considered cursor movement.

services.unclutter-xfixes.timeout.description: Number of seconds before the cursor is marked inactive.

services.unclutter.enable.description: Enable unclutter to hide your mouse cursor when inactive

services.unclutter.excluded.description: Names of windows where unclutter should not apply

services.unclutter.extraOptions.description: More arguments to pass to the unclutter command

services.unclutter.keystroke.description: Wait for a keystroke before hiding the cursor

services.unclutter.threeshold.description: Minimum number of pixels considered cursor movement

services.unclutter.timeout.description: Number of seconds before the cursor is marked inactive

services.undervolt.analogioOffset.description: The amount of voltage to offset analogio by. Accepts a floating point number.

services.undervolt.coreOffset.description: The amount of voltage to offset the CPU cores by. Accepts a floating point number.

services.undervolt.gpuOffset.description: The amount of voltage to offset the GPU by. Accepts a floating point number.

services.undervolt.temp.description: The temperature target. Accepts a floating point number.

services.undervolt.tempAc.description: The temperature target on AC power. Accepts a floating point number.

services.undervolt.tempBat.description: The temperature target on battery power. Accepts a floating point number.

services.undervolt.uncoreOffset.description: The amount of voltage to offset uncore by. Accepts a floating point number.

services.unifi.dataDir.description:
Where to store the database and other data.

This directory will be bind-mounted to /var/lib/unifi/data as part of the service startup.

services.unifi.enable.description: Whether or not to enable the unifi controller service.

services.unifi.initialJavaHeapSize.description:
Set the initial heap size for the JVM in MB. If this option isn't set, the
JVM will decide this value at runtime.

services.unifi.jrePackage.description: The JRE package to use. Check the release notes to ensure it is supported.

services.unifi.maximumJavaHeapSize.description:
Set the maximimum heap size for the JVM in MB. If this option isn't set, the
JVM will decide this value at runtime.

services.unifi.openPorts.description:
Whether or not to open the minimum required ports on the firewall.

This is necessary to allow firmware upgrades and device discovery to
work. For remote login, you should additionally open (or forward) port
8443.

services.unit.config.description: Unit configuration in JSON format. More details here https://unit.nginx.org/configuration

services.unit.enable.description: Whether to enable Unit App Server.

services.unit.group.description: Group account under which unit runs.

services.unit.user.description: User account under which unit runs.

services.upower.enable.description:
Whether to enable Upower, a DBus service that provides power
management support to applications.

services.uptime.configFile.description:
The uptime configuration file

If mongodb: server != localhost, please set usesRemoteMongo = true

If you only want to run the monitor, please set enableWebService = false
and enableSeparateMonitoringService = true

If autoStartMonitor: false (recommended) and you want to run both
services, please set enableSeparateMonitoringService = true

services.uptime.enableSeparateMonitoring.description: Whether to enable the uptime monitoring service.

services.uptime.enableWebService.description: Whether to enable the uptime monitoring program web service.

services.uptime.nodeEnv.description: The node environment to run in (development, production, etc.)

services.uptime.usesRemoteMongo.description: Whether the configuration file specifies a remote mongo instance

services.uptimed.enable.description:
Enable <literal>uptimed</literal>, allowing you to track
your highest uptimes.

services.urxvtd.enable.description:
Enable urxvtd, the urxvt terminal daemon. To use urxvtd, run
"urxvtc".

services.urxvtd.package.description: Package to install. Usually pkgs.rxvt_unicode-with-plugins or pkgs.rxvt_unicode

services.usbguard.IPCAccessControlFiles.description:
The files at this location will be interpreted by the daemon as IPC
access control definition files. See the IPC ACCESS CONTROL section
in <citerefentry><refentrytitle>usbguard-daemon.conf</refentrytitle>
<manvolnum>5</manvolnum></citerefentry> for more details.

services.usbguard.IPCAllowedGroups.description:
A list of groupnames that the daemon will accept IPC connections
from.

services.usbguard.IPCAllowedUsers.description: A list of usernames that the daemon will accept IPC connections from.

services.usbguard.auditFilePath.description: USBGuard audit events log file path.

services.usbguard.deviceRulesWithPort.description: Generate device specific rules including the "via-port" attribute.

services.usbguard.implictPolicyTarget.description:
How to treat USB devices that don't match any rule in the policy.
Target should be one of allow, block or reject (logically remove the
device node from the system).

services.usbguard.insertedDevicePolicy.description:
How to treat USB devices that are already connected after the daemon
starts. One of block, reject, apply-policy.

services.usbguard.package.description:
The usbguard package to use. If you do not need the Qt GUI, use
<literal>pkgs.usbguard-nox</literal> to save disk space.

services.usbguard.presentControllerPolic.description:
How to treat USB controller devices that are already connected when
the daemon starts. One of allow, block, reject, keep or apply-policy.

services.usbguard.presentDevicePolicy.description:
How to treat USB devices that are already connected when the daemon
starts. Policy should be one of allow, block, reject, keep (keep
whatever state the device is currently in) or apply-policy (evaluate
the rule set for every present device).

services.usbguard.restoreControllerDevic.description:
The  USBGuard  daemon  modifies  some attributes of controller
devices like the default authorization state of new child device
instances. Using this setting, you can controll whether the daemon
will try to restore the attribute values to the state before
modificaton on shutdown.

services.usbguard.ruleFile.description:
The USBGuard daemon will use this file to load the policy rule set
from it and to write new rules received via the IPC interface.

Running the command <literal>usbguard generate-policy</literal> as
root will generate a config for your currently plugged in devices.
For a in depth guide consult the official documentation.

Setting the <literal>rules</literal> option will ignore the
<literal>ruleFile</literal> option.

services.usbguard.rules.description:
The USBGuard daemon will load this policy rule set. Modifying it via
the IPC interface won't work if you use this option, since the
contents of this option will be written into the nix-store it will be
read-only.

You can still use <literal> usbguard generate-policy</literal> to
generate rules, but you would have to insert them here.

Setting the <literal>rules</literal> option will ignore the
<literal>ruleFile</literal> option.

services.usbmuxd.enable.description:
Enable the usbmuxd ("USB multiplexing daemon") service. This daemon is
in charge of multiplexing connections over USB to an iOS device. This is
needed for transferring data from and to iOS devices (see ifuse). Also
this may enable plug-n-play tethering for iPhones.

services.usbmuxd.group.description: The group usbmuxd should use to run after startup.

services.usbmuxd.user.description: The user usbmuxd should use to run after startup.

services.uvcvideo.dynctrl.enable.description:
Whether to enable <command>uvcvideo</command> dynamic controls.

Note that enabling this brings the <command>uvcdynctrl</command> tool
into your environement and register all dynamic controls from
specified <command>packages</command> to the <command>uvcvideo</command> driver.

services.uvcvideo.dynctrl.packages.description:
List of packages containing <command>uvcvideo</command> dynamic controls
rules. All files found in
<filename><replaceable>pkg</replaceable>/share/uvcdynctrl/data</filename>
will be included.

Note that these will serve as input to the <command>libwebcam</command>
package which through its own <command>udev</command> rule will register
the dynamic controls from specified packages to the <command>uvcvideo</command>
driver.

services.uwsgi.group.description: Group account under which uwsgi runs.

services.uwsgi.instance.description:
uWSGI configuration. It awaits an attribute <literal>type</literal> inside which can be either
<literal>normal</literal> or <literal>emperor</literal>.

For <literal>normal</literal> mode you can specify <literal>pythonPackages</literal> as a function
from libraries set into a list of libraries. <literal>pythonpath</literal> will be set accordingly.

For <literal>emperor</literal> mode, you should use <literal>vassals</literal> attribute
which should be either a set of names and configurations or a path to a directory.

Other attributes will be used in configuration file as-is. Notice that you can redefine
<literal>plugins</literal> setting here.

services.uwsgi.runDir.description: Where uWSGI communication sockets can live

services.uwsgi.user.description: User account under which uwsgi runs.

services.varnish.extraCommandLine.description: Command line switches for varnishd (run 'varnishd -?' to get list of options)

services.varnish.stateDir.description: Directory holding all state for Varnish to run.

services.vault.address.description: The name of the ip interface to listen to

services.vault.listenerExtraConfig.description: Extra text appended to the listener section.

services.vault.package.description: This option specifies the vault package to use.

services.vault.storageBackend.description: The name of the type of storage backend

services.vault.tlsCertFile.description: TLS certificate file. TLS will be disabled unless this option is set

services.vault.tlsKeyFile.description: TLS private key file. TLS will be disabled unless this option is set

services.vdr.enable.description: Whether to enable VDR. Please put config into /var/lib/vdr.

services.vdr.extraArguments.description: Additional command line arguments to pass to VDR.

services.venus.dates.description:
Specification (in the format described by
<citerefentry><refentrytitle>systemd.time</refentrytitle>
<manvolnum>7</manvolnum></citerefentry>) of the time at
which the Venus will collect feeds.

services.venus.enable.description:
Planet Venus is an awesome river of news feed reader. It downloads
news feeds published by web sites and aggregates their content
together into a single combined feed, latest news first.

services.venus.itemsPerPage.description: How many items to put on each page.

services.venus.outputTheme.description:
Directory containing a config.ini file which is merged with this one.
This is typically used to specify templating and bill of material
information.

services.virtlyst.adminPassword.description: Initial admin password with which the database will be seeded.

services.virtlyst.enable.description: Whether to enable Virtlyst libvirt web interface.

services.virtlyst.httpSocket.description: IP and/or port to which to bind the http socket.

services.virtuoso.config.description: Extra options to put into Virtuoso configuration file.

services.virtuoso.dirsAllowed.description: A list of directories Virtuoso is allowed to access

services.virtuoso.enable.description: Whether to enable Virtuoso Opensource database server.

services.virtuoso.httpListenAddress.description: ip:port or port for Virtuoso HTTP server to listen on.

services.virtuoso.listenAddress.description: ip:port or port to listen on.

services.virtuoso.parameters.description: Extra options to put into [Parameters] section of Virtuoso configuration file.

services.vnstat.enable.description: Whether to enable update of network usage statistics via vnstatd.

services.vsftpd.anonymousMkdirEnable.description: Whether any uploads are permitted to anonymous users.

services.vsftpd.anonymousUploadEnable.description: Whether any uploads are permitted to anonymous users.

services.vsftpd.anonymousUser.description: Whether to enable the anonymous FTP user.

services.vsftpd.anonymousUserHome.description: Directory to consider the HOME of the anonymous user.

services.vsftpd.anonymousUserNoPassword.description: Whether to disable the password for the anonymous FTP user.

services.vsftpd.chrootlocalUser.description: Whether local users are confined to their home directory.

services.vsftpd.enable.description: Whether to enable the vsftpd FTP server.

services.vsftpd.extraConfig.description: Extra configuration to add at the bottom of the generated configuration file.

services.vsftpd.forceLocalDataSSL.description:
Only applies if <option>sslEnable</option> is true. Non anonymous (local) users
must use a secure SSL connection for sending/receiving data on data connection.

services.vsftpd.forceLocalLoginsSSL.description:
Only applies if <option>sslEnable</option> is true. Non anonymous (local) users
must use a secure SSL connection to send a password.

services.vsftpd.localUsers.description: Whether to enable FTP for local users.

services.vsftpd.portPromiscuous.description:
Set to YES if you want to disable the PORT security check that ensures that
outgoing data connections can only connect to the client. Only enable if you
know what you are doing!

services.vsftpd.userlistDeny.description:
Specifies whether <option>userlistFile</option> is a list of user
names to allow or deny access.
The default <literal>false</literal> means whitelist/allow.

services.vsftpd.userlistFile.description:
Newline separated list of names to be allowed/denied if <option>userlistEnable</option>
is <literal>true</literal>. Meaning see <option>userlistDeny</option>.

The default is a file containing the users from <option>userlist</option>.

If explicitely set to null userlist_file will not be set in vsftpd's config file.

services.vsftpd.writeEnable.description: Whether any write activity is permitted to users.

services.wakeonlan.interfaces.description:
Interfaces where to enable Wake-On-LAN, and how. Two methods available:
"magicpacket" and "password". The password has the shape of six bytes
in hexadecimal separated by a colon each. For more information,
check the ethtool manual.

services.weechat.sessionName.description: Name of the `screen' session for weechat.

services.wordpress.description: Specification of one or more WordPress sites to serve via Apache.

services.wordpress.<name>.database.creat.description: Create the database and database user locally.

services.wordpress.<name>.database.passw.description:
A file containing the password corresponding to
<option>database.user</option>.

services.wordpress.<name>.database.port.type: 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

services.wordpress.<name>.database.socke.description: Path to the unix socket file to use for authentication.

services.wordpress.<name>.database.table.description:
The $table_prefix is the value placed in the front of your database tables.
Change the value if you want to use something other than wp_ for your database
prefix. Typically this is changed if you are installing multiple WordPress blogs
in the same database.

See <link xlink:href='https://codex.wordpress.org/Editing_wp-config.php#table_prefix'/>.

services.wordpress.<name>.extraConfig.description:
Any additional text to be appended to the wp-config.php
configuration file. This is a PHP script. For configuration
settings, see <link xlink:href='https://codex.wordpress.org/Editing_wp-config.php'/>.

services.wordpress.<name>.plugins.description:
List of path(s) to respective plugin(s) which are copied from the 'plugins' directory.
<note><para>These plugins need to be packaged before use, see example.</para></note>

services.wordpress.<name>.poolConfig.description:
Options for the WordPress PHP pool. See the documentation on <literal>php-fpm.conf</literal>
for details on configuration directives.
services.wordpress.<name>.poolConfig.type: attribute set of string or signed integer or booleans

services.wordpress.<name>.themes.description:
List of path(s) to respective theme(s) which are copied from the 'theme' directory.
<note><para>These themes need to be packaged before use, see example.</para></note>

services.wordpress.<name>.uploadsDir.description:
This directory is used for uploads of pictures. The directory passed here is automatically
created and permissions adjusted as required.

services.wordpress.<name>.virtualHost.description: Apache configuration can be done by adapting <option>services.httpd.virtualHosts</option>.

services.wordpress.<name>.virtualHost.ad.description: E-mail address of the server administrator.

services.wordpress.<name>.virtualHost.do.description:
The path of Apache's document root directory.  If left undefined,
an empty directory in the Nix store will be used as root.

services.wordpress.<name>.virtualHost.ex.description:

Enable support for Qt 4-based applications. Particularly, install a

services.xserver.desktopManager.surf-dis.description: Whether to enable surf-display as a kiosk browser session.
Extra configuration options to append to <literal>/etc/default/surf-display</literal>.
services.xserver.desktopManager.surf-dis.example:
# Enforce fixed resolution for all displays (default: not set):
DEFAULT_RESOLUTION="1920x1080"

# HTTP proxy URL, if needed (default: not set).
HTTP_PROXY_URL="http://webcache:3128"

# Configure individual display screens with host specific parameters:
DISPLAYS['display-host-0']="www_uri=https://www.displayserver.comany.net/display-1/index.html"
DISPLAYS['display-host-1']="www_uri=https://www.displayserver.comany.net/display-2/index.html"
DISPLAYS['display-host-2']="www_uri=https://www.displayserver.comany.net/display-3/index.html|res=1920x1280"
DISPLAYS['display-host-3']="www_uri=https://www.displayserver.comany.net/display-4/index.html"|res=1280x1024"
DISPLAYS['display-host-local-file']="www_uri=file:///usr/share/doc/surf-display/empty-page.html"

services.xserver.desktopManager.surf-dis.description:
Setting for internal inactivity timer to restart surf-display if the
user goes inactive/idle to get a fresh session for the next user of
the kiosk.

If this value is set to zero, the whole feature of restarting due to
inactivity is disabled.

Disable right and middle pointer device click in browser sessions
while keeping scrolling wheels' functionality intact. See pointer
subcommand on <literal>man xmodmap</literal> for details.
Screensaver settings, see <literal>man 1 xset</literal> for possible options.

services.xserver.desktopManager.wallpape.description:
When set to <literal>true</literal> the wallpaper will stretch across all screens.
When set to <literal>false</literal> the wallpaper is duplicated to all screens.

The file <filename>~/.background-image</filename> is used as a background image.
This option specifies the placement of this image onto your desktop.

Possible values:
<literal>center</literal>: Center the image on the background. If it is too small, it will be surrounded by a black border.
<literal>fill</literal>: Like <literal>scale</literal>, but preserves aspect ratio by zooming the image until it fits. Either a horizontal or a vertical part of the image will be cut off.
<literal>max</literal>: Like <literal>fill</literal>, but scale the image to the maximum size that fits the screen with black borders on one side.
<literal>scale</literal>: Fit the file into the background without repeating it, cutting off stuff or using borders. But the aspect ratio is not preserved either.
<literal>tile</literal>: Tile (repeat) the image in case it is too small for the screen.

services.xserver.desktopManager.xfce.noD.description: Don't install XFCE desktop components (xfdesktop, panel and notification daemon).

If set to false, run lightdm in greeterless mode. This only works if autologin

to use with the lightdm gtk greeter panel.

configuration file.

Built-in indicators include "~a11y", "~language", "~session",

services.xserver.displayManager.sddm.aut.description:
If true automatic login will kick in again on session exit (logout), otherwise it
will only log in automatically when the display-manager is started.

Whether to enable automatic HiDPI mode.
</para>

Versions up to 0.17 are broken so this only works from 0.18 onwards.

services.xserver.displayManager.sddm.ext.description: Extra lines appended to the configuration of SDDM.

services.xserver.displayManager.sddm.set.description:
A script to execute when starting the display server. DEPRECATED, please
use <option>services.xserver.displayManager.setupCommands</option>.
services.xserver.displayManager.sddm.set.example:
# workaround for using NVIDIA Optimus without Bumblebee
xrandr --setprovideroutputsource modesetting NVIDIA-0

services.xserver.displayManager.sddm.sto.description: A script to execute when stopping the display server.

services.xserver.displayManager.session.description:
List of sessions supported with the command used to start each
session.  Each session script can set the
<varname>waitPID</varname> shell variable to make this script
wait until the end of the user session.  Each script is used
to define either a window manager or a desktop manager.  These
can be differentiated by setting the attribute
<varname>manage</varname> either to <literal>"window"</literal>
or <literal>"desktop"</literal>.

The list of desktop manager and window manager should appear
inside the display manager with the desktop manager name
followed by the window manager name.

services.xserver.displayManager.sessionC.description:
Shell commands executed just before the window or desktop manager is
started. These commands are not currently sourced for Wayland sessions.

services.xserver.displayManager.setupCom.description:
Shell commands executed just after the X server has started.

This option is only effective for display managers for which this feature
is supported; currently these are LightDM, GDM and SDDM.

services.xserver.displayManager.slim.aut.description: Automatically log in as the default user.

services.xserver.displayManager.slim.con.description: The command to run when "console" is given as the username.

services.xserver.displayManager.slim.def.description:
The default user to load. If you put a username here you
get it automatically loaded into the username field, and
the focus is placed on the password.

services.xserver.displayManager.slim.ena.description: Whether to enable SLiM as the display manager.

services.xserver.displayManager.slim.ext.description:
Extra configuration options for SLiM login manager. Do not
add options that can be configured directly.

services.xserver.displayManager.slim.the.description:
The theme for the SLiM login manager.  If not specified, SLiM's
default theme is used.  See <link
xlink:href='http://slim.berlios.de/themes01.php'/> for a
collection of themes. TODO: berlios shut down.

services.xserver.displayManager.startx.e.description:
Whether to enable the dummy "startx" pseudo-display manager,
which allows users to start X manually via the "startx" command
from a vt shell. The X server runs under the user's id, not as root.
The user must provide a ~/.xinitrc file containing session startup
commands, see startx(1). This is not automatically generated
from the desktopManager and windowManager settings.

services.xserver.displayManager.xpra.aut.description: Authentication to use when connecting to xpra

services.xserver.displayManager.xpra.ena.description: Whether to enable xpra as display manager.

services.xserver.displayManager.xpra.pul.description: Whether to enable pulseaudio audio streaming.

services.xserver.displayManager.xserverA.description: List of arguments for the X server.

services.xserver.displayManager.xserverB.description: Path to the X server used by display managers.

services.xserver.dpi.description: DPI resolution to use for X server.

services.xserver.enable.description: Whether to enable the X server.

services.xserver.enableCtrlAltBackspace.description:
Whether to enable the DontZap option, which binds Ctrl+Alt+Backspace
to forcefully kill X. This can lead to data loss and is disabled
by default.

services.xserver.enableTCP.description: Whether to allow the X server to accept TCP connections.

services.xserver.exportConfiguration.description:
Whether to symlink the X server configuration under
<filename>/etc/X11/xorg.conf</filename>.

services.xserver.extraConfig.description: Additional contents (sections) included in the X server configuration file

services.xserver.extraDisplaySettings.description: Lines to be added to every Display subsection of the Screen section.

services.xserver.extraLayouts.description:
Extra custom layouts that will be included in the xkb configuration.
Information on how to create a new layout can be found here:
<link xlink:href="https://www.x.org/releases/current/doc/xorg-docs/input/XKB-Enhancing.html#Defining_New_Layouts"></link>.
For more examples see
<link xlink:href="https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/X_KeyBoard_extension#Basic_examples"></link>

services.xserver.extraLayouts.<name>.com.description:
The path to the xkb compat file.
This file sets the compatibility state, used to preserve
compatibility with xkb-unaware programs.
It must contain a <literal>xkb_compat "name" { ... }</literal> block.

services.xserver.extraLayouts.<name>.des.description: A short description of the layout.

services.xserver.extraLayouts.<name>.geo.description:
The path to the xkb geometry file.
This (completely optional) file describes the physical layout of
keyboard, which maybe be used by programs to depict it.
It must contain a <literal>xkb_geometry "name" { ... }</literal> block.

services.xserver.extraLayouts.<name>.key.description:
The path to the xkb keycodes file.
This file specifies the range and the interpretation of the raw
keycodes sent by the keyboard.
It must contain a <literal>xkb_keycodes "name" { ... }</literal> block.

services.xserver.extraLayouts.<name>.lan.description:
A list of languages provided by the layout.
(Use ISO 639-2 codes, for example: "eng" for english)

services.xserver.extraLayouts.<name>.sym.description:
The path to the xkb symbols file.
This is the most important file: it defines which symbol or action
maps to each key and must contain a
<literal>xkb_symbols "name" { ... }</literal> block.

services.xserver.extraLayouts.<name>.typ.description:
The path to the xkb types file.
This file specifies the key types that can be associated with
the various keyboard keys.
It must contain a <literal>xkb_types "name" { ... }</literal> block.

services.xserver.gdk-pixbuf.modulePackag.description: Packages providing GDK-Pixbuf modules, for cache generation.

services.xserver.inputClassSections.description: Content of additional InputClass sections of the X server configuration file.

example.text:
[ ''
    Identifier      "Trackpoint Wheel Emulation"
    MatchProduct    "ThinkPad USB Keyboard with TrackPoint"
    Option          "EmulateWheel"          "true"
    Option          "EmulateWheelButton"    "2"
    Option          "Emulate3Buttons"       "false"
  ''
]

services.xserver.layout.description: Keyboard layout, or multiple keyboard layouts separated by commas.

services.xserver.libinput.accelProfile.description:
Sets  the pointer acceleration profile to the given profile.
Permitted values are adaptive, flat.
Not all devices support this option or all profiles.
If a profile is unsupported, the default profile for this is used.
<literal>flat</literal>: Pointer motion is accelerated by a constant
(device-specific) factor, depending on the current speed.
<literal>adaptive</literal>: Pointer acceleration depends on the input speed.
This is the default profile for most devices.

services.xserver.libinput.accelSpeed.description: Cursor acceleration (how fast speed increases from minSpeed to maxSpeed).

services.xserver.libinput.additionalOpti.description: Additional options for libinput touchpad driver.

services.xserver.libinput.buttonMapping.description:
Sets the logical button mapping for this device, see XSetPointerMapping(3). The string  must
be  a  space-separated  list  of  button mappings in the order of the logical buttons on the
device, starting with button 1.  The default mapping is "1 2 3 ... 32". A mapping of 0 deac
tivates the button. Multiple buttons can have the same mapping.  Invalid mapping strings are
discarded and the default mapping is used for all buttons.  Buttons  not  specified  in  the
user's mapping use the default mapping. See section BUTTON MAPPING for more details.

services.xserver.libinput.calibrationMat.description:
A  string  of  9 space-separated floating point numbers.  Sets the calibration matrix to the
3x3 matrix where the first row is (abc), the second row is (def) and the third row is (ghi).

services.xserver.libinput.clickMethod.description:
Enables a click method. Permitted values are <literal>none</literal>,
<literal>buttonareas</literal>, <literal>clickfinger</literal>.
Not all devices support all methods, if an option is unsupported,
the default click method for this device is used.

services.xserver.libinput.dev.description:
Path for touchpad device.  Set to null to apply to any
auto-detected touchpad.

services.xserver.libinput.horizontalScro.description:
Disables horizontal scrolling. When disabled, this driver will discard any horizontal scroll
events from libinput. Note that this does not disable horizontal scrolling, it merely
discards the horizontal axis from any scroll events.

services.xserver.libinput.leftHanded.description: Enables left-handed button orientation, i.e. swapping left and right buttons.

services.xserver.libinput.middleEmulatio.description:
Enables middle button emulation. When enabled, pressing the left and right buttons
simultaneously produces a middle mouse button click.

services.xserver.libinput.naturalScrolli.description: Enables or disables natural scrolling behavior.

services.xserver.libinput.scrollButton.description:
Designates a button as scroll button. If the ScrollMethod is button and the button is logically
held down, x/y axis movement is converted into scroll events.

services.xserver.libinput.sendEventsMode.description:
Sets the send events mode to <literal>disabled</literal>, <literal>enabled</literal>,
or <literal>disabled-on-external-mouse</literal>

services.xserver.libinput.tappingDragLoc.description:
Enables or disables drag lock during tapping behavior. When enabled, a finger up during tap-
and-drag will not immediately release the button. If the finger is set down again within the
timeout, the draging process continues.

services.xserver.moduleSection.description: Contents of the Module section of the X server configuration file.

services.xserver.modules.description: Packages to be added to the module search path of the X server.

services.xserver.monitorSection.description: Contents of the first Monitor section of the X server configuration file.

services.xserver.multitouch.additionalOp.description: Additional options for mtrack touchpad driver.

services.xserver.multitouch.enable.description: Whether to enable multitouch touchpad support.

services.xserver.multitouch.ignorePalm.description: Whether to ignore touches detected as being the palm (i.e when typing)

services.xserver.multitouch.invertScroll.description: Whether to invert scrolling direction  la OSX Lion

services.xserver.resolutions.description:
The screen resolutions for the X server.  The first element
is the default resolution.  If this list is empty, the X
server will automatically configure the resolution.

services.xserver.screenSection.description: Contents of the first Screen section of the X server configuration file.

services.xserver.serverFlagsSection.description: Contents of the ServerFlags section of the X server configuration file.

services.xserver.serverLayoutSection.description: Contents of the ServerLayout section of the X server configuration file.

services.xserver.startDbusSession.description: Whether to start a new DBus session when you log in with dbus-launch.

services.xserver.synaptics.accelFactor.description: Cursor acceleration (how fast speed increases from minSpeed to maxSpeed).

services.xserver.synaptics.additionalOpt.description: Additional options for synaptics touchpad driver.

services.xserver.synaptics.dev.description:
Path for touchpad device.  Set to null to apply to any
auto-detected touchpad.

services.xserver.synaptics.enable.description: Whether to enable touchpad support. Deprecated: Consider services.xserver.libinput.enable.

services.xserver.synaptics.horizEdgeScro.description: Whether to enable horizontal edge drag-scrolling.

services.xserver.synaptics.horizTwoFinge.description: Whether to enable horizontal two-finger drag-scrolling.

services.xserver.synaptics.horizontalScr.description: Whether to enable horizontal scrolling (on touchpad)

services.xserver.synaptics.maxSpeed.description: Cursor speed factor for highest-speed finger motion.

services.xserver.synaptics.minSpeed.description: Cursor speed factor for precision finger motion.

services.xserver.synaptics.palmDetect.description: Whether to enable palm detection (hardware support required)

services.xserver.synaptics.palmMinWidth.description: Minimum finger width at which touch is considered a palm

services.xserver.synaptics.palmMinZ.description: Minimum finger pressure at which touch is considered a palm

services.xserver.synaptics.scrollDelta.description: Move distance of the finger for a scroll event.

services.xserver.synaptics.twoFingerScro.description: Whether to enable two-finger drag-scrolling. Overridden by horizTwoFingerScroll and vertTwoFingerScroll.

services.xserver.synaptics.vertEdgeScrol.description: Whether to enable vertical edge drag-scrolling.

services.xserver.synaptics.vertTwoFinger.description: Whether to enable vertical two-finger drag-scrolling.

services.xserver.terminateOnReset.description: Whether to terminate X upon server reset.

services.xserver.tty.description: Virtual console for the X server.

services.xserver.updateDbusEnvironment.description:
Whether to update the DBus activation environment after launching the
desktop manager.

services.xserver.useGlamor.description:
Whether to use the Glamor module for 2D acceleration,
if possible.

services.xserver.useXFS.description: Determines how to connect to the X Font Server.

services.xserver.videoDriver.description:
The name of the video driver for your graphics card.  This
option is obsolete; please set the
<option>services.xserver.videoDrivers</option> instead.

services.xserver.videoDrivers.description:
The names of the video drivers the configuration
supports. They will be tried in order until one that
supports your card is found.
Don't combine those with "incompatible" OpenGL implementations,
e.g. free ones (mesa-based) with proprietary ones.

For unfree "nvidia*", the supported GPU lists are on
https://www.nvidia.com/object/unix.html
services.xserver.videoDrivers.relatedPackages:
<itemizedlist><listitem><para><literal>amdgpu aka pkgs.xorg.xf86videoamdgpu (xf86-video-amdgpu-19.0.1)</literal>: ???.</para></listitem>

services.xserver.wacom.enable.description:
Whether to enable the Wacom touchscreen/digitizer/tablet.
If you ever have any issues such as, try switching to terminal (ctrl-alt-F1) and back
which will make Xorg reconfigure the device ?

If you're not satisfied by the default behaviour you can override
<option>environment.etc."X11/xorg.conf.d/70-wacom.conf"</option> in
configuration.nix easily.

services.xserver.windowManager.awesome.e.description: Whether to enable Awesome window manager.

services.xserver.windowManager.awesome.l.description: List of lua packages available for being used in the Awesome configuration.

services.xserver.windowManager.awesome.n.description: Disable client transparency support, which can be greatly detrimental to performance in some setups

services.xserver.windowManager.awesome.p.description: Package to use for running the Awesome WM.

If null, $HOME/.config/bspwm/bspwmrc will be used.

If null, $HOME/.config/sxhkd/sxhkdrc will be used.

services.xserver.windowManager.default.description: Default window manager loaded if none have been chosen.

Extra packages available to Emacs. The value must be a
function which receives the attrset defined in
<varname>emacsPackages</varname> as the sole argument.

services.xserver.windowManager.fvwm.enab.description: Whether to enable Fvwm window manager.

services.xserver.windowManager.fvwm.gest.description: Whether or not to enable libstroke for gesture support

services.xserver.windowManager.herbstluf.description:
Path to the herbstluftwm configuration file.  If left at the
default value, $XDG_CONFIG_HOME/herbstluftwm/autostart will
be used.

services.xserver.windowManager.i3.config.description:
Path to the i3 configuration file.
If left at the default value, $HOME/.i3/config will be used.

services.xserver.windowManager.i3.enable.description: Whether to enable i3 window manager.

services.xserver.windowManager.i3.extraP.description: Extra packages to be installed system wide.

services.xserver.windowManager.i3.extraS.description: Shell commands executed just before i3 is started.

services.xserver.windowManager.xmonad.co.description:
Configuration from which XMonad gets compiled. If no value
is specified, the xmonad config from $HOME/.xmonad is taken.
If you use xmonad --recompile, $HOME/.xmonad will be taken as
the configuration, but on the next restart of display-manager
this config will be reapplied.
services.xserver.windowManager.xmonad.co.example:
import XMonad

main = launch defaultConfig
       { modMask = mod4Mask -- Use Super instead of Alt
       , terminal = "urxvt"
       }

services.xserver.windowManager.xmonad.ex.description:
Extra packages available to ghc when rebuilding Xmonad. The
value must be a function which receives the attrset defined
in <varname>haskellPackages</varname> as the sole argument.

services.xserver.windowManager.xmonad.ha.description:
haskellPackages used to build Xmonad and other packages.
This can be used to change the GHC version used to build
Xmonad and the packages listed in
<varname>extraPackages</varname>.

(Has to be at least 10 minutes)

services.xserver.xautolock.locker.description: The script to use when automatically locking the computer.

services.xserver.xautolock.notifier.description: Notification script to be used to warn about the pending autolock.

services.xserver.xautolock.notify.description: Time (in seconds) before the actual lock when the notification about the pending lock should be published.

services.xserver.xautolock.nowlocker.description: The script to use when manually locking the computer with <command>xautolock -locknow</command>.

services.xserver.xautolock.time.description: Idle time (in minutes) to wait until xautolock locks the computer.

services.xserver.xkbOptions.description: X keyboard options; layout switching goes here.

services.xserver.xrandrHeads.description:
Multiple monitor configuration, just specify a list of XRandR
outputs. The individual elements should be either simple strings or
an attribute set of output options.

If the element is a string, it is denoting the physical output for a
monitor, if it's an attribute set, you must at least provide the
<option>output</option> option.

The monitors will be mapped from left to right in the order of the
list.

By default, the first monitor will be set as the primary monitor if
none of the elements contain an option that has set
<option>primary</option> to <literal>true</literal>.

<note><para>Only one monitor is allowed to be primary.</para></note>

Be careful using this option with multiple graphic adapters or with
drivers that have poor support for XRandR, unexpected things might
happen with those.
services.xserver.xrandrHeads.type: list of submodule or string convertible to its

services.xserver.xrandrHeads.*.monitorCo.description:
Extra lines to append to the <literal>Monitor</literal> section
verbatim. Available options are documented in the MONITOR section in
<citerefentry><refentrytitle>xorg.conf</refentrytitle>
<manvolnum>5</manvolnum></citerefentry>.

services.xserver.xrandrHeads.*.output.description:
The output name of the monitor, as shown by <citerefentry>
  <refentrytitle>xrandr</refentrytitle>
  <manvolnum>1</manvolnum>
</citerefentry> invoked without arguments.

services.xserver.xrandrHeads.*.primary.description: Whether this head is treated as the primary monitor,

services.xtreemfs.dir.address.description:
If specified, it defines the interface to listen on. If not
specified, the service will listen on all interfaces (any).

services.xtreemfs.dir.enable.description: Whether to enable XtreemFS DIR service.

services.xtreemfs.dir.extraConfig.description:
Configuration of XtreemFS DIR service.
WARNING: configuration is saved as plaintext inside nix store.
For more options: http://www.xtreemfs.org/xtfs-guide-1.5.1/index.html
services.xtreemfs.dir.extraConfig.example:
# specify whether SSL is required
ssl.enabled = true
ssl.service_creds.pw = passphrase
ssl.service_creds.container = pkcs12
ssl.service_creds = /etc/xos/xtreemfs/truststore/certs/dir.p12
ssl.trusted_certs = /etc/xos/xtreemfs/truststore/certs/trusted.jks
ssl.trusted_certs.pw = jks_passphrase
ssl.trusted_certs.container = jks

services.xtreemfs.dir.httpPort.description:
Specifies the listen port for the HTTP service that returns the
status page.

services.xtreemfs.dir.port.description: The port to listen on for incoming connections (TCP).

services.xtreemfs.dir.replication.enable.description: Whether to enable XtreemFS DIR replication plugin.

services.xtreemfs.dir.replication.extraC.description:
Configuration of XtreemFS DIR replication plugin.
WARNING: configuration is saved as plaintext inside nix store.
For more options: http://www.xtreemfs.org/xtfs-guide-1.5.1/index.html
services.xtreemfs.dir.replication.extraC.example:
# participants of the replication including this replica
babudb.repl.participant.0 = 192.168.0.10
babudb.repl.participant.0.port = 35676
babudb.repl.participant.1 = 192.168.0.11
babudb.repl.participant.1.port = 35676
babudb.repl.participant.2 = 192.168.0.12
babudb.repl.participant.2.port = 35676

# number of servers that at least have to be up to date
# To have a fault-tolerant system, this value has to be set to the
# majority of nodes i.e., if you have three replicas, set this to 2
# Please note that a setup with two nodes provides no fault-tolerance.
babudb.repl.sync.n = 2

# specify whether SSL is required
babudb.ssl.enabled = true

babudb.ssl.protocol = tlsv12

# server credentials for SSL handshakes
babudb.ssl.service_creds = /etc/xos/xtreemfs/truststore/certs/osd.p12
babudb.ssl.service_creds.pw = passphrase
babudb.ssl.service_creds.container = pkcs12

# trusted certificates for SSL handshakes
babudb.ssl.trusted_certs = /etc/xos/xtreemfs/truststore/certs/trusted.jks
babudb.ssl.trusted_certs.pw = jks_passphrase
babudb.ssl.trusted_certs.container = jks

babudb.ssl.authenticationWithoutEncryption = false

services.xtreemfs.dir.syncMode.description:
The sync mode influences how operations are committed to the disk
log before the operation is acknowledged to the caller.

-ASYNC mode the writes to the disk log are buffered in memory by the operating system. This is the fastest mode but will lead to data loss in case of a crash, kernel panic or power failure.
-SYNC_WRITE_METADATA opens the file with O_SYNC, the system will not buffer any writes. The operation will be acknowledged when data has been safely written to disk. This mode is slow but offers maximum data safety. However, BabuDB cannot influence the disk drive caches, this depends on the OS and hard disk model.
-SYNC_WRITE similar to SYNC_WRITE_METADATA but opens file with O_DSYNC which means that only the data is commit to disk. This can lead to some data loss depending on the implementation of the underlying file system. Linux does not implement this mode.
-FDATASYNC is similar to SYNC_WRITE but opens the file in asynchronous mode and calls fdatasync() after writing the data to disk.
-FSYNC is similar to SYNC_WRITE_METADATA but opens the file in asynchronous mode and calls fsync() after writing the data to disk.

For best throughput use ASYNC, for maximum data safety use FSYNC.

(If xtreemfs.dir.replication.enable is true then FDATASYNC is forced)

services.xtreemfs.mrc.enable.description: Whether to enable XtreemFS MRC service.

services.xtreemfs.mrc.extraConfig.description:
Configuration of XtreemFS MRC service.
WARNING: configuration is saved as plaintext inside nix store.
For more options: http://www.xtreemfs.org/xtfs-guide-1.5.1/index.html
services.xtreemfs.mrc.extraConfig.example:
osd_check_interval = 300
no_atime = true
local_clock_renewal = 0
remote_time_sync = 30000
authentication_provider = org.xtreemfs.common.auth.NullAuthProvider

# shared secret between the MRC and all OSDs
capability_secret = iNG8UuQJrJ6XVDTe

dir_service.host = 192.168.0.10
dir_service.port = 32638

# if replication is enabled
dir_service.1.host = 192.168.0.11
dir_service.1.port = 32638
dir_service.2.host = 192.168.0.12
dir_service.2.port = 32638

# specify whether SSL is required
ssl.enabled = true
ssl.protocol = tlsv12
ssl.service_creds.pw = passphrase
ssl.service_creds.container = pkcs12
ssl.service_creds = /etc/xos/xtreemfs/truststore/certs/mrc.p12
ssl.trusted_certs = /etc/xos/xtreemfs/truststore/certs/trusted.jks
ssl.trusted_certs.pw = jks_passphrase
ssl.trusted_certs.container = jks

services.xtreemfs.mrc.syncMode.description:
The sync mode influences how operations are committed to the disk
log before the operation is acknowledged to the caller.

-ASYNC mode the writes to the disk log are buffered in memory by the operating system. This is the fastest mode but will lead to data loss in case of a crash, kernel panic or power failure.
-SYNC_WRITE_METADATA opens the file with O_SYNC, the system will not buffer any writes. The operation will be acknowledged when data has been safely written to disk. This mode is slow but offers maximum data safety. However, BabuDB cannot influence the disk drive caches, this depends on the OS and hard disk model.
-SYNC_WRITE similar to SYNC_WRITE_METADATA but opens file with O_DSYNC which means that only the data is commit to disk. This can lead to some data loss depending on the implementation of the underlying file system. Linux does not implement this mode.
-FDATASYNC is similar to SYNC_WRITE but opens the file in asynchronous mode and calls fdatasync() after writing the data to disk.
-FSYNC is similar to SYNC_WRITE_METADATA but opens the file in asynchronous mode and calls fsync() after writing the data to disk.

For best throughput use ASYNC, for maximum data safety use FSYNC.

(If xtreemfs.mrc.replication.enable is true then FDATASYNC is forced)

services.zabbixWeb.server.address.description: The IP address or hostname of the Zabbix server to connect to.

services.zabbixWeb.server.port.description: The port of the Zabbix server to connect to.

services.zabbixWeb.virtualHost.description:
Apache configuration can be done by adapting <literal>services.httpd.virtualHosts.<name></literal>.
See <xref linkend="opt-services.httpd.virtualHosts"/> for further information.

services.zabbixWeb.virtualHost.adminAddr.description: E-mail address of the server administrator.

services.zabbixWeb.virtualHost.documentR.description:
The path of Apache's document root directory.  If left undefined,
an empty directory in the Nix store will be used as root.

services.zabbixWeb.virtualHost.extraConf.description:
These lines go to httpd.conf verbatim. They will go after

services.zabbixWeb.virtualHost.extraSubs.description: Extra subservices to enable in the webserver.

services.zabbixWeb.virtualHost.globalRed.description:
If set, all requests for this host are redirected permanently to

services.zabbixWeb.virtualHost.listen.description: List of { /* ip: "*"; */ port = 80;} to listen on

services.zabbixWeb.virtualHost.listen.*..description: Ip to listen on. 0.0.0.0 for ipv4 only, * for all.

services.zabbixWeb.virtualHost.logFormat.description: Log format for Apache's log files. Possible values are: combined, common, referer, agent.

services.zabbixWeb.virtualHost.robotsEnt.description:
